column10: Deadly Struggle

[h3]Like a Dragon [strike]Garbage[/strike]Gaiden: The Man Who Wasn't Able to Erase His Name[/h3]
Not for 50$, no. Game felt just as bad as Kiwami 1 mixed with Yakuza 3.
Yakuza 8 trial was tempting but after i finished Gaiden that trial felt as RGG+Sega were like "hey, at least you get Yakuza 8 trial" *crickets chirping*.
If you bought both Gaiden and Yakuza 8 you paid twice for Yakuza 8. 'Like a dragon: Gaiden' should be free or paid DLC for Yakuza 8 like 'Majima saga' was put into Kiwami 2.

Game feels really rushed. Imagine weird child of Kiwami 1, Yakuza 3 (mostly bad storytelling) with some things from Kiwami 2, Yakuza 6 and Judgement. These were my overall impressions.
If i wasn't familiar with Yakuza series and Gaiden was my first game i'd drop it after playing first chapter. Or even maybe first hour, because:
[olist]
    [*]things that could be optional and put as substories were obligatory to progress main story. Just like stupid missions with kids in Yakuza 3. This dumb intentional dragging.
    [*]top notch dialogues like:
- you're Kazuma Kiryu
- no, i'm Joryu
- you're Kiryu
- no, i'm telling you
- dude...
- bro, i swear
- tell me one more time you're not Kiryu i gonna beat your ass
- okay
    [*]nothing much to do besides Colliseum. Trailer looked promising with karaoke and cabaret, but reality is disappointing. Almost.
[/olist]
In the second chapter things get better.

Fights using agent style felt less soy as fights in Judgement games. You have gadgets that actually are fun to use against crowds. Drones suck and useless, explosive cigs are fun and chaotic. Yakuza style is okay, but i didn't like that you can evade only when you're locked on an enemy. And i couldn't figure out how to switch targets. Also switching styles was completely inconsistent and unresponsive. Animations prevent you from switching styles and this was really annoying when you're in the middle of a big fight.
There're Colliseum fights. They're more likely fun than not. Fighting crowds of weak or medium enemies was okay. But when tanky or just strong enemies come out, fights turn into cheap simulator of:
[list]
    [*]trying to punch through enemy's blocks
    [*]trying to hit evading enemy. Specially with guns (remember Kiwami 1 boss fights?)
    [*]waiting until enemy's phase wears off, because if it's on you can't deal damage or deal very little damage
    [*]incosistent damage. That Justice guy either one-shot-kills-you with his laser, either he just deals some damage
    [*]934856 health bars
[/list]

As for other minigames, they're just lazy copypaste from previous games:
[olist]
    [*]Karaoke. Okay, but 1 new song
    [*]Cabaret. You're guest again like in Yakuza 6 but now hostess are recorded live on videos. Probably because it was easy to produce than fiddle with in-engine cutscenes. Overall impression is okay, i guess. But quantity over quality crops out
    [*]Pocket circuit. Nothing changed at all. You spend more time navigating through obsolete menus than actually playing the game. And it is still random number generator[/olist]
Substories are nominal. Most stories are non-brainers like fetching stuff to people as it was in Yakuza 3 or doing some 3-minute substories like "go and beat somebody" or "wander to some random point several times and talk to people or fight and substory ends"

Main story makes almost no sense. Everybody still knows that you're Kazuma Kiryu in Gaiden and even in Yakuza 8. I guess writers just had to pull story in Gaiden towards Yakuza 8. Ending should've bring some tears but i legit laughed out loud when Taichi saw camera and started telling story of his life thinking it's camera for Kiryu (camera shows many graves, not just Kiryu's).
if you love Yakuza or like a dragon it's more of the same and there is nothing wrong with that. fantastic game with a great albeit short story

This game was originally intended as DLC to LAD... and it shows. 
Apart from the absurdity of Kiryu being brought back from his definitive retirement for the 6th time, this game is just filler content. There is a story, but it's a very uninspired one with characters you don't care about, and the rest of the game is just a set of minigames like colloseum, gambling or fetch quests with random items. While mechanically sound, graphically it's nothing to brag about. Dotonbori area is good, but the tiny part of the game when it takes you to Yokohama, it's terrible. You really can tell that the only reasoning behind this game was being a cash grab rather than bringing any value into the franchise.

It's just a glorified ad for the newest LAD you pay full price for and nothing else. It reaches peak absurdity towards the end where some random guy is easily more powerful than all bad guys Kiryu had faced up till that point and when in the last cutscene sequence he reminiscences a character that hasn't been brought up even ONCE for the last 6 installments. 

tl;dr
PROS:
- more beat'em up content with Kiryu I guess?
- you get to see Dotonbori 
- certain red haired character looks good
CONS:
- repetitive and uninspired content aimed to extend the playthrough
- boring story with major plotholes 
- really bad graphics in ceratin areas 
- cringy attempt at making Kiryu an Inspector Gadget

For a shorter game, I was blown away at how much I enjoyed this one. I was expecting a quick adventure just to explain Kiryu's whereabouts betwen 6 and 7 but man I was not prepared for how much they developed and fleshed out Kiryu's character in the mere 5 chapters it has. While the combat isn't as good as something like Lost Judgment, the story, characters, voice acting, and presentation were just amazing. It was great to see how far RGG has come as it constantly reminisces about its older titles, letting you join Kiryu on a trip down memory lane. This one is easily in my top 3 Yakuza games. Of course, it has its flaws, but the way they handled a modern Kiryu post-6 was great. 

And outside of the main story, the shortness of this game actually benefits it imo with a smaller and shorter set of substories and side content quest chains. The coliseum was fun but just short enough to not let its simple gameplay get too repetitive. And pocket circuit was a nice return even if I didn't play it that much. 

This game is a love letter to fans of the Kiryu games so this is a must-play if you're interested in his story. It gives me high hopes for how 8 handles him too. Thank you, RGG.

Loved the game, bought it on sales. Would 100% wait for the sale. In terms of a reboot, it's clever, fun and feels more like a teaser rather than a full fledged Yakuza game. 

I would say that the MSQ is probably 7-8h. The rest is substories, grinding the "Castle" which has a Coliseum, which in itself is not new aspect but like each Yakuza game, there's some level of mini game that makes you stupid rich. It's the prettied Coliseum of most Yakuza game in my opinion. You can use the taxi to get on it, which I felt was breaking my immersion that it's a boat in international waters. The critique I've read so far is that you can play with other character in the Coliseum but their moves/fluidity is far from being fleshed out and is by far a let down.

As for the story, I feel it's pretty good, this feels like a kind of "Multverse" where Kiryu looks not older than 35 yo but this appears to be set in the future when the kids from the orphanage are in their early 20's. The vilains are mid, the overall dept of the Yakuza line of story is not good. Well to be fair, it's still pretty fresh, I like that Kiryu works as Joryu a covert agent which works for some covert government agency also collaborating with the CIA... Kind of sexy spy who get in to leave the life of crime, protect is children while pretending to be dead. (an absolute easy card pulled each time in Yakuza).

So overall the structure of the game is good. The fluidity of the fighting system - the way it's been kind of dumb down is still very fun. The gadgets are super fun and OP AF. The levelling can be pretty much fully done by chapter 4. Which is 2/3 into the game. Doing all the substories unlock some nice stuff including the 2nd point system needed to level up. So they are kind of extremely important. 

Like every Yakuza game, we are in extremely familiar territory. The mini-game are stale and basically feels like a copy-paste of all the universe and feels lazy.  It's a plus and a con. The pocket circuit comes back and it's a blast! The datacom/SEGA console old games are ok but when I play Yakuza I'll admit, I'm not interested in that. The Karaoke is also not scalable (no difficulty level adjustment); I suck at it! Still enjoyable. The Cabaret is ok. It's a film cutscene of JAV actress, which is OK I guess. 

Like in every Yakuza game, you have a side partner which here it's Akame who was a ok new addition but didn't felt like a mark in the Franchise. Meaning, I wouldn't care if she's not in the next game. She share a drink with you, she talks about why she's doing what she does. There's an attempt to build a rapport, but only feels like a tick in a box to achieve a level of narration, rather than an ally that's actually OP (like all past close allies usually are in Yakuza game) that you find either funny, interesting or add tons of fun to the game. 

By the time you're ready to do the final chapter and you've completed S rank all of the coliseum, gotten all the sexy expensive gear, you've filled up in potions and food. You've had some fun challenges in the Coliseum, you're thinking, Let's freaking go!! Last Boss, Last chapter, action pact +100 low level yakuza, with 30 mini boss and 5-6 big boss fight... Right? Nope! It's OK but it's just not good enough, In fact after you're done with it and you're like... Oh... Ok. 

There's No New Game + , much MUCH shorter than other games. The added features are mid and overall the polishing of the scenes and the custscene as still very good.  It's a solid 6, low 7/10 - Still pretty ok

Easily my favorite combat in the beat em up series. The gadgets and agent style for Kyriu are easily the most fun i have had with the new engine so far. A fantastic entry to the series taking the form of a love letter to RGG games past and present. Taking place 4 years after Yakuza 6 and alongside Like a Dragon 7, this offers a story explaining Kiryu's disappearance and eventual role he plays in Like a Dragon 7. The story is enjoyable and does a great job of making me anticipate his crossroads with Kasuga Ichiban. 

Everything hits all time high notes of the series. The models and graphics are fantastic. The detail is extraordinary without feeling uncanny valley. Facial animations, skin and cloth detail, everything. The music fits and enhances scenes and fights as great music should. Some bangers are Deadly Struggle, Psycho's Anthem and Soul of the Ogre.

The fighting is as good as ever. Utilising Kiryu's usual Dragon of Dojima style being the powerhouse and a new Agent style, there's plenty of ways to switching things up and delivering a creative beatdown. Agent style had some fun gimmicks like gadgets and essentially being similar to the Rush style of the past, whenever you use a gadget (save for the Spider) it slows the combat to a halt.

It's weak point is content. Don't get me wrong, it has PLENTY of content. The usual fare like pub games and arcade games, gambling, etc return. Cabaret dates also come back. The absolute GEM of a game that is Pocket Racing makes it's return as well. Sidestories take the form of the Akame Network. But the game is half the usual length. It's on a comparably smaller map taking place in Sotenbori. I could easily clock in 40 hours in the beginning messing around with quests and games but the whole game took that long to finish.

Overall a great package, I think a more fitting price would be 40$ CAD when comparing it to the content we get of other games, but it still offers a lot.

I played Judgment and Yakuza 0 before this game and can definitely say that the combat feels much nicer and crispier. The only annoying thing is the ragdoll stun attacks that just force you to wait a few seconds to recover. The problem is so much worse with pistol enemies who just stun spam you. Also surprisingly there is no quick select of items like there was in Judgments. That just makes it more annoying to heal as you need to go through the menus every time.

In terms of story, it is engaging right from the start and I am glad that you do not need to play all the yakuza games to understand what is going. The only game I would say you need to play before this one is Yakuza Like a Dragon as the story would make a lot more sense if you do. One minor complaint I have about the game is that there are a few times where the story is locked behind progression in the open world. The grind is not too bad and it honestly never affected me as I was already doing the side objectives anyway but I still find this game design annoying.

The fact that this game is shorter than others in the series actually plays in its favour as it picks up much faster and the story is just overall lean. That is especially praiseworthy as these yakuza games tend to be a bit bloaty and consistently run about 8 hours too long. Here the story is to the point.

Overall a great game and a nice change of pace to have a brawler as a bridge between two huge 60+ hour turn based rpgs.

Again a hard to not recommend game in the Yakuza series. But I'm still going to, here's why.

As is the case with most Yakuza games, the world within the game doesn't follow its own rules. This makes following the story silly and frustrating. First your character is plowing through enemies as if they were cardboard. Next you'll watch a 5 minute movie about your character struggling with a piece of said cardboard. This is supposed to create tension and motivation for the story, but since the world already lost most its believability, it's hard to keep invested.

Next we have what's actually happening in the story. Well... not much really?! The main story is very simple and short. There are side missions that you mostly plow through, and as usual they don't have much story to them. They work as an excuse to beat up people but that's it.

The coliseum fights are somewhat fun, but there's only so much of those until you've seen enough. Maybe some more variety would keep things interesting?
 
The fight system also feels somewhat more limited and boring compared to previous titles. Things are mostly smooth but it's just very repetitive even with full abilities. With only two styles and quite clear use cases for them, fights start to quickly repeat the same pattern.

One of my surprising personal favorite features in previous titles was eating at the restaurants. It brought my mind back to Japan (where I've visited a couple of times), and I always got very hungry watching and listening to Kiryu eating. Unfortunately that feature has been basically removed, as you don't gain any experience from eating anymore and the eating animations aren't that delicious anymore.

It's not a bad game at all, but unlike Yakuza 0, I don't think I'll remember or miss what happened in this game after a few years. And hence, I'd only recommend this to people addicted to Kiryu beating up people.

The Man Who Erased His Name is another entry in the long running Like a Dragon / Yakuza series of third person action games. This is a sequel to Yakuza 6, and features a new playable character called Joryu.

When a powerful Yakuza clan believes that Joryu’s true identity is actually the legendary Dragon of Dojima, Kazuma Kiryu (despite the fact that Joryu wears glasses, while Kiryu doesn’t wear glasses, and he’s definitely not the same guy wearing a terrible disguise), Joryu is drawn into a plan which could define the future of the Yakuza.

[h1]Story[/h1]

•	Writing is good, and contains the usual dramatic scenes, twists, and betrayals that the series is known for. This is also a story about how much someone will sacrifice to protect their family.

•	TMWEHN also connects to the later chapters of Ichiban Kasuga’s story in Like a Dragon, which means we already know how this part of the story ends, however we do learn more about Joryu’s role in those events.

•	I really like Joryu, so I hope we see him again as the main character in another game. There are also a few other interesting characters, including government agents and Yakuza members who want to use Joryu for their own agendas, and a young woman called Akame, who runs a network which takes requests to help homeless people.

•	Cutscenes are cinematic and have good graphical quality.

•	I played with the Japanese voice acting, which has good quality, but only the cutscenes are voiced, with in engine conversations during both the main quest and substories, being text only. Yakuza 6 was fully voiced (I can’t remember if this was also the case with Like a Dragon), so this is a backwards step.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

•	Most of the action takes place in two main locations, Sotenbori (previously seen in Yakuza 0, 2 and 5), and an amusement park for the rich, known as the Castle.

•	Fight against gangs of Yakuza and other thugs in real time combat, using a combination of punches, kicks, and various melee weapons, while building up your heat meter to perform powerful finishing moves.

•	Joryu has a new “agent” fighting style which allows him to use various gadgets during combat. The spider can trap enemies in webs, but I didn’t find the others that useful, so I preferred to use the classic Yakuza style.

•	Boss fights are fun, mainly thanks to the responsiveness of Joryu’s dodge move allowing him to quickly evade their attacks, while also setting up opportunities for a powerful counter attack. I was actually able to win most fights through skill, instead of relying on drinking the drug store’s entire stock of toughness z’s to stay alive like in some of the older games.

•	Besides the main quest, there are various activities to keep you busy.

•	Akame Network involves stopping groups of thugs from beating up civilians, and simple fetch quests (mainly to buy food or medicine from shops). This is basic copy and pasted content similar to what Ubisoft fill their open world games with, but they do reward you with cash which can be used to buy ability upgrades.

•	Substories – the best one features a cameo appearance from a familiar character, but unfortunately most of them lack the wacky tone of the previous games, and can also feel a bit repetitive, for example three of the substories ask you to defeat gangs of thugs, but each gang involves the exact same sequence of 6 fights.

•	Fight in the Castle’s coliseum against single opponents or larger groups for huge cash rewards. Many of the substories allow you to recruit allies into Joryu’s clan, which can take part in team fights. However, I don’t like the time limits, especially at platinum level, where you have to fight 15-20 enemies who all have massive health bars. Winning is less about skill, and more about how much money you’ve spent upgrading your damage to KO enemies quickly.

•	When you want to take a break from the action, there’s also the usual wide selection of minigames, including darts, pool, golf, karaoke, sega arcade, pocket circuit racing, poker, blackjack, mahjong and shogi.

[h1]Technical[/h1]

•	It took me just under 30 hours to complete the story and most substories and coliseum fights, which is a decent amount of content, but still shorter than most games in the series.

•	Controls worked great on my xbox 360 controller.

•	I didn’t have any problems with bugs, crashes or framerate.

•	I recommend using DLSS to clear up some distracting edge flickering, which can be particularly noticeable on Joryu’s glasses.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name is a good game which existing fans of the series should enjoy. While the gameplay feels like just another Yakuza game, its definitely worth playing to continue the story. However I would advise waiting for a sale due to this being a shorter game.

As the story directly follows the events of Yakuza 6, this wouldn’t be a good place for new players to join the series. I would advise starting with Yakuza 0, or the Judgment spinoffs which have similar gameplay but a separate story.

Like a Dragon: Gaiden was a very fun game with some few negative points i'd like to address here aswell.

Pros:
- The visuals are amazing. Character Models, Textures etc are high res

- The combat feels fun and every hit feels like it really has big impact on an enemy.

- Skill Upgrades offer meaningful improvements and not just small boosts. After my first two DMG upgrades i could really feel the difference in how fast enemies got knocked out!

- the Story was incredibly good and the ending a good way to lead into the next main game!

Cons:
- The new Agent style felt like it was TOO gimmicky. At the end i've never really used it whatsoever because the Yakuza style just offered everything i wanted.

- having real life scenes for the cabaret was awkward and a bad decision.

- the Request System that works kind off like the one for the Judgment Series ultimately offered too little variation. There were like 4 quests that offered an interesting storyline while the rest was just a pretext to have some random small gangs show up that you needed to beat up enough times while running through all of Sotenbori..

- For all the hype around this feature i just didn't like the Coliseum at all... For example why would i want to cripple myself playing other characters that barely have any good combo? And those rumble fights were just pure chaos. I didn't decide to play through this completely at the end.


Overall i still recommend it for any Like a Dragon fan out there, though, since it explains well what was going on between Y6 and Y7!

This game is so awesome it was a joy from beginning to end if you're a fan of the series this is a must play. Gorgeous graphics, game play is fun as ever with the new agent style. Kiryu/Joryu journey is one of the best in the series.

What I liked about this game is that "Joryu" can easily clear mobs with the agent skill tree fully maximized. Heck, he can even cream bosses on 1v1 (With full heat bar though)! The Yakuza playstyle, on the other hand, is kinda slow. It's powerful, but I'd pick the Agent style more. 

As for achievements, this isn't your normal Yakuza game as it's one of the easiest to complete 100%. You only need to play the game with minimal mini-games. That means, no mahjong, shogi or 100 collectibles to slow you down. It's a great change, but kinda miss doing a lot for that 100% completion ya know? 

Story wise, they really went great lengths just to create a compelling one in order to connect to the events of Y7: LAD. The ending is one of the best I've seen among the series and can seriously compete for top 3.

Long story short, buy this game! A little pricy, but worth it. Looking forward to LAD: IW!

Never have I ever thought this day would come. The day, when I'm gonna post Negative Review for Like a Dragon/Yakuza title.

I'm not a newcomer to the series by any means. Just checked my game time and it's at least 950+ hours in RGG studio games.

A very humble message to Sega before we begin. Fck you, greedy cunts. Why ? 

A) Intentionally locked Pre Orders for several developing/"poor" countries and THEN proceeded to sell the game at release day, thus depriving fans those silly P/O bonuses
B) The most disgusting price tag across the series in terms Price:Content (Quality + Amount; we'll talk about it later) and the absence of adequate regional pricing. Ukraine, LATAM, MENA, India; you can check and compare prices here if curious:
https://steamdb.info/app/2375550/
I've bought Y:0-6 for full price. Every game. 7 and J games with a small discount. Can't anymore, because Sega decided to raise the price 2-3 times.
C) Sega's support didnt bother to answer a single ticket regarding locked Pre Orders, just marked them as "Solved" and closed.

If RGG had a say regarding pricing and pre orders, I, honestly, wish them the same.

If you wanna know a bit about my "taste" in these games, here's my Top 3 without specific order:

- Narrative-wise: Yakuza 0, LaD (7), Judgment
- Gameplay-wise  Yakuza 0, LaD (7), Lost Judgment

Frankly, whole game felt just like an advertising campaign for IW. With a price tag 50$.

What I disliked the most ? 

LaD Gaiden is a big DLC rather than a separate game. A huge fan service sinkhole which appeals to nostalgy of the fans.
Game surely looks and plays like a LaD title. It has the "shell" of the series, but I didn't feel the "soul" inside that shell. I wasn't hooked on the story. Guys, I loved babysitting at Y:3, Haruka's part at Y:5, but again, this game just didnt click with me.
I also have my doubts regarding writing. It didn't feel like Yokoyama wrote this story. Made some edits - maybe. I'm aware they develop multiple games at the same time and Gaiden was meant to be a small game. It seems like this project was given to junior team/employees.

Characters were okay. Voice acting is top notch as always.

They recorded 30-ish compositions for this one, but the other half of the music - the same tracks from previous games. I wanna stop here for a moment. Music has always been a very important part of narrative in LaD games for me. It dictates the mood and sets the atmosphere for the events we participate in. And RGG always wrote a new tracks for each game with small exceptions. These are Yakuza Kiwami re-made tracks from Y:1, alterations of Kiryu's and Majima's theme Receive You and maybe several more less repetitive examples. Never bothered RGG reused assets from time to time but this title is the one big half assed repeat.

Chapter 2 (was it ?), when Kiryu arrived to the Castle was a cringe fest as well as amount of Ryuji Goda (at this point I dont even know what to call it) references. From my point of view, RGG didn't wanna put more original content in this game or I dunno. What I want to say is that for the first time I'm genuinely scared for LaD series future. This title is theirs first "new" project (Ishin is a remake) after Nagoshi left the studio.
I'm freaking out not because it's something huge. On the opposite. It's a sum of many red flags.

One guy said that nowadays big companies mostly ride on the success on some old titles and almost never develop something new. This is my exact thoughts regarding Gaiden. Too many Y:2 stuff.

Last nail in coffin was the last unlockable Coliseum fight - Minamida Grand
Prix. I guess many reckon it was cool, but combining everything said previously - I think not. You will face robots that mimic movesets of all final bosses from Yakuza 6 to 1 in reverse with their music themes. I already had a bad taste in my mouth and now just remember the emotions every previous title and corresponding battle and the character brought me, only to see a metal piece of crap in front of me - a reminder that the devs are slacking off. This one really controversial for me. On the one hand it would've been fun idea if not all previous fan service in one small game, but on the other, yeah, that and text above.
They also tried to ride on success of previous banger tracks like Pledge of Demon (0) and Theory of Beauty (6). Check tracks Hellish Octagon and Psycho's Anthem and tell me you dont hear the "resemblance".

Whats new ?

Well, 1 new Combat Style; 0.5 new mini game (It's called Hell Team rumble and since it's still in Coliseum...see for yourself) + "biggest" but idk if best addition - Akame Network. Shortly, Substories were mostly converted into requests in here plus you have a lot of mini requests and brawls across Sotenbori. Complete them, earn Cash and Akame points to upgrade your skills, buy new gear. Substories mostly bland and boring in Gaiden. Ai app was okay, Judgment crossover too. At least half of them - eliminating three gangs. 
First Summer Uika's play as Akame was good. Fun fact, her surname is Dojima :D
The rest is familiar to the fans. Same mini games, same bullies on the streets, eateries, shops, lockers.
There are very few Dynamic Intros we all love, and maybe one was good.

No NG+, no Legendary difficulty. Fifty Bucks. FmL....

I wanted to talk regarding specific topic, which caused a lot of confusion for me. Idk why I include this to be honest.

[spoiler]One of the most complex moments in LaD games is "Why Kiryu had to fake his own death ?". The answer for this question is behind the stories of LaD 3, 5, 6 and maybe even more. I must admit I've spent a good hour, trying to remember the events that led to this, plus too look at several discussions. These couple days I played Gaiden and fake death plot twist from 6 felt like unnecesarry stretch. But the orphanage, kids, Haruka's statement in 5, her kidnapping in 6 and many other events just show that sooner or later Kiryu's enemies realize they cant defeat him head on and they pressure his family and friends to get to him. And while he's dead, there's no reason for criminal scum to involve those.
But on the other hand, Daidoji's demands regarding this secret are pure evil, forcing Kiryu to accept the cards that will lead to discovery of his secret sooner or later, just to shorten the leash around his neck.
Me and I'm sure a lot of you hate Daidoji and would prefer Yakuza underworld any other day, but it's a Criminal Drama after all. We have, what we have.[/spoiler]

Out of all Yakuza games where you play as Kiryu, Gaiden has the best combat. You can do juggling combos similar to Lost Judgment and you have gadgets to spice things up. The cherry on top is the coliseum, where you can fight solo or with a team. In the coliseum, you can play as different characters, who have their own movesets and special attacks.

Gaiden has Akame network, where you can get your "substories." While it takes away the surprise of walking into a substory, it keeps them all neatly in one place. Characters in substories can become your allies in the coliseum, which is a smooth way of linking different aspects of the game together.

Gaiden is the first Yakuza game where you can customize your outfit, so get S-S-STYLISH!

Like a Dragon Gaiden is a glorious return to the action brawler formula of previous Yakuza games. The combat has been further refined and thus the Dragon Engine quirks don't feel as prevalent anymore.

The story sees you step into the shoes of "Joryu" - a fake identity crafted for Kiryu after his "death" at the end of Yakuza 6. In terms of timeline, the story runs parallel to Yakuza: Like a Dragon. However it's not necessary to have played that game to understand this one.

Compared to earlier titles, Like a Dragon Gaiden is shorter, with less features. However what is there is still amazing. Personally I love the return of Pocket Circut.

Highly recommended.

I don't know what black magic RGG Studio worked on this game to get it to run so perfectly but this is so fantastically optimized even including DLSS all while boasting very nice visuals around Sotenbori. This leaves me very hopeful for 8 especially after 7 didn't run especially well on my PC.

I mostly got this to check out the demo for the next Yakuza game. This one feels like an extended DLC that should've been part of another game rather than sold as it's own thing. I'm a few minutes into the demo for Infinite Wealth and already enjoying it more than I did the last half of Gaiden. I was just getting so frustrated at watching Kiryu/Joryu whiffing all his attacks instead of hitting anyone laying defenseless on the ground and then getting sucker punched by those enemies the second they stand back up. The more I played the game, the more the flaws in the combat system started to reveal themselves. Outside of using some of your Heat Gauge when a button prompt appears next to an enemy on the ground, most of your attacks and moves are going to whiff right over top of them. I really don't understand how it's so hard for Kiryu and all his allies to hit enemies lying on the ground and by the final chapter, I just wanted to finish the game already so I could check out the demo.

The story in this feels short and rushed. It's over in 5 chapters and most of the 5th chapter is an hour or so of consecutive fights and cutscenes. Plus it all takes place in one tiny map with no good means to avoid enemies when simply walking around given they spawn at almost every intersection and there's not enough space on the streets to run around and avoid them. I don't really play these games for their side mini games as much as I checked them out for the story and combat. This is only the third one I've played beside the turn based one and the samurai one. I liked both of those more than this one and the best thing I can say for this one is it made me wanna finish both of them too and check out the demo for the next one.

Don't get me wrong, the combat can be a lot of fun when things are flowing right, but then you or an ally will knock an enemy to the ground and then you just stand there throwing attacks that go right over their heads. The agent gadgets as well. Maybe I should've been leaning on Yakuza mode throughout the game more, but the agent gadgets were honestly a lot of fun throughout the whole game. The only thing that sucked about them is what sucks about the combat as a whole-defenseless enemies on the ground are so hard to hit and knock out.

If you can get this on a sale for like $20-40, I could see myself recommending people check it out cause it does have 20-40 hours of content here, but I imagine you might get frustrated with the combat halfway thru like I did and I had/have the Infinite Wealth demo to look forward to now that I've pushed thru to the end-without that motivation, I probably would've abandoned the game 10 or so hours ago and gone on to play something else.

I know some people say/think you have to know all the lore from previous games to appreciate the story in this one, but I don't think you do. I liked the story as much in this as I have in the other 2 even if I haven't finished either of them yet. Extra context can always be filled in later if I wanna play more of the older games. Dropping the game or at least considering it had nothing to do with the story in this game and everything to do with getting tired of the combat by that point. I think if there were mechanics in the game for your character and his allies to determine an enemy was lying on the ground and adjust their attacks and gadgets accordingly, it would've ended up being a lot more fun throughout and I might have been willing to keep working my way thru the Colosseum fights after beating the game. As it stands, though-even the combat in this feels rushed and not fully fleshed out-like it's meant to be part of a big expansion DLC that instead became it's own "full" game. I went into it pretty excited and am leaving slightly disappointed but with the hope that they could keep refining it and make it better at some point-although I don't know how they would do that.

This is one for the books. Great game and great story-line. If you haven't checked out the other Yakuza games, try them first. Still lots of side activities and quests. Couldn't get to most of it because the story was so good. This will leave you with multiple emotions. Play with a controller is a must.

Story (no spoilers):
Definitely conscious of the character. This game does justice to Kazuma Kiryu's past, ideals, burdens and history.
It does an excellent job at feeling as a perfect focus for him, with its occasional callbacks to past games, with it not being too little, but not too much either as not to feel like complete fan service rather than a well founded game. So yeah, if you want a game, even if short (5 chapters in lenght only) that gives a gives a more proper send off to Kiryu, this is a entry you shouldn't skip by any means. (Why would you want to skip it, anyways?) 
Kiryu has much more attitude than in many previous games, too. 
The ending made me drop tears of both sadness and joy.

Gameplay: 
The gameplay is, to put it simple, fun. 
Agent, the new fighting style, is presented as a more tactical one, being able to overwhelm hordes of enemies. However, as you progress through the game, it becomes less than that to become more of a quick, easy way around finishing fights. And no, it's not because the character being bound to get stronger as the game progresses, but rather than it not being as tactical as presented, but more of a silly mix up of gadgets that justify the name of the fighting style, some of which are of quick and of more slow use, but all of them being able to finish the battle in a minute, or 8 seconds in most cases. It doesn't mean it's not fun, because it's the complete opposite, but it's definitely not a before and an after when it comes to battles styles in the series either. 
Kiryu's signature Yakuza fighting style (now being the fighting style that you unlock as you progress a little further into the story) has some minimal changes that might not be for the convenience of the player too, like it being powerful at the price of being slow, and the beloved ¨finishing hold¨ move being stuck behind Heat Mode. Even so, this is the most fun it has been playing with Kiryu in the Dragon Engine so far, to say the least.

Duration and side stuff: 
The main story is around 12 hours, but that was no relevant for me because of how the side content of the game does a wonderful job at stretching the game to around 30 hours. 
Side missions. Customizable clothes. Minigames. Immersive hostesses. Pocket Circuit Races. Colisseum fights and the entirety of the Castle. Even being able to play as any of the characters you recruit to join your side at the colisseum.
All of that felt like a fitting part of the main story as I went through it. 
What I'm trying to say, if you want the game to be longer and more enjoyable than what only 5 chapters sound like for a Like a Dragon/Yakuza game, all you need to go is to go out of your way and have fun. I cleared all of the colisseum fights with a S Grade and reached rank 30 in the Akame missions, and it was like having a buffet served in front of me that left me with a smile and conversations topics for the future.

DLC: Owning the Legendary Fighter Pack DLC is fun, but definitely not a must to overcome the colisseum. In case you think it will be defining to your enjoyement of the game if you don't own it because of how the characters there are some of the glorified cameos of the series. (Looking at Majima still spinning as the fight ends is fun, though).

Conclusion: Akame is very cute. Having the game's duration in mind might help you savor and enjoy the game and its events more. Buy the game on sale.

Like A Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name, or Yakuza 7.5 is a pretty good game; though, it sticks true to its name of being half of a game. The game has a total of 5 chapters compared to a regualar yakuza games 12 chapters.

[h1] The Combat [/h1]

Yakuza Gaiden's combat is more akin to Judgement's combat rather than Lost Judgement. Like Judgement, Kiryu has 2 styles now, being Agent Style (More Defensive, and Gimmick related), and DOD/Yakzua Style, also sadly Kiryu does not have the power of Tekken to Juggle. Extreme heat is also back, and it increases the amount of Agent Style's Gadgets Kiryu can use; while for DOD/Yakuza Style, it enhances the physical capabilities of it (More damage, and a new light attack combo after the 6th? light attack where Kiryu uses that one heat action but it isn't now). 

[h3] Agent Style [/h3]

Agent Style has 4 gadgets being a long-range web slinger (Spider), a drone (Hornet), a explosive cigar (Firefly), and a pair of thrusters for the shoes (Serpent). Spider, Hornet, and Firefly's upgrades just increases the number Kiryu can use it, while Serpent's upgrades just increase the duration of the boots. The gadgets are mostly just crowd control gizmos, with Hornet being a distraction for bosses, or enemies. Agent Style's normal attacks are rather lackluster, but Kiryu can dish out more than 7 light attacks. Personally Agent Style is more used for defensive or crowd control situations, but its still a decent style.

[h3] DOD/Yakuza Style [/h3]

The Dragon of Dojima style (Yakuza 6 version) is back, and its rather good. There is really nothing to say about this style other than the addition of having an ability to have Triple Finishers (One of the finishers is the Famous Kick), and that the style is rather pretty great.

[h1] The Prologue/Story (Spoiler-Free) [/h1]

The game's story right off of Yakuza 6, and also runs parallels with Yakuza 7. At the start, Kiryu makes a deal with the Daidoji. Under this deal Kiryu is "Dead", and works with the Daidoji. A new life outside the Yakuza underworld, and a new life under the Daidoji. Daidoji is an organization of elite skilled agents who do contracts from certain other organizations (like the CIA). I would classify the Daidoji faction as a shadow organization since no one really knows it, and the HQ is a temple. Kiryu lives under the new name of Joryu, and is trained in martial arts (Agent Style), and was given gadgets by other Daidoji affiliates. One of Joryu's major tasks refers him to a dockyard where Joryu waits for a truck of gold; however, this turns out to be a trap. Soon Joryu goes to Yokohama (Literally only appears in one chapter), where Joryu investigates the Omi which is also a trap and Joryu's handler, Hanwwa (I don't know how to spell his name; however, its something like that), is kidnapped by two Omi Members Tsueno, and Shishido. The Daidoji does not care about a single member of their team getting kidnapped; however, Joryu cares about him, and the Daidoji does not allow him to leave. Soon Joryu discovers the truth of the kidnapping, and the plot of the Watase Family.

[h3] Story Spoilers [/h3]

To be written... probably trust me.

[h1] The Maps [/h1]

[h3] Yokohama [/h3]

Most of Yokohama is locked out, and its literally only available for the first chapter, and premium adventure. It has nothing to note apart from a reference to Yakuza 7 when Namba found Ichiban.

[h3] Sotenbori [/h3]

Sotenbori is the main map of LAD:Gaiden, and it added back the park that was removed from Sotenbori in Yakuza Kiwami 2. The map is still the same Sotenbori, apart from the removal of certain businesses, and the addition of others.Pocket Circuit Race returns within Sotenbori; however, Kiryu's favorite buddy, Pocket Circuit Fighter, is sadly not present.

[h3] The "Castle" [/h3]

The Castle is the "second" map you have access to throughout the game (Yokohama is only available for one chapter and then you're locked out lol). There are two main attractions within the Castle, and those are the gambling hall/Casino, and the coliseum. Not much people gamble within the Yakuza fan base, and instead they just play mahj-, so the coliseum is just the main attraction. 

[h1] Misc. [/h1]

Anything else notable? Yes.

[list]
[*] [b] Dynamic Intros [/b], There are like 3 Dynamic Intros in the game. 4 if you count the Darts minigame where you challenge your handler since that has a unique intro.
[*] [b] Return of Billiards/Pool [/b], I have no comment on this, its fine.
[*] [b] No Kamurocho [/b], Makes sense, Kiryu does not want to return to the dreaded city to have another shirtless fight at the top of the millennium tower.
[*] [b] Amon [/b], New Amon fights Joryu. His moveset is just Classic DOD, and agent gadgets with Yakuza 7's Amon Theme. Nothing really interesting compared to other Amons.
[*] [b] Karaoke [/b], Baka Mitai is back, and the picture is Pocket Circuit Fighter again! Kiryu mourns more about PCF than Nishiki, or Yumi.
[*] [b] No New Game + [/b], WHY RGG.
[*] [b] 100% [/b], probably the only yakuza game that people can 100% easily.
[/list]

Relatively short for a Yakuza game (hence the Gaiden in the title); probably 1/3 the length of Yakuza 8 (also known as Yakuza: Like a Dragon). However, it's almost all killer, no filler. The ending sequence had me in tears. 10/10

I liked the return to the traditional Yakuza combat; I didn't mind 8's turn-based combat as much as some die-hard fans but it was definitely a slog at times. It definitely fits the more standard Yakuza theme of "Kiryu keeps punching things until the world is as it should be" that this game has.

My only complaint is that there is a specific fight that overlaps in this and 8 ([spoiler]The fight between Kiryu and Ichiban[/spoiler]) that I would have love to have played from Kiryu's perspective, but that was just shown in flashback form at the end. I was really looking forward to it, and was bummed it wasn't there. Not a huge deal though, as the rest of the game is fantastic.

One thing that I liked / disliked was the Akame requests system. I do like that it was really easy to find and complete all the substories without wandering around looking for the triggers or relying on a guide, but it also felt less "Yakuza-y", in that there wasn't an equivalent of, for example, randomly getting roped into a Michael Jackson music video. It certainly streamlined things though.

All in all, it's a great game, and whets the appetite for Infinite Wealth without burning you out on the formula.

Like a Dragon Gaiden feels to me like the perfect distillation of the best parts of modern Yakuza games, compressed down into a package that's much more compact than other recent entries while still providing the same mix of compelling story, incredible combat, and wildly varied mini-games and side content. As a companion to Yakuza 7, it provides a wonderful feeling of familiarity, and as a standalone entry in the franchise, it stands tall among the better entries in the series.

By nature, Gaiden is a much shorter game than 7 or either of the Judgment games - it's designed as a side-story, returning to Kiryu to fill in the gaps in his narrative between his exit in Yakuza 6 and his small side-role in Yakuza 7. Despite clearly being a shorter narrative, though, I found that it felt plenty meaty, moreso than several of the pre-5 entries in the series. I think a big part of this is that its story is split across just five chapters, making each of those chapters quite long compared to how these games are usually structured. The end result is that the narrative has very little downtime, with only a few periods where the story gives you the time to poke around and do whatever you want for a little while. The story is typically split between serious, heavily-written drama and absurdity, centering Kiryu's struggle to continue on in a life that, in his perception, no longer has meaning, and this narrative thread carries him through to where he seems to end up in Infinite Wealth. It's well-written and feels like it does Kiryu much more justice than 6 did, while setting him up for a potentially perfect true departure from the franchise with the next game.

The combat is not quite peak Dragon Engine combat - Yakuza Style still feels weird and retread-y even with the tweaks to combat borrowed from the Judgment games, but Agent Style is an absolute revelation and completely justifies the weird narrative framework of the Daidoji faction. Seeing Kiryu shoot out Spider-Man webs and whip people around relentlessly, zip around on rocket boots, summon literally fifty drones to irritate every enemy in sight, and blow people up with explosive cigarettes is both hysterical and deeply satisfying. The group/1v1 split in the styles is still clear, with Agent ideal for clearing out large groups of enemies and Yakuza best suited to one-on-one showdowns, but it often felt like a necessity to switch to Yakuza rather than a choice I was glad to make. On the whole, though, it's still modern Yakuza combat, and it still just feels great.

On the whole, Gaiden is another worthy entry in the Yakuza franchise, far more essential than its side-story nature suggests. As a brawler-style palate cleanser between the turn-based 7 and 8, it's extremely fun, and it provides a great mix of connective tissue between the games and standalone entertainment and intrigue. Pick it up.

Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name is a spin off game which details the story of Kiryu Kazuma more or less during the events of Yakuza 7: Like a Dragon. 

First and foremost, I remember I was pretty annoyed when this game was announced as I remember (perhaps incorrectly) reading somewhere that the writers were done with Kiryu's story and that Kasuga Ichiban would be the new protagonist going forward and that turn based combat would be how the games would proceed. As someone who fell completely in love with Y7 I remember getting frustrated at the idea of going back to beat 'em up. But quite frankly I was just wrong in my entirety. 

LAD:G plays like all the Yakuza games before Y7, it is a beat em up but the story itself is significantly shorter than what we're used to from a Yakuza game, if you're like me and like to do a lot of side content (not to 100% completion, just messing about a bit) and doing the main story, you're probably talking about 25-30 hours for a standard playthrough, still a lot, but less than what we're used to. Much like every Yakuza game, the story is compelling and it's very easy to get invested in.

Gameplay is similar to Yakuza Kiwami 2, feels great, punches and kicks are heavy, overall very satisfying. Although I'd say one of the best improvements is the seamless blend of running around then transitioning into combat. No more little "Crack knuckles" mini cinematic, no more money counting up at the end, it's literally just run around > Guy wants to fight > You fight him > Money added. There is no downtown between any of the random encounters in the game, which is a huge improvement as I'm sure a lot of us have been frustrated at times having to do random encounters in previous games one after another; this feature really saves a lot of time.

Has everything that hallmarks at Yakuza game, daft little mini games, a bunch of substories, bigger sidewquests that hold their own weight alongside the main story, it's all here.

Overall I can definitely say that my initial opinion on this game being released was wrong and I should have had more faith in the Development Studio and the Writers, I guess I just wanted more Ichiban that I forgot about just how good it was to be Kiryu again. If you're looking for a short quick beat 'em up, or something just to tide over that Yakuza desire until Infinite Wealth comes out, this is the game to play. 8/10.

A painful sort of parting. 

Let me state up front that, despite what Sega's marketing claims, this is the absolute worst place to start the Yakuza franchise. Not because of its quality, but because this feels like the closing epilogue to a saga that spans close to two decades in releases. 

I've played Yakuza for going on twelve years at this point, ever since importing the Japanese release of Yakuza 5, then emulating the originals, and slowly working forward from there. It's given me great joy to see the new waves of popularity RGG have rightfully gotten in the wake of Yakuza 0's debut in the West, and it gives me even greater joy to see that rather than sit on their laurels, they've consistently pushed themselves to make each new release as great as it can be. 

Gaiden is a side game, and that nature is plenty evident in everything from its skeleton to its skin. It simply lacks the wide variety of content that the mainline franchise is well known for. It tries, and my hour count- I hope- serves as sufficient evidence to show you'll get plenty of bang for your buck, but I would strongly encourage you to temper your expectations somewhat before diving in, and I think you'll be pleasantly surprised as a result. 

I don't want to speak overlong on the story, because I consider it Gaiden's greatest strength. If you've been following Kiryu through the course of his life, from 0 to 6, then this absolutely *is not* something you want to sit out. Speaking personally, it's the sweetest kind of pain seeing what he goes through in Gaiden. It's the sappy, Valjean-esque sort of drama you've come to expect from Yakuza, but it hits home all the more simply because it's Kiryu. To see an immovable force of nature show the scars and strain behind his stoicism wasn't only deeply moving, it was heart-wrenching. 

Because of Gaiden, because of the momentum RGG have been picking up with Yakuza 7 and Lost Judgment, I am wholeheartedly certain that Yakuza 8 will be their crowning masterpiece, and a game that'll leave me utterly broken with tears. 

I cannot wait.

It's a Yakuza/Like a Dragon game. Of course it's good. 

Kiryu is back with another engaging story that you never want to put down... Taking place during the same time as Yakuza: Like a Dragon, it is highly recommended that you play that game first. You will be able to pick this up and play without too much missing if you haven't played the previous title, but things make even more sense if you have the hindsight of the last game. It is also very exciting to be able to draw similarities in the key story points. "Oh, I remember that happening in LAD7!" is something you will think a lot.

The game looks incredible and feels seamless to play. Running into enemies keeps you in the world and you're right back into it after fighting, no loading screen, no waiting. This was my only gripe with Like a Dragon 7, and it was solved. It's as funny and off-the-wall as Yakuza games are, with the focus on combat quality that the Like a Dragon section brings to the table. 

It is worth mentioning, though, the game is probably only ~15 hours. While that's a lot for a game nowadays, it's unusually short for an RGG game. I imagine this is the case as it is a "catch-up" storyline, so we learn what Kiryu has been up to just before Infinite Wealth. With the two games releasing so closely together, along with the rerelease of Ishin in an entirely new engine, it's no surprise the game is short. I just hope Infinite Wealth will be a longer game. 

There are still a ton of quests and minigame challenges I haven't completed, though. 

There's no BS DLC or season passes that other companies try to shill out. RGG is a perfect example of what a video game company should be.

Now, let's talk combat. Kiryu's new agent style proved to be a rule-setter and a ton of fun to experiment with especially the Serpent wire. They also brought back the classic Tiger Drop Yakuza style, too and its as great as it was in the other games. Although the combat was indeed good, I still think Lost Judgment had the better combat overall, But hey, considering this game was cooked up in just six months, the combat's pretty damn good.

And the story? Short and sweet, but man, it's great, especially the ending. Prepare for emotion and tears, especially if you've been tagging along with Kiryu on his journey. Seeing his vulnerable side hits you in the feels. The guy might be a dragon, but he's still human.

All in all, this game was a blast and got me pumped for whatever's coming with Infinite Wealth! Loved it so much I even got the platinum. Dive in, but fair warning—grab some tissues for the end!

[h1]Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name[/h1] 


Like a Dragon Gaiden is unlike previous LAD games more of a side story like experience, but even then it's still a LAD game. With beautiful visuals, it still has the classic vibe and side stories/minigames but with a much more compact story. And man, what a story it was! Also my personal goty.


[b](My thoughts on the story)[/b] 
I'm going to keep this very short considering that the story isn't all that long either
so I'd rather want you people to experience it yourself. 
But man to me this was the game everyone (me included) needed
that weren't agreeing with the way Y6 ended and used some of its characters.
Overall the story is great man, lots of intense and crazy moments happening, with some fun stuff as well. 
But I am gonna tell you this, this game broke my soul man :')
This game also overtook 6 as my favorite Kiryu game. Yeah, it's that good!


[b](Gameplay)[/b] 
Gameplay is crazy, the fact that Kiryu has more than 1 style again and for the fact that we can JUGGLE as well in this game. You start with the new style Agent, it's the style that you acquire from the Daidoji, it is basically a mix of Yagami's Crane style with a more Agent like vibe I guess??
Either way it's more fast-paced compared to the second style as that is more for a brawler and street fight type way, the move style for agent is more of a martial arts tactical fighting style.
Both styles also have a color, for Agent being the color blue and for the other red. Agent style is also a great way to start juggles when going in heat mode. Overall, you're gonna get a lot of Judgment/Lost Judgment vibes when playing the game. But Agent style is not only fighting no, no, you have like 4 gadgets you can use, a spider-man like web/string that comes out of your watch to pull enemies to you or push them away, a cigaret that's basically a bomb. Freaking rocket boots, and drones that can chase enemies.
Agent style is crazy hahaha there is so much from it. And of course for the second style we have 
The Yakuza Style as the game names it (normally being dragon style but oh well). It is vastly improved from the versions of Y6 and Y:K2, being overall much smoother and fleshed out with some changes, new move sets and finishers, he can basically do his iconic kick pose as a finisher. But dude do you kick the shit out of enemies when upgrading it oh man enemies went flying hahahahah.
I do gotta say this in all honesty, this is I think is the only game where I haven't relied on heat moves as much compared to the other games, I was really mostly just fighting with juggles and charged attacks
so that did kinda surprise me a little. Overall the combat in this game great, although a combat speed could have been nicely added, It's good but not LJ level good as that one still takes the cake for best RGG combat let's say it's better than K2 and 6 and on par with JE combat considering that one also has 2 styles. 
However, one huge new thing has got to be the feature that you can actually personalize Kiryu. That's right full on character customization, I freaking love this feature in this game
and I really hope it doesn't just stay in Gaiden, but actually carries on to other games as well. 


[b](Substories and Minigames)[/b]
LAD Gaiden still has the side stuff like Substories and Minigames, as they will always be a core piece of these games. this time you have something called the Akame points, in order to get those Akame points you'll have to do Akame missions/substories, as in this game substories are actually a checklist that you do in order to gain more bonding with Akame, it's kind of unfortunate that it's not randomly like the previous games
but as for Kiryu being an Agent like person, it kinda makes sense that he is doing it this way, and either way the substories are still fun to do, especially for some! But you'll have to see it for your self.
Mini-games, oh man POCKET CIRCUIT IS ACTUALLY BACK, I love this minigame man, one of my favorite things to do in Y0 and K1, and I'm really glad they brought it back one more final time, aside from that another mini-game that returns to the Dragon Engine is Pool, yes that was missed as well for some odd reason and that is also still fun to play, one other new thing is that some point you'll unlock a hideout that has an actual Sega master system which is pretty nuts, has around 12 games in it, tho some you got to buy at like ebisu pawn something close like that.
Also, later in the game you'll unlock a new play environment called The Castle, there it has the casino/Japanese gamble games, a cabaret with LIVE ACTION performances yeah it's super weird honestly, and holy shit does it take so much space around 28 GB????? (0_0?). 
Outside of that you also got the place where you personalize Kiryu, The Boutique which has all kinds of clothing options.


[b](Enemies, Colosseum and Bosses)[/b]
Enemies are your typical street guys or yakuza like the previous games and not the unique types like in LAD7. However, they are very advanced like the enemies in the Judgment games, so when you have a low upgraded Kiryu, be tactical as to how you fight them because lots of them fight back hard. 
A returning feature to the game is The Colosseum, which also is featured in The Castle, but man is this the best version of the Colosseum we all know.... EVERY FIGHTER IS PLAYABLE, and no I'm serious every fighter in it is playable, if you preordered the game you get playable [i]Majima, Saejima and Daigo[/i] (or if you buy it separately as DLC). But holy shit actual playable Daigo is nuts, lots of the fighter have their own move sets alto some also have move sets from previous bosses and enemies, pay close attention, and you'll see it. The rest you'll have to see for yourself, as it's too much to say about it. 
Now, then, the other thing this game does great are the bosses. Every, and I mean every, boss in this game is just great. You do have some mini bosses, but they are also good. But the main bosses? Holy shit, very fun to fight to and to some degree quite challenging, also there is a returning feature that the enemies will use Mortal Reversals, as they were first introduced in LJ, Gaiden also has them for some of its enemies and all the bosses. Now I will stand on this with all my heart, this game has the best final boss fight in all LAD, yep there I said it! Overall just the final boss fight was peak LAD moment it has 3 action phases with the last one having a different OST.... Holy shit, I loved this boss fight.


[b](Soundtrack)[/b] 
The soundtrack is quite a take cause holy damn this shit good! What's surprising is that most of the composing was done by a lot of new people and by some returning composers
that did the OG Y1 and 2. The boss fights, fantastic osts, the battle themes for both styles are really great, long battle themes also great, personally the main theme Fading Away hits in every spot for me that's some tearjerker stuff right there if you just even read the lyrics. The third phase of the final boss really nails it for me man, I've been constantly listening to the soundtrack a lot! 
It really is still something that RGG studios does for every LAD game of theirs.
Having an absolute banger of a soundtrack!


That concludes my review for Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name.
Even though it's shorter, this game was very much quality over quantity to me from the gameplay, the great story and characters, and even the side stuff.
I really hope we get more Gaiden games, maybe for other characters like Majima or Akiyama
there are tons of options! I also hope this is really not the last Kiryu Action game...
Cause if so, I'm really gonna miss it :'(

Yakuza is funny, because it proves that a good story, a lovable cast, a refined world with fun substories and the omnipresent feat of being able to convince you that the fate of Japan rests upon a fight between two shirtless men is enough to make this one of my favorite games this year.
LaD Gaiden is the second swan song for Kiryu, and a beautiful one at that. Since it is solely focused on him, the game has the breathing room to reminisce on the earlier games, his past adventures, and ponder on the mistakes he's made along the way; through both the you get to glimpse into the human behind the brute facade, and laugh (often out loud!) with him at certain moments and callbacks to previous shenanigans that have now turned into franchise-defining memories.
Kiryu absolutely pulls this story through, and both voice actors manage to deliver an emotional impact at the end that demolishes any other RGG game in emotionally destroying me. Having spent over 230 collective hours across seven entries with this character, I couldn't think of a finer ending.
RGG is also clearly succeeding in stepping up their storytelling and game design with each iteration: the combat is fast, flashy and the most fun it has ever been, making me hold it in the same esteem as Lost Judgment and managing to get me to play through the coliseum, which I usually steer clear of; the boss battles are cinematic, fun and super long, and took me back all the way to Yakuza 0 and 2, which still have some of my favorite ones; Sotenbori is fresh and dense, accompanied by Akame, which turned out to be a fun and happy-go-lucky companion, and who offered great contrast to Kiryu. The only thing I would change is the skill upgrade system being tied to Akame Requests, which did not hinder the game for me, someone who is not invested in her or the substories Gaiden has to offer might feel put off and not enjoy the combat as much as a result.
I am insanely hyped for Infinite Wealth, and overjoyed I got into Yakuza throughout the past year at the behest of a close friend after showing interest in the wacky minigames and fun side content - little did I know what I was signing up for.

Like a Dragon Gaiden: Them Man Who Erased His Name is an amazing side story that takes place during the events of Yakuza 7/LAD. It rewards players who were invested with Kiryu's story with callbacks from previous entries and paves a way for Infinite Wealth. If you have only played Yakuza 7/LAD and want to know who this Kiryu fella is then this is an okay starting point but it is highly recommended that you start off with Yakuza 0 or Yakuza Kiwami (Yakuza 1 remake)

Combat feels better than Yakuza Kiwami 2 and is akin to that of the Judgement sub-series offering two Combat styles, those being Agent Style and Yakuza Style. Agent Style is a new style utilising gadgets to take out multiple enemies and helps with crowd control while the Yakuza Style is akin to that of previous entries and is better for 1v1 battles.
Upgrades are a mixture of Yakuza 0 and Yakuza 6 where you need Money and Akame Points to unlock new skills which is fine, the Coliseum is a great way to grind money while exploring the world of Sotenbori and The Castle nets you Akame points.

There are only 2 locales being Sotenbori and The Castle which is again fine, as both have great set-pieces and help the world feel more alive

The DLC gives you the Legendary fighter pack in which you are able to play as 3 legendary Yakuza in the Colosseum Only and also fight against them in Special Matches. Those being Goro Majima – The Mad Dog of Shimano, Taiga Saejima – The Slayer of Eighteen and Daigo Dojima – 6th Chairman of the Tojo Clan

My only gripes with this game is that there is no NG+, No Dragon of Dojima Outfit for Kiryu to wear + can't take off glasses and Staff Roll/Credits not being in the Replay Cut-scenes

I'd get the game if you want to see Kiryu's side of Yakuza 7/LAD and want to play the Demo for Like a Dragon 8: Infinite Wealth or wait for a sale to get the digital deluxe.

I've played every Yakuza game and they all kept me wanting to play more, but this is the only game where I got bored of playing. I guess the story just doesn't catch my interest like the other games did.

It's definitely a mainline Yakuza game still, but it's about 1/3 to 1/2 the length of previous main titles.

Still, if you enjoyed Yakuzas 1 - 6, no reason you won't enjoy this one. Fun battle system that isn't too complex, minigames galore, and a relatively simple skill advancement system with only two styles to keep track of.

For a Yakuza game that only has 5 Chapters this sure is a long ass game, and I don't mean that in a bad way.

I will, however, NOT recommend this game as a starting point to the Yakuza games (as much as that one article said about it being so), I will only recommend this game after playing the entire series, from 0 until 7 to enjoy the story fully. 
REMEMBER THAT WHEN YOU ARE PURCHASING ANY YAKUZA TITLE, ITS STORY FIRST THEN BEAT EM UP AND THE SHIT AND GIGGLES SECOND.
The graphics are fantastic even on Medium graphics (the graphics I played it on), there are loads of things that are brought and improved from the Dragon Engine they used for Lost Judgement, the combat feels amazing, loads of side content for you to enjoy (and not enjoy if you are planning to 100% this game), and much improvements from the previous series. There are some minor inconveniences like how everything costs money like in Yakuza 0 and the classic RGG Studios of reusing assets but they have never bothered me THAT much that I didn't want to play the game.
This game has literally made me, a grown ass man, cry in tears and its fucking worth it. So if you've played the entire series until 7, this is VERY much a worth it purchase.

I'd give this entry a 9/10, if it weren't for the grinding I had to do to upgrade some of skills and the Pocket Circuit Racing being RNG based, I would've rated it way higher. But the story was worth it just to get here.

This game is an asset flip that exists solely to justify why Kiryu returned after 6 wrote him out. It's only 5 chapters long and all of the characters are rushed and uninteresting, all of the minigames are reused (Pocket Circuit, Arcade Games from LJ, etc.), and the soundtrack is oddly middling outside of a few tracks. 

Graphically it's better than 7 but continues the long running track of Dragon Engine games always looking worse than the last, with this games being noticeably uglier than Lost Judgment while also having way less effort put into the presentation, with very few prerendered cutscenes as well as a general lack of polish all around. 

The story is just not that good. Most of the new characters don't land that well save maybe Hanawa, Nishitani III is just a weird retcon of Nishitani being a lineage as apposed to a single guy which falls flat, Shishido would have been cool if he was in a full game and wasn't telegraphed as the big bad from moment 1 because of how short the game is, and every returning character is just their Yakuza 7 scenes save for Watase who apparently got stabbed before the speech (this literally does not matter at all idk why they did that).

New Karaoke song is good, and the scene at the end with the kids got me to tear up a bit, but that's only really because of the context from Yakuza 6 (also you never see Haruka wtf).

All in all this game simply did not need to exist and it sucks that this is Kiryu's last game now. Yakuza 6 wasn't a perfect game but it was a much better ending for him than this. Not worth $50, wouldn't buy it for any more than $20.

After Yakuza 6, I was very skeptical of the idea of Kiryu returning in any role as a protagonist or major character in future games. However, the game does a wonderful job connecting Yakuza 6 and Yakuza: Like a Dragon together, while also setting up Infinite Wealth in a way that makes me extremely excited to see what happens next. 

For a shorter title compared to RGG's other works, the game is still full of content that can very well take over 30 hours to complete. Side content like the Coliseum are obvious stand-outs, and there's a decent selection of substories to go through as well. Combat still feels fun to mess around with, and the soundtrack features a very different feel that other entries haven't had (in a good way). For me though, the story, while relatively short, was the obvious star of the game, featuring a great cast of characters and a deeply emotional ending that broke me more than any other Yakuza game. 

In all, Gaiden is another excellent entry in the franchise, and one that makes me very excited to see what's in store next for Yakuza fans. While I wouldn't recommend this title for newcomers, the payoff after playing all previous mainline titles is fantastic, and very much worth waiting for.

This game does not at all let you know it was made in the span of 6 months in parallel with 2 other games from the studio. 
   As a Like A Dragon entry, it's well paced and punches way above its weight with a very cohesive narrative that still has its classic mood swing charms, yet it avoids the messy plot webs of the PS3 era games that might make it too nauseating for less committed fans. Kiryu's characterization is even stronger than it was in the previous games, but it still finds time to explore and discuss the formerly-titular organisations that this franchise is actually about. 
   As a standalone game, it is one of the shiny gems of 2023 with a characteristically strong desire to make an enjoyable product and tell a compelling story. The downside i can see in playing this game as a person unfamiliar with the series, however, is that structurally, Gaiden is heavily reliant on callbacks and references to at least 4 previous titles, from characters that are mentioned to events that are retold, which can leave a new player with gaps in the understanding of the overall story. 
   The $50 price tag, though, might just be a bit too steep for a game with about half the playtime of a mainline title, especially considering that most of the secondary content is reused from previous titles. 
   Overall, this is one of the best entries of the franchise, and its a fairly high bar.
