[h1]I've... given up my past, my life, and even my name[/h1]

As I am awaiting the release of [b]Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth[/b], to my surprise [b]Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio[/b] released [b]Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name[/b]. This takes place after the events of [b]Yakuza 6[/b] and during the events of the 7th game. This title uses the action beat-em-up gameplay that the previous games have done, rather than the turn-based RPG mechanics that were used in [b]Y7[/b].

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Fantastic story with many twists
[*]Very fun gameplay with a lot of abilities
[*]Fun upgrades and interesting gadgets
[*]Tons of side content to do
[*]Excellent soundtrack
[*]Beautiful graphics that look amazing
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The story is a bit on the shorter side
[*]Agent style is a little underwhelming
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
[b]Kazuma Kiryu[/b] is now putting his [b]Yakuza[/b] life behind him, assuming the name of [b]Joryu[/b] and effectively becoming a dead man to everyone he loves and the world. However, one night during a mission he was assigned to someone seems to know what actually happened to him and wants to bring him out of hiding. [b]Joryu[/b] must find out what is actually going on and take down whoever is trying to expose him but it also seems a lot more is going on than it seems.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3111729471 
The only issue I had with the story in this game, is that it’s really short. I completed it in like 6-7 hours at best. The story for this game is honestly fantastic, it fills in some gaps that [b]Y7[/b] had and the characters are overall amazing. It will also showcase some events from [b]Y7[/b] as well as some of the characters making a cameo appearance. 

To top it all off, the ending to this game actually made me shed some tears which is one of the first and only games to do so.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay is very fun, and I enjoyed playing through the beat-em-based combat as always. This is also the first game where I played on professional difficulty, which was manageable for me. You have access to two fighting styles, [b]Agent[/b] and [b]Yakuza[/b], each having its own set of skills and abilities for [b]Joryu[/b] to utilize. [b]Agent[/b] style allows him to use the [b]Daidoji Factions’s[/b] specialized martial arts. It’s a fighting style that is very fast-paced, with fast punches and kicks. [b]Joryu[/b] can also use special gadgets in combat, including a grappling hook called the [b]Spider[/b], AI drones to home in on enemies called [b]Hornets[/b], Jet engines on his shoes called [b]Serpents[/b], and [b]Firefly[/b] - a bomb disguised as a cigarette.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3111727742
Then there is the [b]Yakuza[/b] fighting style, which is more mixed with the [b]Brawler[/b] and [b]Dragon[/b] style used in the previous games. It now has triple finishers and a new red aura so your enemies can know you are a threat. All of his heat actions are back, from all the way back to the first [b]Yakuza[/b] game, with two new ones added to spice things up. Overall, the [b]Yakuza[/b] style is a slower fighting style and the one I used the most during combat, as it was my preferred choice.

There are also times in the game when enemies do a special attack that will do massive damage. [b]Joryu[/b] can counter these moves with a counterattack and deal some damage to the enemy while doing so. The [b]Heat Action Meter[/b] has also changed - if you take damage the [b]Heat Action Meter[/b] will no longer deplete, the only attacks that can make it deplete are ones that use electricity.

While in [b]Extreme Heat Mode[/b] any damage done to [b]Joryu[/b] will be done to the meter instead and will keep doing this until it’s depleted or shut off. There is also gear you can equip that will help you out in combat by providing state buffs.

To get upgrades in the game, you can do side content to get money and [b]Akame Points[/b]. The latter are given to you after you are done with a side quest. You can get stuff like new moves, health, attack damage, etc. There is a ton of side content to do and I did a bunch of it throughout my playthrough to make sure I got enough [b]Akame Points[/b] to get some upgrades. I never had an issue with getting enough [b]Akame Points[/b], though I did have an issue getting money as that is also used to get upgrades. However, there are ways to get money - it’s just that I ran out most of the time getting upgrades and buying healing items.

As mentioned before, The [b]Akame Network[/b] has a few side quests for you to complete that will earn you money and [b]Akame Points[/b]. There are also [b]Stroll and Patrol[/b] missions for you to complete that will give you the same rewards. This can raise your [b]Akame Rank[/b] and the higher it is, your rank will go up in the [b]Castle[/b], which is a secret area you can visit that has a colosseum for you to fight other people.

However, I do have one issue with the gameplay and that is with the [b]Agent[/b] style; it’s underwhelming. The issue comes with the fact that the [b]Yakuza[/b] style is better for taking out enemies as a whole. While the [b]Spider Gadget[/b] is useful for crowd control and there are upgrades to grab more enemies with it, that also has an issue. To use any of the gadgets you have to hold down the button. So, for example, if I want to use the [b]Spide Gadget[/b], I will have to hold the B button on my controller and this applies to the other ones as well. To get them out is a bit slow and you are kind of a sitting duck while doing so.

Except for the [b]Serpent[/b] gadget, that one makes you move and it seems to be quick to activate. I wish I could have used [b]Firefly[/b] more but besides the delay of holding X and the time it takes for the smoke to explode, it's not worth it as sometimes it will be out of range of enemies and can hurt you and your allies.

[h1]Graphics and Performance[/h1]
The graphics for the game are honestly beautiful with some of the scenes being simply breathtaking, all backed up with a fantastic soundtrack.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3111728377
I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM. I experienced no issues while I was playing, and the game ran fine for me. Although there were some drops in my frames a few times that may be due to the fact I need new PC parts, only time will tell if I can run the next game.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
I had a ton of fun with [b]Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name[/b], but I need to mention that if you are someone who is starting out with the series, I'd avoid this game for now, as you won’t understand the story of this game all that well. Also, the game is only 6-7 hours long. There is a lot of side content but that only brings it up to about 20-40 hours in length. I’d wait for a sale before buying this game as 64.99 CDN is a lot of money if you only want to focus on the game's story.

Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name is a new entry in the long running series of titles that erased their old international name (which was Yakuza), but remained mainly open world action adventure titles with beat ’em up combat and cinematic stories. This entry, as the title itself says, is a side story that is set during the events of Yakuza: Like a Dragon, but despite the short visit to Isezaki Ijincho (the main setting of that game), most of the events happen in the classic Sotenbori that was originally seen in Yakuza 2.

At this point I usually write that the “open world” section is not big but is otherwise dense with stories, but it isn’t exactly the case in this game. It’s not fully embracing a typical open world onslaught of icons pointing to busywork tasks, but for whatever reason the substories do go in this direction this time around. Not that there are no longer more deep side stories for you to explore, but most of the optional content this time around is far closer to how substories were in the earliest entries, with simple “bring me X item” tasks. While the longer more involved substories rarely do anything interesting even when their premise is good. There’s one wonderful crossover exception, but apart from it, the substories are pretty weak in this one.

Same goes for the main story, really. You do get to learn more about some secret agent-like society that was first hinted upon in Yakuza 6 and some of the characters shown there seem to be set up to reappear in a later game. But as far as the current story goes, you get some minor details and some new emotional scenes talking about things you already knew from other games and it’s not particularly fulfilling. Some of the new characters are really nice and Kiryu, for a change, has more range in his personality, but it’s not a game that will interest anyone with its story but the biggest fans of the series.

So what did I like about Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name? It plays really goddamn well. Just like with Lost Judgment, combat controls are extremely fun and better than they’ve ever been in the series. Every fight just flows well and provides enough challenge (on a highest difficulty) for those who like it, while providing a perfect amount of challenge (on other difficulties) for people who just want to have fun. Granted, some mini-games still go really unfair, unless you grind or look up best solutions, but those are an exception and most of the time this game is just really fun to play.

Yet it puts it in a weird spot. If you like RGG universe games for gameplay and it alone can interest you, this is a good game for you. It’s unlikely to become your favorite, but it’s really really fun. But if you like the RGG universe for the story, you really can skip this one and not miss out on anything the games won’t recap if needed later on. I liked it, but at the same time, it was a rather forgettable even if enjoyable time.

"This is a shorter side story", they said. "We only took six months to make this", they said. 

Riddle me this: how is it that a game that was thrown together in six months - PALTRY amount of time by today's standards - has far more content for $50 at launch than most games that cost $20 more and took YEARS to develop? Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio. That is all. 

Let's get one thing out of the way real quick: this is easily the shortest story in the series by far. Only five chapters to get through, most of them can take you - assuming you prioritize the story and occasionally upgrade your abilities - about a decent seven to eight hours, tops. That being said, story itself is as rock solid as you'd expect. Though be warned, if this is your first foray into the series, you might be left out of the loop on some things, so at the very least, watch a story recap to get caught up (bare minimum; play or watch Yakuza: Like a Dragon). To keep it as spoiler-free as possible, this is a short and sweet adventure that - especially towards the end - is a perspective flip on a certain part of Y:LaD (set at the same time as the latter, to be exact) and leads directly into the next game, Infinite Wealth. 

As for the game itself, well... it's more Yakuza. Or Like a Dragon as it's called now. More of that beat-'em-up goodness that you've come to know and love is still present and accounted for, and given some of that much-needed polish from Judgment, 'cause RGG have pretty much mastered the Dragon Engine by this point that - without exaggeration - this is THE BEST Ki-er, Joryu has played in DE by far. 

Spoiler alert - no, the styles from 0 and Kiwami don't return, and Kiryu's still using the same style that he did from 6 onwards, but two things - it's given a proper name now (Yakuza) and, perhaps most importantly, it just FEELS so much better to play. And if you want to be on some real goofy ahh Roger Moore-era Bond chicanery, then the Agent style's got you covered. It's a little cumbersome to get used to (the Rush Combo in particular is a little sluggish), but the gadgets more than make up for it with how hilariously fun they are thanks in part to the DE's wonky-as-ever physics. 

As for side content, there's still a fair bit to be had. For all intents and purposes, this is basically the Kaito Files from Lost Judgment if it were turned into a standalone entry. Short story to get through, but this time around, the content is a lot more plentiful (Substories are present, for one), having all the usual staples you'd expect (Karaoke, Pocket Circuit, Hostess Clubs, Completion List, etc). Realistically speaking, though, you'll probably be spending A LOT of your time in the Castle, which has the best iteration of the series' coliseum (last seen in Kiwami 2, fun fact) yet. Trust me, it's better to see it for yourself if you haven't already. 

Yes, this game is worth it. Whether full price or on sale, you can never go wrong with an RGG Studio product. Just that simple.

tl;dr this is a pretty good entry in the franchise and is fairly dense with content. the combat system is quite novel and fun to play around with, though not much else is original and there are some flaws. it's 45 GBP which may or may not be a bit much for you considering that yakuza: like dragon is ten pounds more for more than double the stuff to do. the demo is pretty cool too.

TECHNICAL

Maybe my computer is getting old but it seems like this game takes a while to load things. Entering combat or a building causes a bit of lag. It also crashed twice during these "entering" situations. Maybe wait a while for some performance things to be ironed out if your computer is not so good. Aside from that you can expect typical Dragon Engine stuff to happen, for better or worse (for me at least the ragdolling is funny).

GRAPHICS/AUDIO

The game still has realistic models and buildings, it looks like how it would in Kiwami 2 for example. It matches Kiwami 2's appearance to the point where it has the same level of saturation and shininess to it that I don't like. I much preferred the look of Yakuza: Like a Dragon on that front. 

VAing is of similar good quality to previous installments. Somewhat of a spoiler: Kuroda gets to flex his crying chops and does a good job on that end. 

COMBAT

The combat system has a two-style system akin to Judgement. Kiryu has a hard hitting, slower Yakuza style that is better for one-on-one combat and a fast Agent style that is good at group fights and uses James Bond gadgets. I certainly think the system is better implemented than Judgement's was in that neither style is overridingly better than the other. Yakuza style uses a lot of moves from previous games and it's satisfying to kick a guy across the street. Agent lets you steal weapons, throw people, and blow them up; there's a drone move but I found no actual use for it. 

In general, juggling enemies definitely seems easier than in previous games. I was able to get juggles off every combat and I'm a complete scrub at this sort of thing.

The leveling system is like Yakuza 4 with the lines of orbs. You don't really unlock anything incredible through leveling but it gives stat ups so you will need to level up.

SIDE STUFF

The game is set in primarily in Sotenbori, which is unusual but makes sense for a more compressed game. There aren't any truly new minigames other than one arcade game but there are innovations on existing ones. The cabaret clubs use FMVs with real people and are much shorter per hostess, pool got added back, as did Pocket Circuit, which had an overhaul to make it completely independent of money. I personally have never liked Pocket Circuit as it was effectively random whether you would fall of the track even with an optimal build, but it hasn't gotten worse.

There's a new "secondary city": the Castle, where you can do some cool things. You can change your appearance and fight in the Coliseum, an RGG staple. One of the funnier innovations of the Coliseum are team battles and the ability to play as non-Kiryu fighters. Yes, you can fight a hulk of a man in the arena while playing as some scrub you had destroyed in 30 seconds just prior, then recruit that same hulk and do it all over again. 

Unfortunately, the substories have re-used the annoying system from Judgement where you have to go to your "office" to start any of them. It's even worse than in Judgement, actually, because in Judgement you could encounter a few substories on the street, but here you get every substory except for a specific sequence of seven via this office billboard thing. Another oddity is that almost no substory grants an item as an award. 

Aside from substories there are also these miniquests you can do that are mostly either singular fights or fetch quests. They're pure filler if we're being honest, except for a few interesting ones that make you hunt for landmarks. 

PLOT

Two things to note on the outset:

1. This game is only five chapters long, which is a half to a third of most RGG games. If that's too little story, get this game on sale (or don't get it). If it's not, then it's not. 

2. This is not a game to introduce someone to the franchise with. If you don't want to play through the first six games, that's one thing and Gaiden would introduce you to the contours of Kiryu's story to some degree but the game has significant spoilers for Yakuza: Like a Dragon so it's not great as a primer for either main character's storylines.

The story's not bad but I was expecting a bit more on two fronts. The first is that the impression I got from promotion material was that this would be like a James Bond - RGG hybrid, but I would say that largely it's more of the latter than the former. Obviously having an RGG-type story is not bad in and of itself but the secret agent angle is not as prominent as I thought it would be. 

The second thing is that I feel that this game's story exists to promote the upcoming game, Infinite Wealth, and therefore is a bit beat-by-beat by itself. The side characters for example were a bit undercooked and not exactly special. The main villain is honestly not all that great either and is someone we've seen before (not literally but also quite literally). Some of this may be the short length of the game: perhaps there was not enough time in the story to make them more developed. The twists in the story weren't great but I can see what they were trying to do with some of them: they were out of the blue but also not shocking on an emotion level either. The best part of the story was the absolute end scene, which is strange because it is one of the most emotionally impactful scenes in the series; the rest of the game shouldn't really be standing on the same podium as that cutscene.

I imagine that sometime down the line after Infinite Wealth comes out people will make the case that plot-wise, Gaiden should be considered by new players to be a supplement to Infinite Wealth and not something that is outstanding on its own except for the aforementioned cutscene. I assume that some but not all characters will show up in the next game: the yakuza characters will potentially be prominent but I cannot imagine a significant role for "Boss" who appears two times ever but has a trading card dedicated to him.

INFINITE WEALTH DEMO

I would venture that this demo accounts for a significant portion of the price. I didn't play too much of the demo stuff but what I see makes me optimistic. The map is packed, the minigames are quite fun, and the combat is expanded upon in a good way that leaves much less up to chance. There are a few iffy things like animation stuff and some strange audio effects in cutscenes - one of Ichiban's lines had a noticeable echo for example, but I assume by Jan 2024 this stuff will be fixed. The story demo makes me think that the writing will retain the quality from previous entries as well, even given the setting transplant. 

I know there is some controversy over the English dubbing, but I don't usually play these games with dubbing anyways. It just seems strange in concept given that the past games kind of point against the main characters being perfect unaccented anglophones, you know?

Note that you have to beat Gaiden to be able to play the demo.

I started off "Like a Dragon Gaiden" with a strong feeling of déjà-vu, concerning the sceneries, map and gameplay - a feeling that progressively vanished as I went on playing the game.

So, true; the bases of the gameplay are relatively the same as before, even if each Yakuza game has the talent to show some notable differences for this matter. The map consists in only the city of Sotenbori, and later on the castle, and at start I wished Kiryu could have evolved through a different area, city, as he was supposed to be "incognito".

Well . . . fact is, now that I've finished the game, I feel just blown away by those few dozens of hours I've played, and its' captivating story; it's a Yakuza title that is very worthy to appear in the series, even essential - with an ending that is certainly long, but "Grand Finale" style. And I think that what strongly participated to my feeling of satisfaction in the end was, as for other Yakuza games I've played (including the Judgment ones), I just took my time, with the mini-games, with the Coliseum, and the Akame requests - and all just fit together perfectly, the game was a real blast and don't regret one bit playing this to the end. I also felt that the combat difficulty was a bit higher, which I appreciated.

It isn't perfect though, some lengthy grinding may be necessary for the Coliseum for instance; or once again, the map is actually the most limited in the series - but whatever, Like a Dragon Gaiden is a total banger, mostly if you care to not rush it and explore well all of its' map and everything it has to offer.

So if you already played and liked some games of the franchise, you can buy this with no hesitation ; and if you're a newcomer, my personal advice would be to play the games in the most chronological order possible, starting with Yakuza 0, the first game in the series, and a most well reputed one, for all its' great qualities and fun. But overall I can only recommend such a great game, that made me feel that RGG took all possible care in respecting their audience and followers, and executed that close to perfectly.

Honestly floored by how much I enjoyed this game. It's a short one, well for a game in this series, only having a small handful of chapters and a fair bit of side content. The combat in this game is fun. The Agent Style adds quicker moves together with gadgets that are fun to use in certain fights when you've figured out how to control your opponents with them. The Yakuza style is probably the most fun Kiryu has been to play in a non RPG game in a good while. Overall the usage of these two styles together can make fights with enemies and bosses alike interesting if you use them in fun ways. 

A fair bit of the side content is related to The Coliseum which gives you your standard 1 V 1 fights of past games, vs groups of enemies and the new mode where you have a team you assembled face off against an enemy team. This mode is fun when figuring out how to best support your team to make sure they don't get eliminated whilst fighting everyone although leveling up said team mates does feel a bit tedious and time consuming unless you have a lot of money on hand already. That being said, when your team is the appropriate level it's a fun side mode to figure out how to handle battles. You can also play as the fighters you recruit although they have a limited moveset so Kiryu is usually who I stuck with.

The story and music is some of the best the series has had. Almost all of these tracks are amazing and the composers of them went above and beyond! The story is genuinely something I did not expect to hook me as it is a side story that seems like lead up to Infinite Wealth but oh how I was wrong. This story goes from a small steady thing to one of the most engaging bits of story this series has ever had. I am honestly amazed with how they hooked me so good towards the end. This is a must play experience for fans of Kiryu's story. 

Beyond that this game has side activities you would expect from the series. Golf, mahjong, gambling, cabaret clubs, side stories, pocket circuit, locker keys, Master System games, arcade games, claw games, pool, shogi and darts. 

This is a game that is worth it for long time series fans and if you are new to the series start with Yakuza 0 or the first game on PS2, otherwise this game will probably not do as much for you.

[h1] Gaiden is the new peak of Yakuza[/h1]
As a reminder: 
[b]Do not play this before completing Yakuza 0-7[/b]
This game is a conclusion of all the Yakuza games released to this day. Playing this first would be the same as watching the final Season of Attack on Titan or any other good series before Season 1-4. You would ruin your experience.

Now for the review:
Kazuma Kiryu is back, for better or worse, depending on how you see it, but on a technical level, this game takes everything that made Yakuza 6 and Kiwami 2 amazing and improves it quite a bit:

[h3] Combat [/h3]
Kiryu keeps his Dragon of Dojima style, which is now called the Yakuza style, but it’s slightly nerved in comparison to Y6 and K2. They made it slightly slower and took away two of the side-steps, you can only do one now (and you get a roll upgrade later) otherwise the moveset is mostly unchanged.

The star of the show is the new Agent style. It’s mixture of Yagamis Crane and Kiryus old rush style with some new gadgets, which are really fun to use.

Gameplay wise Agent style is superior, especially on harder difficulties, due the nerving of Yakuza style and it generally being faster.

One of the biggest changes in terms of combat is the number of enemies you can fight at once. Some battles (mostly in the Colliseum) makes you fight up to 20 enemies at once. 
After this game, One Man Army Kiryu definitely deserves his title.

[h3] Minigames [/h3]
The main story might be shorter but in terms of minigames and side content, Gaiden has almost as much content as a normal Yakuza game:
[list]
    [*]Improved Pocket Circuit Racing
    [*]Improved Colliseum with it’s own Subplot including Team Battles and the opportunity to control and fight with different characters other than Kiryu.
    [*]A mixture of Judgment side cases and and the classic Substories. It’s presented in a similar way as in Judgment but play out like the classic funny substories we know from Yakuza.
[*]New and old Karaoke songs, including Bakamitai
[*]Billiard for the first time in the Dragon Engine
[*]Hostess Club (They made it worse and more creepy by using real actresses, but it’s there for the people who like it).
[/list]

Additionally, something, that doesn’t really fit into any of the Subcategories: 
[b]You change the appearance of Kiryu now.[/b]
Some outfits from older games return or you can just dress him up as a clown, and it will affect almost every cutscene!


Now for the most important part of the game:
[h3] The Plot[/h3]
In terms of story writing, it's kind of amazing to think that the entire situation of Kiryu, where everything started to go downhill for him, begun in Yakuza 5 or more specifically it's ending.
Before that, all Yakuza games had it's of own concluded stories without any big impact for it's successors, but with Yakuza 5 and successor Yakuza 6, everything changed:
[olist]
[*]Kiryu ends up in prison due the aftermaths of Yakuza 5 (2012)
[*]Haruka leaves Morning Glory Orphanage due unwanted attention by media (sometime between 2012-2014)
[*]Haruka meets Yuta (2014)
[*]Haruka gets hospitalized due her involvement with Yuta (2016)
[*]Kiryu fakes his death to protects his family (2016)
[*]Which leads to Gaiden (2019-2020)
[*]Which then leads to Infinite Wealth, due the affairs in Gaiden and Yakuza 7. (2023)
[/olist]
The entirety of Yakuza 6 and Gaiden could have been prevented, if Kiryu would have been there to protect Haruka. The decision Kiryu made at the end of Yakuza 5 to go into prison were the trigger for everything that took place afterwards. You could even go further back and say that Kiryus decision to let Haruka pursue her dream of becoming an Idol let to all of this, which is impressive to think about.

You could say, that this is all an one big arc and it's still ongoing for 11/12 years now.

If the writers of Yakuza, or Like a Dragon, how it’s called now, planned this from the start, it’s actually really good story writing. Now we will have to see how it continues in Like a Dragon Infinite Wealth

The sum it up, without spoiling the game, this game has definitely the most emotional scene in the entire franchise with one of the best voice acting pieces I’ve ever heard, which would even make the toughest Yakuza cry.

Absolutely loved this game. Its events occur at the same time as Like a Dragon's, so it's quite a self-contained game story-wise, but it still took me 20+hr to beat the game and side content (notably, substories and arena, didn't quite never got into Pocket Circuit racing).

As Kiryu's last dance approaches (presumably), we get to see him in action again from the ending of Y6 until the ending of Like a Dragon. This time around, Kiryu's some kind of secret agent with gadgets and all, which give some variety to the combat gameplay. First few hours of combat fell a bit stale and lack options, but variety quickly grows and combat gets funnier very soon as you start unlocking new moves.

We get the same old Yakuza Style, and the brand new Agent Style, which is a more swift, agile combat approach in which you can use Kiryu's gadgets. Some of them felt pretty useless (cigar and drones), but thread and rocket-powered shoes felt like they added variety and added some strategical options, so a nice change of pace. It's not like fights are very difficult anyway, specially since this game allows us to unlock Tiger Drop as early as chapter 1...

Music and voice acting are top tier as usual and the graphics are the same formula as ever: gorgeous for main character models, more modest in environments, and some PS3 sprinkle for NPCs...

If anything, I would complain that unlike in Y6 or LaD, Gaiden's new characters didn't really leave a mark on me. Kiryu and the old dogs steal the show, really. Though I would like to see Akame back, she seems qualified to take over as a new kind of Florist of Sai.

All in all, if Like a Dragon franchise is the kind of game you enjoy, this is close to the greater ones, so don't hesitate to give it a try. Solid 8-8.5 for me.

TL;DR: Same great Yakuza game formula. If you're a fan of the series and the developer, RGG Studios, you already know what to expect in terms of presentation, execution, humor, combat, minigames, gameplay mechanics and so on. If its not broke, why fix it, right? If anything, you can expect some innovations such as (but not limited to) the 'Agent' style with its variety of gadgets, going into this game. A must buy for any Yakuza fans, especially if you're a diehard fan that has played every entry because this game panders to people like us with multiple callbacks (moreso than any other previous titles) to previous games. Its like a RGG Studios love letter to their fans, in the form of a game. Story-wise, this takes places during Yakuza: Like A Dragon and you will see references to parts of that game here.

This is likely going to be the last game we will see the legendary Kazuma Kiryu in a good ol' Yakuza beat-em-up style game and as the main protagonist as his appearance in the upcoming mainline entry, Infinite Wealth (which will primarily star Ichiban Kasuga and co.), is going to be his last appearance (heavily implied from the trailers). RGG Studios have gone on record to state that mainline entry games are now going to be turn-based only moving forward, meaning this game is a side entry. Plus Gaiden translates to 'another tale' so that's a fun fact for you. Like any other previous Yakuza game entries, there are numerous callbacks to that have happened in the previous Yakuza games, so if this is going to be your first Yakuza game, expect to be confused.

The game's engine is amazing. This is definitely the same game engine that will be running the upcoming mainline entry, Infinite Wealth. Faces (to an extent, NPCs as well) and facial expressions are amazingly detailed. Lighting and textures has been improved, I dont know how RGG Studios do it, every game they release they just one-up themselves in the graphics department. Simply amazing. Performance-wise, its great too. 4k60fps without DLSS gave me no stutters or performance losses on my 3060. Shame that this has to be pointed out as numerous modern game releases have been plagued with performance issues.

Gameplay-wise right off the bat, even without upgrades, Kiryu feels much more agile akin to Yagami from the Judgement series in his new 'Agent' style. The 'Agent' style battle stance and moves are even similar to that of the detective's. Kiryu is also much faster and lighter hitting and he comes equipped gadgets to play around with, like the wire thats showcased in this game's store page. 

The legendary Dragon of Dojima fighting style that we all know and love, dubbed as 'Yakuza' style here, makes its reappearance too. Although in this game, Kiryu does come with more baseline moves such as being able to charge your attacks from the getgo rather than needing an upgrade like in the previous titles. He's a also tadbit slower than the [strike] Yagami style [/strike] 'Agent' style but hits harder and can now, for the first time in the series, counterattack right after getting hit with either a headbutt, a quick punch or a quick kick. This is exclusive to 'Yakuza' style and it essentially allows you to trade blows with enemies. Kiryu naturally has this new ability without needing an upgrade though its not stated anywhere in the game that he can do this so I'm making a point to mention this in my review. You can also later, get an upgrade to charge these counterattacks. Almost all of the fighting moves and heat actions we know and love are back in this game, like the repeating knee to the face, mashing punch that will lead into a heat action, finishing holds and more. Understandably, some heat actions have been omitted as it wouldnt have fit Kiryu's current personality, such as the heat action where you were able to scrape an enemy's face on the ground in Yakuza 5.

Mortal wounds from the Judgement series are not present in this game. Furthermore, both the 'Agent' and 'Yakuza' styles have their own unique BGMs that will play during a fight, much like Yagami with his various styles having unique BGMs in the Judgement series. Picking up items overworld that are elevated off the ground have been made much less tedious here with the wire too as opposed to how tedious it was back in the Judgement series. Also, finally, you can now smoke on demand as Kiryu (no, the smoking taunt in Yakuza 5 doesnt count) at any of the designated smoking areas just like Yagami can.

For the first time in the series, you are now able to customize Kiryu's outfit as well as equip him with various accessories and not just change into preset outfits (which were only available during post-game in the previous titles)! While technically you could already do this in Yakuza 6, your choices were only between the full iconic grey suit or ditching the coat and just the red shirt with sleeves rolled up. In Gaiden, you are given a wide variety of outfits and accessories to pick and choose from to completely dress Kiryu up in fashion, head to toe.

The Sotenbori locker and finding the respective locker keys to unlock each locker from Yakuza 5 returns in this game.

One of the biggest changes to minigames is the change to the Cabaret hostess club minigame. The Yakuza series has always found a way to incorporate interactions with real gravure or JAV actresses, such as the live chat minigame in Yakuza 6, into one of the minigames but it has never been done with the Cabaret hostess minigames. In the past, the games would have Kiryu interact directly with various actresses with their likeness rendered into an in-game model using their faces as a reference. In Gaiden, this has been replaced with a VR-esque styled gameplay where the hostess addresses you as Kiryu while directly looking at the screen/camera. Personally, this change felt really jarring to me since you could even see the ringlight in the actresses' eyes. It certainly wasn't my cup of tea, though your mileage may vary, depending on if you're into this particular style of interaction.

What an amazing game. This game is the pure Like a Dragon/Yakuza experience without all the failing of the other games. The combat is very good, importing many of the improvements made in the Judgment series and altering it to fit Kiryu's gameplay. Juggling and mortal reversals make a return, while Extreme Heat has become very akin to EX Boost. The only thing I would complain about in combat is there is a fairly low amount of heat actions, but the ones they brought into this game are excellent. The progression is pretty good, returning to using money and the new Akame Points to buy upgrades. Bringing money back into skills make it really fun and interesting to actually earn money, due to its direct impact on gameplay now.

The story is amazing. It ties into Yakuza: Like a Dragon but from the perspective of Kiryu, giving us a fresh look at the events of that game, while also tying up Kiryu's story, since Yakuza 6's bittersweet ending left something to be desired. All of the new characters in this game are to become instant favorites, they did an amazing job with the cast of this game.

Visually this game is beautiful. The game is visually darker than other Dragon Engine titles, but they also use more highlights and brighter colors to offset the darker shading present, giving us one of the most striking titles yet. All the UI and menus look sleek as well. Everything is expertly shaded, animated, modeled, and rendered to the point where they would splice in real-life footage cause they were so confident. The quality of the visuals is so good that there are no more pre-rendered cutscenes, the in-game just looks that good now. 

The game length is about 1/3 of a full Yakuza title. Not the worst thing though, since it bypasses the long, confusing stories of the previous game with a short one that does everything that it needs to. Plus, if you need more game to play, there is still tons of side content to dig your teeth into. All of the side content in this game got an expansion (except for golf, sorry DJ Khaled). The Colosseum is tons of fun, with a huge amount of fights to do. Pocket circuit is back, with more races than ever to do. The Akame Network side content is filled with either well-written personal stories, or silly one-offs to fight homeless guys or convenience store clerks to recruit to your army. The cabaret minigame is all live-action 4K footage, which takes 23.4 gigabytes of space on your computer sadly. 

OST is full of bangers, its on Spotify if you want to listen after you play this game. Game reuses some songs from Yakuza 0 and Judgment/Lost Judgment for substory music, which is kinda funny. All the karaoke tracks in this game are good, some being brand new and some being remastered ones from previous games. 

Overall, an amazing game. Taking the best from the previous games while improving on the shortcomings of previous Kiryu games makes this a must-play for Yakuza/Like a Dragon fans. Can not recommend this game enough. 9/10

150 words or less review:

Gameplay:
An action-RPG at its heart, Like a Dragon Gaiden combines its seasoned-past with their newer IP, Judgment, to craft an engaging and combo-orientented brawler. While there could be room for a little more refining in a specific fight style, gameplay never felt boring and there is always something new to do. Even if the player doesn't love the fighting mechanics, rhythm-based karaoke, pocket circuit racer, shogi, darts, pool, and much more offers a variety that makes this game addicting to play from start to finish.

Graphics:
With AAA games making it harder to stand out from the crowd, LaD still manages to capture the world and its characters with very little infidelity. Facial expressions, pores on a face, and detailed landscapes makes this game still beyond worthy to look at. The only aspect stopping it right now from being more "modernized" is raytracing

Music:
Not "gotta-download-this-album" worthy, but still music that purposefully matches the tone of the moment,

Story:
Long-time fans will love the story of Kiryu's tale into obscurity. The questions of legacy and if a legacy is worth it if the person cannot witness it all unfolds and proves to be the Dragon of Dojima's strongest chracter study yet

Score: 8/10 (One of RGG studio's best action-rpgs yet, with a story that will satisfy longtime fans and motivate them to see what comes next)

It's difficult to review this game without spoiling plot points in Yakuza 6 and Yakuza Like a Dragon so I'll just point out pros and cons so you can decide if you want to get this chapter of the saga or would rather watch it on a video.

[PROS]
- STORY: The story picks up where Yakuza 6 ended. I feel like many people might have had issues with the way the story ended, so this one tries to expand on what happened after the events of 6. And the story happens at the same time Yakuza Like a Dragon's plot happened, so if you played that one before you'll be able to piece together pieces and understand better the reason behind some of the plot points in that one too. And the quality is pretty good, without spoiling anything the ending had me fighting the tears off.
- COMBAT: I've heard multiple opinions on the combat of this game, but as someone that has yet to play Judgement the combat in this game feels polished. Again, I jumped from the combat of 6 into this one and it feels so much more polished. Game has two styles: Agent - A style that is characterized for being ultra fast but low damage and Yakuza - Basically the style of 6 where you hit like a truck but attacks are way slower, leaving you open to getting hurt. So, if you liked the combat in 6, it's here. And if you wanted new combat you also get that and can easily switch mid-combat with the push of a button.
- SIDE CONTENT: Lots of minigames to play. It doesn't really introduce a whole lot of new stuff, rather it brings those minigames that were more popular and polishes them, giving us sort of a "Best of" selection of things to do. Things like Pocket Racing, karaoke, coliseum battles, they all make a very strong comeback.

[CONS]
- STORY: This game is the shortest in the entire saga. And it's not an exageration, it's VERY short. I don't know how regional pricing might work for other countries, but right now this is the most expensive Yakuza game in all of Steam, so having a game that you can complete in around 35 hours (I took my sweet time to play it, tried all minigames, completed most of the side content, walked around the map instead of running and still finished it in 32 hours) for that price is one thing you might wanna keep in mind. The quality is there, RGG put out a fantastic product, but it's short.
- COMBAT: While the combat is polished, the fact that the game is so short gives us a smaller list of heat actions and all of the abilities are gained with money rather than experience or training. Depending on how much you play the side content you might be super weak the entire game or super strong, there's no really in-between. And the game ends before you can get properly comfortable with your fighting style.
- SIDE CONTENT: Again, the fact that the game is so short makes this part a gray area, while there are plenty of side activities and these are well done you don't really experience a whole lot before the game ends. The number of side stories in this game is surprisingly small, and now instead of getting them by walking around and helping the residents of the city, you are given side stories from a side-quest hub in your hideout which I don't know ... for me it sort of robs the charm these games have. You're not a good samaritan helping people anymore, you're an agent hired to do odd jobs. And I know it's only for this game but I can't not mention the tonal shift the game takes. Yakuza games are always a serious story with a side of silly. This game is very serious from beginning to end, couple of side stories are funny but overall the game mantains a very serious tone which might charm some and polarize others.

[ACHIEVEMENTS]
This must be the easiest game in the series to 100%. I've seen people do it in around 45 hours. The Completion List means nothing, you don't have to finish it on a high difficulty, and I'm pretty sure you can complete all the achievements in your first playthrough if you have the patience for it. Personally, it disappoints me a little, but I also understand how it can be due to the length of the game.

[SUMMARY]
Overall a very strong addition to the series. One that in a way was needed to tie up all of Kiryu's journey on a nice bow and send him for what might be his final adventure in Infinite Wealth. I'm very satisfied with the product I got, but if you think the price might be too much and want to wait for a discount that is a very valid option.

Outstanding game - As someone who's played the entire series, this is a love letter to fans, and those who've followed Kiryu's story from his life as a young punk to his life as a surrogate father to his kids. I am sobbing at the ending, and dear god I am not ready for Infinite Wealth.

You really should wait and play the other games to understand Kiryu's story before this - it makes a lot of the callbacks and some of the fights themselves have just that much more oomph to them. The combat sadly is not as smooth as Lost Judgment, despite Kiryu's style switching and Yakuza style being as brutal and weighty as ever. Thankfully, juggling is back and Kiryu can do it, which is honestly pretty awesome. 

The story though, wow. Remarkable, and while it may have some filler, it was engaging to me from start to finish. The last act was a highlight, and it def shows the writers and whole team are much better at crafting a proper ending to their stories. I don't think I've cried that hard over a game in years.

Will always be a fan of RGG Studios, and hope to see more and more from them as the years go on. Just make the Yakuza style hit slightly faster FFS.

Overview:

Depending on how you look at it, this is either a low-effort dlc-into-full-game spinoff or part of a proper send-off of the Kiryu Era or objectively both.

Part of the reason why some would buy this game is that it is possible RGG will move on from  the older Yakuza action games  as they continue onwards in the Ichiban era, but moving on seems hard for both the developer and the players.

Supporting this game might send a message they should do more action spinoffs like this and Judgment now that turn-based is the MAIN game.

Regardless - the point of this game is that it is intended as a final sendoff for those who were invested into the older games and an excuse to make people pay for Kiryu. You get backstory of Kiryu addressing events from Yakuza 6 and Y:LAD and a linkage + demo to Infinite Wealth.

Spoiler Advisory for old and new players:

To be clear, this is game for the fans from the Kiryu era. It is heavy on references that need most players to play those game to appreciate them.

If you are new, ensure you played at least Yakuza: Like a Dragon before you play this game to avoid spoiling yourself. Knowledge of Yakuza 6 is recommended but not optional.

While you should play this game before Infinite Wealth, but it isn't *strictly necessary* based on the story I seen for myself. Not everything about Kiryu in IW is addressed in this game but if you love Kiryu anyway, just play this game before IW if you can.

Why you should play this game (slight spoilers):

- You are a big RGG/Kiryu fan like me
- A lot of references to older games. Probably most of all the Kiryu Y0-Y6 games.
- You enjoy the fan service, familiar minigames and familiar 4-king-something subplots
- You enjoy dressing up Kiryu
- You think live-action girls cabaret is awesome (meh)
- And you think it's cool to play as an Agent (it's a little absurd and tech superhero-like)
- You want to see the latest Sotenbori (it's the ONLY main map in this game. the rest don't really count)
- You want to try the Infinite Wealth demo (unlocks after completing game)
- You are okay with the pricing

Why you should wait for a sale or skip for Infinite Wealth (again, slight spoilers):

- You expect new and fresh things. There's not much 'new things' aside from agent style and cabaret. The main driving point of this game is just narrative and sentimentalism. No new minigames, just a reboot of Pocket Circuit. And a Coliseum.
- It's quite obvious this game was indeed finished in 6 months. Most of the stuff here are carried from older games. Some parts feel abit unpolished. Just adjust your expectations accordingly.
- There's only one completely new karaoke song. Horrifying!
- There's half of the side stories, and only 1/4 of them is interesting (imho). I never really liked the four-king subplot but here it is, occupying 2/5 of the substories.
- It's too expensive for half the content of any Yakuza game
- You aren't interested in the minigames, sidestories, coliseum, challenges, etc. Then you probably will get even less value of this and probably can finish the game in 2-3 days.

Also the Judgment crossover is one of the bigger sidestories. But it has no dedicated voiced lines for story, just recycled grunting. Google yourself to find out more.

I love crossovers but this one just feels abit meh. Consider it as bait.

Side note on Difficulty:

Dev tries to make the game more accessible through 'action assist' and a 'combat tip' that show things that the game think is helpful. The video is ok (abit annoying) and can be toggled off, but the action assist doesn't work very well, trigger things without your consent and makes you unable to learn the combat, manage your heat bar or fight unpredictably.

Recommend most people to just play normal mode at start. The economics of this game is easy enough for you to eat regularly and prep enough heals.

TLDR: Only Real Yakuza/Kiryu Fans should buy this game. Everyone else should wait for a sale or play any or the older games, or just invest in Infinite Wealth. That game is likely to be rad based on the demo I played.

The story is your typical Yakuza charade. It starts strong, falls flat in the middle and gets really hype towards the end. It also expects you to have finished Yakuza 3, 6 and at least LaD, although some Side content is better with the knowledge of 0, 1, Kiwami 2 and Judgment / Lost Judgment.

The feeling of the Combat is on par with Lost Judgment, although the complexety is not. Joryu has access to Agent and Yakuza Style. Agent is a new one, faster than Yakuza, but deals less damage. You also get access to Gadgets in combat, each bound to one of the Face-buttons of your controller. Yakuza style is slower but allows to charge attacks. Its basically Kiryus Y6/K2 style with some additions and removals. 
The game also features a coliseum that allows to fight as the Peapole you recruit, each with their own movesets, but without any heat actions. On that note: Majima, Saejima and Daigo had their moveset severely reduced from previous games.
The game isn't very long. I've finished it in around 30h with all Side content besides Amon.
It also includes a special Infinite Wealth Demo, that is only playable after beating LaDG, but I haven't really played that one.

My expectations were pretty low considering how short the Kaito Files from Lost Judgment was and the devs statements on the length of the game being compared to that made me think $50 was pretty steep for it. But funnily enough this is probably my game of the year despite its length. With my only real gripe being the lack of NG+ for it, as I think the lack of it hurts the replayability especially with its shorter length. A first time playthrough (watching cutscenes and all) would probably take about 7 hours give or take. Hitting the Platinum only took about 25 hours (one of the easiest plats I've achieved honestly.)

The story (without getting into spoilers) takes place during Yakuza 7. And is pretty much the events of that game through Kiryu's eyes. And was far more emotional than I had ever expected it to be.

The combat reminds me a lot of the first Judgment game. With the 2 fighting styles focusing on crowd control and 1 on 1s respectively. Agent is like Crane where it focuses on crowd control (albeit more with gimmicky gadgets and not Yagami kicking everything.) And "Yakuza" being the slow, but hard hitting 1 on 1 style. Unlike Judgment though, the CC style is actually really useful in battles with bigger groups what with its speed, bombs, rocket shoes and wire grab. Kiryu can air combo now, and it's actually really cool setting up into them and getting creative with what you can do.

I was surprised with how much they actually managed to do with a game that supposedly only took half a year to make. But with how the studio does really well with their "less is more" approach to their open worlds, I guess I shouldn't be too shocked. 

The story is very emotional with good fan service moments throughout, and we see Kiryu in a couple different ways we hadn't seen before. The combat is fluid and allows for a lot of creativity and shenanigans (though yakuza could be a lil faster) and the side activities are like a "Best of" collection from the series. This is probably one of my favorites in the series despite being like a third of the size.

It's like a dash of Judgment in your Yakuza(/LAD) and that's not a bad thing (such as the strong enemy attacks you can interrupt and follow up with hard-hitting counters and bleeding from bladed weapons). The game is short (by comparison) if you're looking for the usual Yakuza experience but if you are invested in the story of the games, if you want some more context behind a certain character's arrival in Like A Dragon, if you are invested in Kiryu and what he has gone through in his life then this story is really, really good. The ending tore my soul apart in the best way. It really is a must for fans.

You will find a some fun references to Yakuza 2 as well as one or two Yakuza 0 callbacks and while it is easy to become overpowered in combat it does, at least, make clearing the street trash rather quick. There are some fun attacks that combine with the agent style but you will find yourself feeling familiar with the style if you've played Judgment (it is not outright copied but has the same tight feel as Yagami's tiger style). Among some incredible cameos I won't spoil, there is a Judgment character who shows up in a really great sub-story. In fact, I'd say the sub-stories in this game are almost all fantastic and worth the time.

The arena allows you to play as many different characters (including three from Judgment). The coliseum really does feel like the big showpiece of the game and it's a really is a spectacle to be introduced to. Akame, a new character, is also a fun addition to the cast.

Problems:
Your mileage may vary but I found the hostess stuff absolutely weird and uncomfortable (but if you're a fan of Kson, that might be different?), two of the four gadgets feel as if you really could just ignore them outright. While there are many options to fight as in the coliseum there is, unfortunately, no real contest between Kiryu's strength and playing as someone like Daigo, Majima, or Saejima (which, while fun, does lack the upgrades Kiryu has). While the group battles in the coliseum are really fun it does bring out a bit of a grind to level your team which might extend gameplay for some but was not quite for me. I also found the omission of some classic heat actions from Kiryu's Yakuza style to be a disappointment. Also, if you happen to be a fan of grappling attacks in combat you can expect to be frustrated as almost all enemies but the weakest will quickly break free. While the agent style does have a fun way to snatch weapons from enemies or the ground there is something lost in not being able to actually carry weapons on your person like previous titles (though you will be familiar with this if you have played the Judgment games).

Conclusion:
All in all, if you're a Yakuza fan (and have played Yakuza 0 and Yakuza 2 or Judgment) you will find a lot here to like. There are some really great moments where you finally see Kiryu losing his composure and usual cool with where his choices in life have left him and the pain it is putting him through. It's a must for following the Dragon of Dojima and his story and leads into an explanation as to why Kiryu will be found in Infinite Wealth. While it might not be worth full retail price right now, the english dub might be enough to warrant it (if you prefer not to deal with subtitles) but I don't think it will hurt to try and get this game at around 40 or so. If you love the Yakuza storyline, however, the price of admission is worth seeing the emotional ride Kiryu goes through in this title.

Quick edit: As for long-time Yakuza fans? You can FINALLY WEAR DIFFERENT OUTFITS WITHOUT HAVING TO BE IN PREMIUM ADVENTURE!

[h1] "I play through every Yakuza" Part Gaiden[/h1]

General:
I absolutely LOVE the new agent style, you get so many fun toys to play with it makes combat an absolute blast, while dragon style is arguably better, agent style is much more fun and entertaining to throw enemies around, blow them up and move at blazing speeds.
The main story is a lot shorter than your usual Yakuza game, though that also means it's much more condensed, it picks up fast and all chapters have a good bit of meat to them, unlike other game where one chapter can end after just going to a phone booth.
I also liked the Ending-Sequence a lot.

Substories:
Most of the substories are rather short, alltough none of them are the basic "oh, no. Con-Man" ones. There aren't really any that are as good as the best ones from other games though but they were still fun to complete.
The requests which are sort of mini-substories were a bit tedious and not all that rewarding even though it felt good to complete all of them. Though they mostly consisted of simple fetch-quests or photograph the thing quest. Though they are pretty optional so it's not a problem.

Minigames:
I really love the minigames in Yakuza and alltough they were only the one's you'd be used to, I had a blast playing Mahjong and finally understanding what's going on since I bothered to learn it for the first time.
Big Minigames: (2)
- [spoiler] Pocket Circuit [/spoiler]
- [spoiler] Coliseum / Hell Team Rumble[/spoiler]

Unique Minigames (Not counting those which are in most other games like Shogi, etc.) : 0
- 

Conclusion:
Alltough technically a shorter game, I did pretty much everything including Amon in this and got pretty much the time I would expect from a numbered entry. I would very much recommend this game and also recommend learning Mahjong, it's actually pretty good once you understand what's going on.

Despite having a rather short main story, about 10 hours long, this game packs everything a Yakuza fan could ask for: good story, amazing gameplay, sick boss fights, and of course it ain't a Yakuza game without the outrageously hilarious and random substories, and hundred thousand mini games.

The game takes place in Sotenbori and on a ship called The Castle, a lavish entertainment center, explaining what Kiryu was doing after [spoiler] faking his death [/spoiler] in Y6 and how [spoiler] he ended up in Y: LAD. [/spoiler] The game contains some heavy spoilers from previous titles, hence if you are new to Yakuza series, perhaps you shouldn't start with this game.

As everyone know, the biggest introduction to the game was Kiryu's new fighting style and the new gadgets. I'm glad RGG brought back style switching mechanism. Besides the Judgment games, Y0 and Kiwami had the best fighting simply because they had the style switching mechanism. This game offers not only a new move set and animations, you get to use high-tech gadgets that are best suited for dealing with multiple enemies -needn't to mention they are also super fun. Who would've thought tossing people around with a literal Spiderman webshooter and blowing them up with explosive cigarettes would be this much fun? It's a shame that we will not have them in IW or future games.

Things that are different from the previous titles:

[u] Level up system [/u] If i remember correctly, this is the first game that require money to level up. You need money as well as Akame points to upgrade your abilities. But needn't worry because the Coliseum arena fights as well as the thugs in the streets give fair amount of money for you to spend on bentos and boozes.

[u] Substories [/u] All the substories are available through Akame instead of randomly running into fake Kiryu or Majima dressed as a cop in the streets. And it only has 26 substories total which is super low compared to the previous titles e.g. Y0 had 100.

You can customize Kiryu's outfit FINALLY. There are plenty of outfits as well as make ups for both outside activity and coliseum fights for Kiryu to wear.

Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name is a fitting final chapter for Kiryu as a spotlight protagonist, that being said, this game is mostly call backs to the previous iterations, especially 6 as this is almost a direct sequel to it. This game was made for fans of the series, and requires a lot of context to fully enjoy. i would recommend at least playing 6 and 7 before this game at minimum. The combat is really satisfying, more so than Lost Judgment which up until now had the best combat in an RGG game in my opinion and the coliseum is a great addition, allowing you to play as different characters with different move sets including characters from previous RGG titles. For the first time in an RGG game, you can freely customize your clothing options without having to beat the game, with options to change everything from suits to shoes and glasses.

The length of the game. Its biggest drawback is its saving grace. At 24 hours I've completed about 80 percent of the game, all sub stories, the main story, the coliseum, im basically doing activity logs and finding locker keys now. that being said, if this was a 40-50 hour game many features would've become stale quickly, for example, the lack of heat actions and the repetitive nature of the miscellaneous quests. I genuinely enjoyed every second of this game except for some of the later coliseum matches which were just ridiculous at some points. The length of the game also makes for a quick delivery of a very satisfying story.

(One hour of play time is the demo for Like a Dragon Infinite Wealth which was also very enjoyable, and will be a day one purchase)

Kazuma Kiryu is dead, and has been for 3 years. In his stead, a Daidoji faction agent named Joryu tires away, hidden from the eyes of the public.

Gaiden is a masterful way of working the Tojo's 4th Chairman back into the franchise after his (apparent) departure in 6 and appearance in LaD. This game, despite being the shortest mainline title, is so packed with content and fun that I took my time taking the sheer amount of side-content in. Being the first mainline game that does not include Kamurocho, you're limited entirely to Sotenbori and a new area, a container ship located off the coast of japan known only as The Castle. Both areas are filled to the brim with things to do, with the best coliseum in the entire franchise being hosted in The Castle. Combat in this game is almost as smooth as Lost Judgment, packing that trademark Kiryu brutality and oomph that has been in the series since day one, making for the best implementation of the Dragon of Dojima style in any game (for me) and the ever fun Agent style is so satisfying to use, thanks to the bond-esque gadgets at your disposal (spider gadget my beloved <3).

The story this time around packs a melancholic kick, and by god did that ending have me tearing up.

Even though Gaiden is a side game with a main story and side contents roughly half the size of the usual RGG games, it still delivers on pretty much most of it. The biggest strength in Gaiden is how it bridges between Yakuza 6, 7 and upcoming Like A Dragon Infinite Wealth. The story revolving about Tojo and Omi's dissolution and how the aftermath of 6 made Kiryu a Daidoji Agent are handled really well. Even with short runtime, all the major characters are well written and have their own story arcs. The final boss symbolizes perfectly well about how the dissolution won't be easy for lots of the yakuza, how times are changing and some of them are desperately clinging to their old way of life. It's tragic but also handled with an intense and cathartic action sequences that is both entertaining to play through and make you feel for the characters.

And then the ending, one of the, if not the saddest moment in the series. It's moments like this that make Kiryu feel believable throughout the games. Beneath his stoic demeanor hides an overwhelmingly warm heart to his family. Gaiden is ultimately a direct continuation of Yakuza 6 and that feeling of parenthood and sacrifice echoes throughout the game and especially in the ending. 

Combat in Gaiden feels great and the more aggressive enemies make for more challenging fights. It just feel and play incredibly well in every situations. The side contents, although small in variety, still manages to entertain. Some substories are among the best in the series and tackle Kiryu's past events, some are about current technological dilemma and some are just really funny. The live action cabaret hostess minigame is actually enjoyable, even if it's shorter than the previous games and lack depth that Yakuza 6 had. The fact that you can't ask them out for Karaoke is also a bummer but the live action videos itself are acted well enough, some are sweet, some are seductive and some are funny to watch. Pocket Circuit is back, still great as ever and it does have a callback to previous Pocket Circuit. The Boutique is great, although a bit barebones compared to other games with similar feature. The Castle Coliseum is the best version of the series coliseum to date, it can be challenging, chaotic and just really fun to fight.

Gaiden is mostly about quality than quantity. It comes with smaller package than the previous games but still manages to be one of the best RGG games, especially for longtime fans. Coupled with varieties of great soundtrack, the updated gorgeous visual, the beautiful locations and its attention to details and generally just how much optimized the game is, it's made in less than a year  but still a quality game through and through.

A perfect bridge between previous games and Infinite Wealth that not only concludes one of the series' story arc in a beautiful way but also genuinely telling an engrossing and emotional story.

Like a Dragon Gaiden is a side story of what [strike]Kiryu[/strike]Joryu was up to after Yakuza 6 and during 7. It's a relatively shorter game at just around 20 hours for the campaign. But don't let that fool you into thinking it'll be lower quality because it definitely isn't. The story is one of the best in the entire series and has some very emotional moments. The gameplay is a refinement of Kiwami 2's with a hint of Judgment. The new agent style is very fun as well. Kiryu + grappling hook is a very fun combo as it turns out. Of course the usual Yakuza insanity also returns in full swing. Pocket circuit is back baybeee and it is glorious!

Oh and it comes with a demo for LaD 8, and it's great! It's a massive improvement over 7 and I can't wait to get my hands on it.

The one big downside is that it doesn't have new game+ so consider that if that's a big deal for you. Otherwise this is a solid entry in the Like a Dragon/Yakuza series.

I want to start by saying as a fan of the franchise the ending to this game is so cathartic and unbelievably emotional. Its a roller coaster ride. Its a kick in the chest. It genuinely feels like a reward for playing the last 7 games and It makes me all the more excited for infinite wealth. I can not wait. 

How in the world did RGG studios make such an incredible game in only 6 months? Hell, they gave us more game in 6 months than most devs give us with years of development. What once was meant to be a DLC side story, came out as its own feature game at a reduced price, that barely feels reduced in any way. There is so much on the plate with this game. Returning to sotenbori was a treat, Pocket circuit us back with a vengeance and the Colosseum mini game is better than it has been in like ever. I thought i was going to hate the agent fighting style, but my god its actually fun. Dont let the over the topness of it all steer you away. Game play is king and agent style is super fun. A very nice conclusion and wrap up of Kiryu's story at least until Infinite Wealth hits. The story is easily right up there with Yakuza 0 with a very good mix of comedy and serious moments that everyone has come to love. The quality of cut scenes and cinematics have improved so much and it was an absolute joy to watch.

Combat feels nice although it definitely feels a bit lacking when compared to previous games. There's a smaller variety of heat actions which is a shame and combat is significantly easier as extreme heat mode is a very easy way to cheese most fights. Boss fights are definitely much less fun than compared to previous titles where each boss has a quirk; most of the boss fights in this game feel the same. However, the introduction of Agent style more than makes up for it. I've had way more fun beating people up and throwing them all around than in any other previous game. Coming from Yakuza 7, it was great to beat people up in the combini again.

Another change from previous games is that substories are all now triggered from a "HQ" location which is kind of neat as it is easier to clear through all of them rather than hunting them around town. I can understand why some people might prefer the older method though.

The coliseum was pretty cool but kind of underwhelming due to the ability to cheese fights with extreme heat mode. The team fights also felt kind of forced in and at some point, they become very annoying due to the insanely high health pool of some of the "boss" and "mini-boss" characters can be.

Overall it was a really fun game and well worth it's full price. Steam Deck compatibility from launch was also a really neat bonus.

Like a Dragon Gaiden is the perfect, most service to die-hard fans RGG studios have made to date! I don't write reviews on Steam that often, but this game I simply had to write a review for no questions about it. As someone who's played all the Yakuza titles, starting with Yakuza 7 Like a dragon, then 0-6, and with the Judgment games, I absolutely felt so emmersed and invested into the game at the very start to the very last moments. When I've seen the trailers for LAD Gaiden and seeing it's gameplay, features, new additions along with us figuring out where Kiryu went after the ending of 6, it was one of those games that I simply HAD to pre order and play on day one! And I'm so happy I did. 

(WARNING: SLIGHT SPOILERS TO PREVIOUS GAMES BUT KEPT TO A MINIMUM, NO REAL SPOILERS TO THE STORY)
For those wondering, LAD Gaiden takes place after the story of Yakuza 6, and during the events of Yakuza 7 Like a Dragon, where we figure out and follow the story as to where Kiryu went and disappeared to after the events of 6, and how he ended up in 7 Like a Dragon. 3 Years after the Y6 you understand quick and clear why Kiryu did what he had to do to keep his loved ones safe and erase his name. His challenges and trials during the game to keeping his situation a secret as he's supposed to be a dead man. Only for him to realize Yakuza guys can't take a hint or keep a secret.

The story as always is heaven sent, with clear and very concise understand everything without having to go back. It sucks you in just like every single game they've made for Yakuza. The boss battles and long battles are always a joy to get into, and you feel like a kid in a candy shop just from doing the wacky side quests. And upgrading Kiryu with his Agent and his Legendary Yakuza style was a pure joy grinding for and then taking it into battle with some hooligans on the streets. 

There is only 5 chapters but of course there is no sense of this game feeling short at all. There is plenty to do, as long as you are not in a point of a story where you can't go out and explore. They will make that clear, but you can really take your time with the game without feeling like you have to prioritize anything. Here's just a taste of what you can do.

*Pocket Circuit Racing (Yes it's back for our 50 year old Kiryu XD)
*Fight in The Castle Coliseum (Yes it returns and it's so easy to make money for upgrades)
*Karaoke (Real fan service here with references to the past Yakuza titles)
*Akame Requests (which is reskinned wacky side quests but the wackiness and humor is still here. With a TON of references and special guest appearances from past games and even from Judgment.)
*Buy Clothes for Kiryu (Coliseum, Free Roam and Story)
*Go to the Casinos
*And of course give knuckle sandwiches to street punks

I also wanted to speak a bit on the final chapter without spoiling anything. It was the perfect tie in and ultimate way to finish off the game with preparing for the Omi Alliance and Tojo Clan disbandment. Main reason why I love this so much is because I got to see Ichiban and his friends there, and (in a way) seeing them fighting side by side protecting Watase and Daigo. I was totally fanboying from start to finish, from the moment the camera pans into the room before his speech just seeking and looking for Ichiban like it's Where's Waldo, to seeing Kiryu come in with that punch and remove his glasses to Ichiban, Maejima and Saejima. Seeing this through Kiryu's perspective and seeing the dragon himself meet his successor and equal, along with that heart filling smirk Kiryu gives to Ichiban when he saw him reveal his dragonfish back tattoo really helped make this game for me. And to end it all off with a epic long battle with the Yakuza legends, and then to finish off, a boss battle to end the game that will have you remember the events and villain of Yakuza 5. Just a big chef kiss.

And of course, Kiryu's breakdown and him crying at the closing moments of the game was enough to bring me to tears just like everyone else. We all want Kiryu to be happy and he deserves it and the world 10x over for his heart of gold and influence on others. I'm hoping there will be some closure and happy ending to his story, but I'm already looking forward to Infinite Wealth so much.

In conclusion, RGG has made yet another 10/10 classic for the Yakuza franchise. THIS, is what gaming is about, and what AAA gaming should be. No bugs, god sent story, ultimate fan service, never ending action, fun and remarkable gameplay, and no micro transactions or nickle and diming fan-bases. From the bottom of my heart, thank you RGG. You guys deserve the whole world and more for making incredible games. I pre ordered this game from you guys, took a day off work just to play it, ordered pizza and I didn't regret it not one bit. 

I'm already putting down my pre-order for Like a Dragon Infinite Wealth and it's going to be probably the best birthday gift (or in my case belated Birthday gift since my bday is on the 22nd of January) I will ever receive. I'm looking forward to seeing Ichiban and Kiryu side by side together against the evils they will face.

Thank you for all the memories and heart gripping stories RGG! Never change!

While I disagree with SEGA that this is a good point for those who haven't played any Like a Dragon games before, for those who have kept up with the series, it is an excellent albeit short entry in the overall story that helps wrap up a lot of hanging plots in the series. This game leans pretty heavily into plot points from Yakuza 3-6 and a little of Like a Dragon 7 so it would behoove anybody thinking of playing this game to play those at the very least. 

As far as the gameplay goes, the combat is back to the older beat-em-up style offering many of the previous moves from Yakuza 6 with an all new Agent style that starts off feeling a bit underwhelming but evolves into a fantastic means of crowd control by the end.  Many of the series' staple minigames are back which serve as less of a healthy distraction in this game and more of the bulk of the overall gameplay. 

Ultimately, I believe that this game may be a bit rough for those who are not familiar with the series already and may be a bit short for those who aren't super into the franchise or aren't one of those who force themselves to complete the game 100% but outside of that, it still holds up modestly well to the other entries that precede it.
