Yakuza is one of my favorite game series of all time. It has its highs and lows, and even my least favorite game, Yakuza 5, is still something i would consider a very good game respectfully. Some people still deemed me a bit harsh torwards it, and honestly after playing this i'm realizing how right they were because holy shit.

Like a dragon gaiden is the first game that was made post the departure of its usual game director, Toshihiro Nagoshi, and i didn't think it would make that much of a difference. My bad relationship with this game starts with what i have seen so far of Yakuza Infinite Wealth. 

Hawaii as a setting is fun on paper but in execution? Yakuza is a very political series, regardless of how you want to see it. And the game has made its stance clear by putting how much emphasis on how it is part of the USA and you get to dress up as a cowboy to shoot down the natives while the party has no darker skinned characters to begin with. Oh and you're friend with Richardson now. When in Ishin released this year there was so much emphasis on how colonization was bad and you even slashed the ever loving shit out of his old time equivalent and his men. Its only made worse by having a animal crossing happy home paradise type game set in a real life area and its primarily done for tourists... around a time where a shit ton of natives of hawaii lost their homes. Kinda leaves a bad taste in your mouth, especially when you consider Ichiban was literally fighting his own brother for the rights of the less fortunate and minorities only a mainline game ago.

So that kinda soured my experience but i figured "infinite wealth isn't out yet and this new spin-off is coming soon, perhaps it will help contextualize some things and build my curiosity torwards where the story goes and make me want to check out infinite wealth after... Yakuza is a game i play for the story first and foremost after all... and uh... yeah even on that aspect the game is just not great.

I'll say the game's greatest strenght is the improvement on its combat, besides some weird changes, its good for the most part especially compared to past dragon engine RGG games. Sonic the fighters is fun too!

As for the negatives uh...
-If like me, Kiryu's part in yakuza 5 was your least favorite cause it just felt like kiryu torture porn making him miserable for the sake of it, that's this game's story from the get go. Forget the potential of starting with a clean slate with a new alias as a super agent. That goes out the window really fucking fast for the saaaaame tired shit of 'we need you back in the game'. 
-I figured after 7 we went past the whole "chinese/korean people are evil" trope of early game but they really insisted on getting back to this shit.
-Yakuza always had softcore porno stuff that was always exclusively optionnal. And most of it was usually in-universe and in-engine stuff that still keeps you somewhat immersed in the characters and the world you live in. Gaiden really really REALLY wanted you to go through their creepy live action recorded first person cabaret club where you have the least normal conversation possible with a porn actress and then put so much emphasis on how much of a degenerate and pervert you are when you literally cannot progress the story without going through it. That shit felt straight out of trash like 'the seducers' type game it wasn't fun nor immersive like it insisted so much on being.
-There are moments where Kiryu really feels out of character and has the most passive or neutral stance to the most horrible shit happening before him without any hint of disgust or remorse, like straight up slavery. And Kiryu is a christian that goes pray to a church now? Did i miss something?
-Most of the 'positive' of the story is just cheap underwhelming fanservice mean't to go "REMEMBER THIS GOOD THING THAT YOU LIKED?! REMEMBER IT?!" but in this case it feels more like a desperate way to keep your attention rather than actually making you meet some old friends

Just... tonally Gaiden (and to an extent, infinite wealth) feels a lot more like how Sega always pushed the marketing of the games rather than how the games actually were in practice/play. No matter how improved the combat or gameplay feels Yakuza is a series primarily carried by its characters, narrative and tone and right now it just feels so fucking wrong and doesn't build me any confidence in the future of the series. I might revisit this game later and i could end up being wrong about 8 but its not particularily looking good for me so far. 

And honestly trying to have any crititism or conversation about that leads to people going "ITS JUST A VIDEO GAME" or "STFU YAKUZA IS PEAK" which to me translates to "stop asking questions. Just consume the product and get excited for the next one to come out". SF6 had some yikes bits in its handling of its story and touchy subject but i did not expect street fighter to be a pinnacle in story telling. Yakuza i know can do better and its not looking this way. So anyway im going back to sf6 and wait for Ed to come out for more world tour adventures.

Interesting gameplay, great story, and excellent graphics. Though the publisher said that this is a good entry for the series, I think this is more likely a gift for fans that have played through series from 0 to 7.

A great fan service game for the RGG fans. Only contains 5 chapters, so some plot points and characters are not developed enough. Although, if you are a yakuza fan, the last chapter will probably make up for the all the shortcomings this game has. 

Combat is kinda clunky. I like it better than K2 and 6, but it is still not that fun compared to Yagami from Judgment. The agent style is way too op if you max out everything, but it's fun to look at Joryu using these crazy gadgets. The yakuza style is alright. It's good for 1v1 but that's all I have to say about it. I recommend using mods for this. It's a lot more enjoyable imo.

The substories are on yakuza's standard, but the other main side content is meh. It's just fetch quest and "go beat this group" over and over again. Some of them require you to find a certain place and take a picture. Overall it's there to pad out the game time. 

Coliseum, on the other hand, is the best one we got so far. The variety of fights. You can play as other characters (with a very limited moveset.) Also, there is a nice surprise for those who are a fan of this series if you clear almost every fight.

Soundtrack is alright. There are good tracks there, but not a lot imo. Might be due to not many memorable scenes. New karaoke song is good though. 

The only thing I'm super disappointed about is that, there's no new game plus and legend difficulty.  Only recommended if you are invested in Kiryu's story and have played Yakuza 3 and 6 (Although I urge you to play them all before this one.)

I'm a big fan of the games but this one is just shallow and left me unsatisfied. TLDR I do not recommend it for current price (50$) and would recommend waiting for sale . Can easily recommend it for 30$. It just feels like a dlc turned standalone game and reminds me a lot of current COD MW3 situation
- There's only one city (Osaka) and it's reused from Kiwami 2/LAD , the first chapter does feature yokohoma for like few scenes and goes unused for the rest of the game. I was expecting them to have 3 cities (Yokohoma, Kamarucho and Sotenbori) but only one goes used.
- The minigames suck for the most part. Pocket circuit racing (I seriously don't get people hype behind it) is just reused from Y0/kiwami with barely any changes and just overall reusing minigames in Like a dragon games IMO is bad idea since most of them are "oh that's cool" things that overstay their welcome in the same games they featured in. This includes pocket circuit racing and it's annoying enough that they are mostly tied to substories and you have to play and beat them for Amon fight. I think if you reuse minigames, reusing it more than one time makes it extremely boring and just lazy. One thing I will say that they did good job on is hostess club. The fact they using FMV add to the experience and also they made it not grindy at all like in past titles. Don't even get me started on another fighting ring that's again is boring as hell and has substories tied to it so you must do it.

- The substories are extremely boring and uninspiring. Again, there are very few good ones but most of them are "THERES THIS GANG AROUND TOWN, BEAT THEM UP" and then after you do that "THERES ANOTHER RIVAL GANG, BEAT THEM UP" and that's like legit 75% of substories, just pure filler.

CONS
>They lied with the cabaret club "mini game" being a manager one

>combat progression focused too much on the new agent style

I still cannot recommend buying this at full price but a 15-20% sale is definitely worth it.

Like a Dragon Gaiden is a filler game starring the series protagonist Kazuma Kiryu. It explains what happened between Yakuza  6 where he went into hiding, to his unexplained surprise cameo appearances in Yakuza 7.

Despite being a smaller title than the rest, the game is filled with charms with modest game length. The new fighting mechanics is great and fans will notice the various throwbacks to the previous games here and there. Unlike previous game however, most of the game is set in Sotenbori and a new place called 'Castle', which function as a huge high end gambling dams and a Colosseum. Still there are lots of contents to go around and looking at how the Yakuza era ended from Kiryu's perspective is rather interesting.

The ending is one of the most emotional endings in this series, and it also leads into the opening to the next game: Like a Dragon Infinite Wealth. Although it is a gaiden story, I highly recommend it.

A quite short entry with probably the most managable 100% achievements in history of Yakuza saga (mostly because it doesn't require you to play mahjong for completion, don't worry though, mahjong is still included in the game).
To indirectly quote one of the comical substories - they really went balls out with this one. We get the marvelous, over-the-top combat with wacky special agent/007 style gadgets, which in my humble opinion culminated in the most memorable [spoiler]Amon[/spoiler] fight in the series.
The main story consists of five chapters, which together with requests (substories), colliseum and minigame completion required for 100% achievements take about 35 hours, possibly much shorter if you decide not to take your sweet time with it. After completing the final we get to play premium adventure mode which allows to experience all side content. There is no NG+ implemented (yet).
Once we finish the story we get the possibility to play the demo of Infinite Wealth. The transition from finale to story demo is quite smooth, but once the first combat starts one might realize how bittersweet this demo inclusion is. After hours of having a great time and silly fun with Gaiden's actual combat system we get... the JRPG turn-based combat. Of course it had some major revisions since release of the 7th installment, including combo attacks with party members, possibility to move around during combat (crazy, I know), and area of effect display for AoE skills and attacks. Those changes allow a much more tactical approach, but still walking away from the great active combat style to turn-based one is the saddest part of the series current direction.
So grab Like a Dragon Gaiden and enjoy the action combat, we Yakuza fans all know and love, in its possibly greatest display, as it may very well be the last time we get to see it.

Satisfying continuation of Kiryu's story, I love Yakuza 6, so this is a perfect  instalment for me. Story was very short, but sweet, dramatic, funny, interesting and overall emotional like the rest of the stories in this franchise. Gaiden introduced new characters, who became almost iconic to me, they fit into the world perfectly, are awesomely voiced/acted and they just feel like real people.
Side content wise, it is again stupid how many activities you can do. Fan favourite Pocket Circuit is back, still holds up to this day and it is enjoyable as hell. Substories are not weak at all, I was surprised in how many new situations main protagonist ends up in. Even a few nostalgic callbacks made an appearance. Playing a Yakuza game only for the main story is almost like not playing the game at all. Of course I need to mention customization: hat, glasses, clothes, rings, earrings, gloves, shoes, and so on, pure awesomeness.

Like the original title of the game tells us, it is a side story to Yakuza 7, don't expect Gaiden to have a nuclear impact on the whole franchise, but at the end, you will certainly tear up at least. Thanks to this game, I understand the story of Yakuza 7 more, Gaiden takes you behind the scenes and some things becomes clearer.
And combat was super awesome, you could maybe compare it to Lost Judgment. Great game, I can certainly recommend it to all players who want more of Kiryu Kazuma/Kuroda Takaya.

Set between 7 and 8, a conclusion to a certain bodyguard's story. The main story is very short relative to past games, so it is very obvious it is being padded out with Akame side content to slow down the progress. During the early parts it does not affect the pacing that much, but during late game the point requirements forces the player to do all the substories and minigames for points, on top of grinding for stupid amount of money in the Castle, to upgrade abilities.

The battle system is  like Judgement(two styles), one for solo and another for group. Classic battle style is good from the get go but Agent requires a lot of investment in abilities to become usable and eventually very fun. Suzuki Taichi's basic moves are greatly simplified in this entry so being able to call 20 drones to do the fighting instead is great to have. 

On the topic of fights, from a pure game play pov there are no memorable fights nor bosses in the mainline quest, maybe in a longer game there will be more time for character developments to hype things up, but boss fights are shockingly plain. Past entries you have some random guy that bust out the door with machine guns, and chainsaws, and some other . In this entry the most interesting boss is a dude wielding a tanto that gets knocked out before he can even show anything.....

Perhaps the most praiseworthy aspect of Y7.5 is the graphics. On a mid range set up I can max out every graphic setting and still run the game stable at 60fps. The lighting, assets, special effects and detailed character models looks amazing in most environment. Compared to Y7, it felt like there is a greater emphasis on uping the saturation and contrasts to make cut-scenes more dramatic, sometimes it gets too dark to see any details on default gamma settings.

Overall: Amazing teaser for Y8, play it.

RGG Studio has truly outdone themselves with the Dragon engine. Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name truly highlights why the Dragon Engine is so good. The graphics in this game are top notch and this game is really well optimized in terms of PC performance requirements. I love that RGG Studio incorporated juggling into this title's gameplay like they did with Lost Judgment. It's really fun especially when switching between Agent Style and Yakuza style constantly. Continuing RGG Studio's long track record of great and memorable video game music, the soundtracks in this game are all very catchy and enhance the experience greatly. I also enjoyed the variety of the minigames in this title. While not my favorite set of minigames out of all RGG Studio games, I still had a blast playing through all of them, with the Coliseum being my personal favorite as it allows you to play as any character available in the Coliseum which is a first for the series!

The new cast of characters introduced in this title were all a delight to watch from start to finish. Despite the shorter runtime in comparison to other RGG Studio games, this title's story is just as focused and even more engaging than some of RGG Studio's other titles. In fact, this title made me really empathized with Kiryu even further and I really love this game's conclusion. I would recommend to play this game after Yakuza 6 and then Yakuza: Like a Dragon to truly enjoy this game's story to the fullest.

After finishing this game I can say that this was more than just an after thought for Kiryu and his story after 6, it feels like this was genuinely made to be from the start of 3. The amount of references to many of the games in the series along with meeting certain people from a certain similar series, shows that they really wanted to solidify this game into the series.

I highly recommend playing this only if you've experienced the game Yakuza: Like a Dragon and the games before, since many of the events that take place in this are related to key events of that game.

The combat feels more polished than what Kiryu was left with in 6, making him feel the best he's been since Yakuza Kiwami. Agent Style adds a new feel to the game, akin to hack and slashes with the way Kiryu mows through crowds of enemies using his new Spider gadget. Yakuza Style felt like a lite version of Kiryu's iconic Dragon style, which isn't bad since it is taking the backseat for Agent Style.

The game definitely feels like one you should complete in one playthrough, since the length isn't as long as the other titles in the series. The game starts off with many cutscenes, but you'll start to see more and more things unlock as it goes on. You'll be doing yourself a disservice if you rush through the game, as you won't get the most bang for your buck. The game has so much to offer with it's coliseum mode. It gives us a chance to experience the game outside of the main Yakuza cast. Not to mention if you beat the game, you can play the trial of the next game in the series.

Overall, the story alone was enough to keep me involved, but the substories and the new content kept me wanting to play more. Real Yakuza play Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name

Didn't think I was gonna even buy this game, did it anyways. Wasn't sure if I was gonna enjoy it all that much, and I really did anyways. To start off, for newcomers/those who just started with 7, I don't think you should start with this game. RGG did say that this game is sort of tailored towards those starting with 7 to get a better understanding of Kiryu before Infinite Wealth comes out and he returns to the spotlight, but there's enough nostalgia bait in this game (particularly in the substories) to where I believe that it is best enjoyed after playing through the rest of the series. But if the length of the series seems too daunting (because it is), then there's nothing wrong with playing this after just 7 maybe.

For the story itself, it's unique in that it's not the most recent game in the timeline, rather being set at the same time as 7. As the trailers and price tag explained, it's the shortest mainline game in the series. So you would think that hey, we know what's supposed to happen by the end of the game, and we know that they don't have as long of a story to dive that deep into the plot either. So why should play it? And although the story may seem "safe" in some regards, it is still nonetheless a very enjoyable one. It does suffer from the RGG signature early game slog, but the payoff is more than worth it. If we're talking about a proper sendoff for Kiryu, then this game does a much better job at doing so as compared to 6 (although I enjoyed that story as well).

The main selling point for me personally coming into this game was the combat. And with 2 extra games of experience (thank you Judgment series) it feels like this game's combat is a true redemption for Kiryu in the Dragon Engine. RGG has perfected the real time combat for this engine, and playing the DoD style from K2 and 6 (which were pretty meh experiences) and it being so enjoyable here nearly brought tears to my eyes. I also liked how different the agent style was, with it's faster moves and the gadgets of course. The scale of the fights are also bigger in the literal sense, with many group fights (even random encounters) having close to 10 or more enemies at once. Some may find this as a negative (and it did get a bit tiring at one point) but nonetheless I can still say that Gaiden may have my personal favorite combat in the series.

I only just finished the game so I can't talk much about the side content in terms of minigames. The main two parts of side content are the Akame Network and the Castle and its Coliseum. For these two I have both pros and cons. The rewards from the Akame Network are pretty good in this game, and my main choice for grinding out money. However, I am still a bit on the fence about the Akame Network itself, being a spiritual successor/replacement for The Florist (and the Castle replacing Purgatory). I do wish that there were actually substories you can chance upon randomly, rather than them all being from the Network. The format of each substory also felt a bit more toned down, with a lot more straightforward "turns out he's the bad guy and now we fight" rather than the series' signature goofy shenanigans. This in turn kinda bored me out in grinding them, which sucks because there are a lot of substories requiring previous ones to be completed meaning that I was not able to do them. Maybe I missed out on some of the best ones, who knows.

The Coliseum in this game is pretty damn fun, and I think it's super cool that you can play as any member of your clan. It's the reason why I preordered rather than wait a bit after release, because I wanted to get the DLC and play as some past favorites. Of course their combat is ripped straight out of the previous games with little touchup (so Majima is still awful to play as), but given there's so many new fighting styles you get to use (with most of them being ripped from previous bosses in the series), I can't complain that much.

Overall, Gaiden really surprised me by becoming one of my personal favorites in the series. The visuals and sound are fantastic, with the Castle of course being the highlight in terms of areas. Such a colorful and chaotic mess that I need to spend more hours in to truly enjoy. It's a bit sad to hear that RGG is probably moving away from the Dragon Engine, as it only just feels like they have perfected it. There are some weird omissions from this game, such as NG+, Legend difficulty (although I think the professional difficulty was a good enough challenge), and no premium adventure without beating the game. All signatures of the series, hoping that the future entries bring them back. Also no "Real Yakuza use a gamepad" before the title screen bring that back please lol.

One last thing to note, the finale of this game is really damn good. As in like, best final boss in the series good. Character, presentation, and difficulty were all made to perfection, chef kiss. And after all that badassery it still managed to give some really emotional moments, and I was indeed crying towards the end. For a game so short, a DLC-turned standalone entry pumped out in 6 months, it's incredible how I think this might be one of my top 3 Yakuza games. Please play this game.

While I enjoyed my time with this game, I feel that with a $50 price tag, 5-chapter story, and being mainly locked to Sotenbori there is not much to justify the price. For newcomers to the Yakuza series or those who haven't played Yakuza: Like A Dragon, this game may is not the best.

I specifically have issue with the story and pacing. I was hoping the story would be a little longer especially where there were time jumps or just small slideshows explaining how the story went. While I understand the game's relatively short development cycle (6 months according to a dev), it's easy to see in the lack of fleshed-out gameplay elements. Going into the game I was really hoping to [spoiler]go back to Yokohama and relive the battle between Kazuma Kiryu and Ichiban from Like A Dragon. Unfortunately this only talked about after a massive time jump.[/spoiler] Even an appearance by [spoiler]Ichiban as a Castle opponent[/spoiler] would have been satisfying.

I would recommend the game only if you've played Yakuza: Like a Dragon AND have played most of the other Kiryu games. It effectively explains Kazuma Kiryu's whereabouts and his appearance in Yakuza: Like a Dragon. The ending is particularly well done, then transitions into the upcoming Like A Dragon: Infinite Wealth game and bundled demo for it.

I do like what's been done with the Castle and think the system could integrate a lot more battles and opponents to make it interesting. To get some of the achievements and skills in the game, you effectively need to grind battles over and over again which loses it's charm pretty quick.

Overall, I think this game exists to ease you into the Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth game coming out next year. It does an OK job at explaining the side of Kazuma Kiryu during the events of Yakuza: Like a Dragon but most of the payoff comes from the ending. However, I would hesitate to recommend this game to casual fans of the series or newcomers. I do not think $50 is a good price for the game ESPECIALLY since you can get Yakuza 0, Yakuza Kiwami, and Yakuza Kiwami 2 for $18 in a bundle right now.
https://store.steampowered.com/bundle/13660/The_Yakuza_Bundle/

Despite this being a smaller-scale endeavor for this series, I've not only found myself investing more time in its side content and intricacies, but enjoyed doing so more as well. The combat is the most fresh it has felt in years and the visual style is at its most stunning.

Kiryu's story after the events of Yakuza 6 is something I always wondered and I am satisfied with that I got, the story is good, it takes place during the events of Yakuza: Like a Dragon so do note that you might encounter some spoilers for that game down the line. The game is short, yes, it only has 5 chapters, but there's load of other side missions and stories that sort of make up for its length. 

The combat is also good, it ain't perfect, but it's fun as heck once you get used to it. The Agent and Yakuza style are good, but both have their ups and downs. From my experience the Agent style is best when dealing with the group of enemies, meanwhile Yakuza style is good for one on one encounters. 

The agent style introduces gadgets that are fun to use and are pretty solid for most part, though upgrading them should be one of the priorities, at least to level 2. 

The Yakuza style is good old fashion brawler style Kiryu pretty much used through out his games, you get to unlock all of the classics, like Tiger Drop- which to this day is still one of the best skills to use.

Overall, while this game is shorter than most games, it gives us enough content to satisfy until Infinite Wealth releases.

After playing all Yakuza/Like a Dragon games that are available on Steam, I can't say either this is a must play or a skippable entry.

Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name takes place in parallel to Yakuza Like A Dragon (Like a Dragon 7) and you play as Kazuma Kiryu (now using a fake name "Joryu"), the classic protagonist of the series. Planned as a DLC package for Like a Dragon 8 Infinite Wealth, Gaiden is shorter than most entries and feel like a lot of its parts are made with less budget and time.

That being said, this is still a very entertaining game from RGG. These guys know how to make the most out of a small open world and the grounded setting. Plenty of minigames, progressions, and side stories that are worth sinking your time into, not only because they're fun and have depths beyond the surfaces, but they also give you resources to unlock upgrades for Joryu in combat. And trust me, you'd want to have some upgrades.

The combat system in Gaiden is somewhere between Judgement, Lost Judgement, and Yakuza 5. Joryu has 2 fighting styles, Yakuza and Agent. Agent is a brand-new style to the series, it focuses on fast and long combo string, 3 consecutive side-stepping, and sci-fi gadgets like drones, Spider Man web wires, rocket-powered shoes, and cigarette bombs. Yakuza is a combination of Dragon Engine Kiryu's Dragon of Dojima style and some moves from his older games. Yakuza style's attack speed can feel quite slow, but not overly clunky like Yakuza 6, similar to Judgement. This game also features enemy-juggling, which was first seen in Judgement and streamlined in Lost Judgement. Joryu's combat rhythm and capabilities can open up even the stronger foes for some nasty juggling combo. While juggling and gadgets sound fun and powerful, enemy AI in Gaiden seem tampered to be more aggressive and opportunistic in their strikes. Lost Judgement (the latest Dragon Engine game) seemed to have AI's that are afraid to hit the player and often leave you alone while you combo attacks either regularly or while juggling. Meanwhile Gaiden's enemy AI doesn't care where you are in the arena or what you're doing, they will try to hit you and get you off a combo. So most of the time while you're fighting multiple foes, you'll have to utilize everything to create yourself some space or dispatch the weaker enemies quickly. The Heat mechanic also returns, but it is nerfed pretty harshly. The Heat bar that allows you to use Heat actions or activate Extreme Heat goes up rather slowly in Gaiden. So, either you have to stock up on heat-regenerating items or use it very sparingly, either way you cannot spam it like in the older games.

[b] The reason why I can't say this is a must-play [/b] is highly dependent on a player's investment to the series. I'd say that if you only played 1 or 2 Kiryu games, then Gaiden wouldn't be as worthy to you. But if you're invested in the series, the story, the gameplay, and universe, I'd say this is a must-play, implying you haven't played it already. This game tells a very interesting and emotion part of Kiryu's life story but not necessarily required to enjoy future or older games.

One more thing I find weird (and noticed when it got worse) in this game is the lighting. Most RGG games are fine with their lighting, even with Kiwami 1&2's green filter, scenes from those game don't look out of place and offer a consistent imagery experience throughout each one. But Gaiden has a focus on darker shadows and overall color level contrast of the image. This might be to some people's preference but I just find it a bit jarring. Seeing bright particle effects over a dimly lit environment, while contact and cast shadows are sometimes too dark and sometimes too bright that they don't seem to exist, threw me off from the experience a bit. Some scenes nailed the high-contrast lighting perfectly, such as the prologue scene with blue and red lights on each side and the shadows are dark and threatening. While some scenes like the final boss fight has less detailed lighting, overly reliant on baked and static textures and colors. It's a good game for screenshots sometimes, but not most of the time imo.

I still give it a 7.5/10, a good Yakuza game, through and through. Even with shortcomings from short development time and branding as a side-game, it still offers a completed Yakuza experience through good story, memorable characters, cool set-pieces, abundant side activities, soundtracks, and satisfying combat system.

I liked this game but it is horribly overpriced for what you actually get. Short story with a lot of filler at the start and about 5 actual substories that have any thought put into them, the rest being menial tasks that have hardly any substance. 

They also seem to have regressed in the combat department, it is very clunky and unresponsive, and I hate with a passion that you have to press X to toggle run even in combat. This was a completely braindead decision by the developers. There are a lot of design decisions that I just do not understand. The agent style's most developed gadget, the spider, being that it is the only one with any actual abilities tied to it, does not even work on boss fights in any capacity. The agent style just feels kinda useless in boss fights in general, and the clunky controls do not help at all. The gadgets feel underdeveloped in general, it would've been nice to have some heat moves tied to them, like one where you rush towards the enemy using the rocket boots could've been pretty entertaining. It feels like there aren't many heat moves in general really. The yakuza style doesn't feel great also, but I feel like it's more of a problem because of how the enemy AI works. You have a lot of charge attacks you can use but the enemies seem to block and dodge more often than in the other games, barring maybe Yakuza 3, and they completely block charge attacks, so you can be mid combo and want to go for a charge attack and they will just go into a block and completely negate it. It's fun at times but there's been much better combat in the series and you'd think they'd try to improve it every game, but it seems to go up and down.

I enjoyed the story itself but for the first few hours I was pretty bored. I enjoyed the intro but then I just didn't really care for much of what happened until you [spoiler] rescue Hanawa [/spoiler]. The tutorials and introductions to systems were just not interesting and more grating than they are in the other games. However it does get pretty decent later on, with a nice finale that leaned into 7 quite well. I also think the ending has one of the best scenes in the series.

Like A Dragon Gaiden is a fantastic addition to the Yakuza/Like A Dragon series, serving as a compelling bridge between Yakuza 6 and Yakuza: Like A Dragon.

The story, while predictable, is engaging and well-executed. It may not surprise you with unexpected twists if you have played Yakuza: Like A Dragon, but it delivers a satisfying narrative that fits perfectly within the established Yakuza timeline.

One of the highlights of the game is the reworked move set for Kiyru. The developers have done an excellent job refining his moves from Yakuza 6 and Kiwami 2.

And of course, it wouldn't be a Yakuza game without its unique style. Like A Dragon Gaiden delivers on this front, offering all the charm, humor, and eccentricity we've come to love from the series.

Like A Dragon Gaiden is a must-play for any Yakuza fan. It may be a short story, but it's a great one that adds depth to the overall saga.

Wow, for being a "shorter" side game in RGG's eyes, this game is a complete and worthwhile package. Absolutely incredible game and a perfect installment to the Yakuza/LAD series for longtime fans. Gaiden is definitely the kind of follow up I desired after Y6 and Y7. ESPECIALLY Y6.

It follows up perfectly on Y6's ending, and really does feel like an important companion piece and closure on a game whose ending is kinda controversial. This game makes a ton of callbacks and connections to previous games across the series with good emotional payoffs, if you've played Kiryu's saga, this game ABSOLUTELY hits like a pink truck.

Normally, most RGG games don't require you playing any prequels, but you'd definitely miss out on a lot of emotional hits if you haven't played Kiryu's games. Not to say it's required, but I feel like this game does a lot that draws on previous games that would be lost on someone starting only with this game.

Also, this game has big spoilers for both Y6's and Y7's endings. Definitely would recommend playing at least Y7 prior.

This game's combat is hella fun, the new Agent style took a bit of getting used to, but omg when it's upgraded more it's definitely fun as fuck. Yakuza style is the best version of the DoD style in the Dragon Engine we've gotten.

The side content is pretty great too. Kinda liked the fact that this was a smaller game. I actually finished every substory and coliseum fight. Even beat the hard super boss fight, which is awesome. Never done that before in a LaD/Yakuza game.

The main story is definitely short, they definitely weren't joking that it was a shorter game. BUT, it has some of the coolest action set pieces and moments I've seen in a Yakuza game. I took, SO, SOOO many screenshots during the course of this game.

The final boss's sequence was actually perfect. Like, the perfect boss, ideology, set pieces, to send off Kiryu's final chapter (as the stand alone sole protagonist). It somehow equals or tops Y5's for me, which is no small feat. 

Might be the best final boss of the main series.

Also, the ending absolutely emotionally destroys you. It hurts so bad. (But in a good way)

Gaiden feels like a capstone piece to everything that Kiryu is as a person by current day. Huge fanservice game, great connections, tie ins, callbacks, and paving the way for the future.

One thing that grinds my gear about the franchise since LAD is that RGG Studio, in an attempt to deepen players' engagement with side content, tried to fuse them into the main storyline one way or the other. For LAD, it was one particular huge difficulty curve introduced in a boss fight that was supposed to be solved by grinding an "optional" ladder tower, and the job system whose biggest fault was simply being unbalanced. For Lost Judgment, in order to finish the school stories to their fullest (which, while are totally detached from the main storyline, felt very much like the second most important piece of narrative in the game), you have to suffer through some of the worst minigames ever introduced in this series so far. This catering-to-completionist design mythos is one I've always been mixed on, and I was hoping that RGGS actually takes time to flesh out the more player-oriented mechanics instead of forcing mediocre minigames on us in order to access the best narrative pieces of the game.

And I guess LAD Gaiden is meant to be the answer to that? This 20 hours trip through Sotenbori - historically the smallest and most structurally simplistic city in Yakuza, lasts 5 chapters where the story probably could have been told within 6 hours at most, while the rest of the game acts more like a reintroduction to the city which hasn't been a big focus point since Kiwami 2 and probably will play a role in the third Judgment installment. Gone are the substories that you encounter naturally just by roaming the streets, now they are presented as jobs given by your fixer, a mechanic lifted directly from Judgment's request board. Next to those are the fetch quests/menial tasks that contribute to Akame Network's progression bars and level number. Everything seemingly feeds into another positive feedback loop where the more money, xp and funny looking numbers you earn, the more benefits Kir- I mean Joryu gains. You have much more agency here compared to LAD, no pressure to grind mindless fights, no moment where I found myself being forced to do anything I disliked. 

Even with a better approach towards quantity/quality balance, the act of completing side content remains hampered by a few legacy design decisions. The unnecessary menus where you can't take more than one sub story at once and have to talk to Akame to hear her exposition on the situation.every.fucking.time came off as the most egregious to me. Sotenbori's simplistic layout and bland atmosphere turned exploration into pure boredom after 10 hours of playtime, and the new slingshot gadget that let Joryu grab objects out of reach, while is a nice touch, never got its usability expanded outside of combat and can be safely tossed into "one-off shallow mechanic" bin that includes Lost Judgment's parkour. Despite all those relatively mild weak points, LAD Gaiden easily beat out the two last main installments by simply ending the journey before the game itself got obnoxious.

Gaiden's combat shines again, and RGGS even threw in a fighting arena to please players thirsty for brawler bloodshed, an aspect that Lost Judgment did well yet had very little space to unleash due to extremely low combat difficulty. Sadly, the new combat gadgets like drones, explosive cigarettes, and the sling don't spice up Joryu's combat as much as I thought due to imprecise control and extreme heat mode being way too overpowered to the point it thwarted even the best combat moves in the game. Power fantasy catharsis remains high thanks to the much higher number of enemies in each pack which feels like... a Dragon Engine capabilities flex at this point, and hopefully RGGS can polish some leftover kinks to make brawler combat even smoother to engage with in the future.

For fans, the mysterious premise is of course Gaiden's biggest selling point. The main storyline is actually pretty uninteresting and predictable here due to various factors: the Daidoji being painted as a morally ambiguous shadowy organization that feels too mustache-twirling cartoonish in its way of operation to be believable, the two main antagonists are surprisingly cookie cutter in their personality and writing with the only saving grace being their excellent acting performances; the story once again gave Kiryu an easy way out in its midpoint climax and almost became a soap opera. The overall storytelling lacked some of the harsh edges from the Judgment series, or the elegant gut punches that's been a staple in Yakuza's writing since 0, but it nicely filled in some of the missing pieces that led to Kiryu's appearance in LAD which I guess is the whole point of the game. On the bright side, Gaiden introduced some of the most likable allies in the franchise, alongside an ending that both hit you like a spaceship and, strangely enough, teased a continuation of Yakuza 5's unsolved threads. I DON'T NEED SLEEP, I NEED ANSWERS.

While I came off Gaiden somewhat mixed, overall this is still strictly a game for fans and more of a companion piece to LAD and Infinite Wealth first and foremost, so it's easy to chalk it off as an engine experiment for bigger scale combat and preparing side characters for the next installments. Can be placed somewhere in the middle of the pack, not bad but also not very memorable outside of the cast and the ending. Kaito Files still holds the crown for budget short story here.

Definitely one of the best Yakuza games in my eyes, but probably one of the worst to start with. With no context I think a lot of this might not really hit and at this point, this story is built upon half a dozen games worth of narrative and it's so satisfying to experience it if you've played all the other games. It's chock full of fan service for the earlier games and really hits all the spots you wanted Yakuza 6 to hit, it's a far more personal game for Kiryu and really focuses on him as a character and has some of the best cinematography in the series, so many of the shots are gorgeous and the choreography and spectacle of the fight scenes are great.

This iteration of the arena is so much fun, my only complaint is that I wish there was a bit more content to it because it's so addicting but can be cleared pretty quickly excepting a few of the very high end matches which require pretty set strategies. The team hell rumble matches especially, are brilliant. I loved collecting random characters from the other games and engaging in a massive chaotic brawl with them, gangster pokemon is always fun to engage in with yakuza games. You've got Mr Masochist, Gary Buster Holmes and Sodachi here, just to name a few. 

The new agent style is fun to use, but sadly I found it to be entirely overshadowed by how obscenely overpowered yakuza style is, but it remains very useful for thinning out large crowds. The store pages says you should adapt your style to the situation but you don't really need to... Kiryu has always been a bit of a monster, but he does SO. MUCH. DAMAGE with yakuza mode, especially in extreme heat mode and as a result I found this to be by far the easiest game. It is very satisfying to channel spider-man and definitely non-lethally throw some street thugs into the river though. Jetpack loafers are also good, albeit a bit clunky to use like the bomb cigarette, but it always remained a quirky random style to use for a change rather than a must-use.

I also think this had some of the best acting in the series. Kiryu has always been a very stoic character but his actor really got to show off what an incredible range he has here. The entire ending sequence was so well done.[spoiler]LET THIS MAN SEE HIS CHILDREN AND GRANDCHILD[/spoiler]

Gaiden relies a lot on Kiryu's past, so a little bit of warning it has all sorts of minor and major spoilers from many games, and also spoilers of the one that happens alongside with it, so do be aware of that. WIth all that said, I was not ready at all for how hard this story would go, main story doesn't beat any longer than maybe 10-12-ish hours but they still manage to pack a whole lot of drama and feelings into this one small package, all of the new characters are memorable, and obviously some good old Kiryu coolness as we love it

Combat throws back to the hack'n slash formula, bringing Kiryu a bit of Judgment influence which is great. Agent style is nimble and tactical, full of gadgets and technical combat, and the Yakuza style brings back the street fighting dragon, full of heavy power and strong strikes. You can't go wrong with either style honestly, both have their unique shine in the right time, combos feel awesome

Side content also goes hard, the Coliseum is the big attraction of this game and the main moneymaker, spending time here experimenting with teams and even playing other characters is mighty fun. Akame Network is quite bulky and important to upgrade abilities, the return of Pocket Circuit is a welcome funsies add, show your charm for the girls in the Cabaret Clubs (this time in live action), visit the Boutique to customize Kiryu's clothes and face, and of course all the usual gambling and sports minigames are present as well. Also, big props for bringing an arcade of Sega Racing Classic 2 (renamed out of Daytona USA 2 due to licensing), that's a first ever PC/console release for that game and I was really excited for it

Dragon Engine had great graphical ugprades, more specifically to lighting, reflections and colors, everything is so much more atmospheric and colorful I love it, and once you have a taste of the Infinite Wealth demo you can tell they meticulously upgraded these departments thinking of this game to deliver a very lively and colorful Honolulu, definitely the peak in graphics for the series

And speaking of, Like a Dragon Infinite Wealth Special Trial is an extra gift you earn after beating the main story of Gaiden, packing a short story demo and an exploration demo, it's similar to the same event demo you've seen a few times on youtube but here with even more content and no time restrictions (thankfully!). Needless to say this game is looking and feeling awesome, I could fill another half-review with how many cool details it has but you've read a lot of text at this point already. Can't wait for it now, fueled my hype that was already skyrocketed

Gaiden only has one DLC. Not a huge impact in this one it's more for fanservice funsies, you get three legendary yakuza for the coliseum, obviously they're awesome and strong but if you want to spare some money it's okay, not that much to be lost in terms of content

After you beat the game you can still enjoy Premium Adventure as you always do in the series, but Gaiden unexplainably lacks New Game+ for you to replay the story carrying over your abilities. My theory is that it maybe just maybe could have to do with how Akame Network works, but it's just a silly little theory of mine we never really got word on why's NG+ just missing, but yeah that has to be my only big complaint about this game

[b] To finish this, I want to thank RGG for yet another fantastic release and also make a wish here: a wish that they realize how far Dragon Engine has reached and how great it feels and looks now, please give it some extra thought before moving to Unreal guys, you have a fantastic proprietary engine in your hands. WIth all that said, Gaiden was such a blast, even in a shorter spin-off package they still deliver top quality content as always, and I can't even wait for Infinite Wealth now, crazy how we're just two months shy of it [/b]

100% Steam achievements with 38 hours clocked. I had a great time with Gaiden and loved almost everything about it but I just wanted to quickly highlight the very few things that I didn't like:

1) Akame is a great character but ranking up her network often felt like boring busywork which was clearly designed to pad out the runtime of what is a fairly short game. This is especially true of the requests that require you to run all over the map talking to various NPC's placed on opposite ends of the map or fighting groups of gangs scattered across town. These were definitely a chore to get through and they frankly don't do anything for the overall experience. The substories were great though.

2) I wasn't a fan of the live-action hostesses at the cabaret clubs. They felt awkward and forced and frankly unsettling. I had to power through those by skipping through every scene. Fingers crossed they never bring that back.

3) JUSTICE - the Third King bossfight found in the Colosseum - is completely scuffed. Anyone here who has fought him knows exactly what I mean. Not even Amon comes close to the level of bullshit and unfairness found in this fight, almost to the point where I can't quite believe it was intended to be this way. I guess time will tell. In any case, this was the lowest point of the game for me and the only time when I felt frustrated and angry while playing Gaiden. 

Other than that I universally loved everything else. The game is short by RGG standards but by every means sweet and the story is up there with the best this studio have made. I'm more excited than ever for Infinite Wealth and I'm desperately hoping that Kiryu gets the ending we all know he deserves to have.

Kazuma Kiryu returns in a story that bridges the ending of Yakuza 6: The Song of Life with Yakuza: Like A Dragon (Yakuza 7) and the upcoming Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth (Yakuza 8)
Having finished, here's a breakdown of Likes, Dislikes, and Your Mileage May Vary's:
Pros:
- Brawler combat is back, and so is style switching
- Agent style's gadgets are fun when you get the hang of them
- Coliseum is a lot of fun, and you can play as other characters besides Kir- I mean Joryu
- Story does a great job of bridging 6- Like a Dragon- Infinite Wealth
- Great emotional beats
- Final boss goes so hard
- Infinite Wealth demo is included
- Lots of minigames
- Small things, like the "in-engine cutscenes" (that you can skip with the X/A button) feel much more "cinematic"

Cons:
- YongYea's English Kiryu... not good (from the IW demo. Maybe his Gaiden performance will be better?)
- Some frame drops in the Castle. Also, you can't use your phone camera there? (This restriction is lifted sometime in Chapter 4 due to story events)
- Combat feels like somewhat of a downgrade to Lost Judgment's fluid and fast combat
- You can't change outfits at Akame's office or in the menu-- you have to go to the Castle and do it at the Boutique
-No New Game Plus!!!

YMMVs:
- Story is much shorter than a traditional Yakuza/Like a Dragon game since this was initially planned as DLC for Infinite Wealth before being developed as an interquel
- Not as many skills for both styles for what I was expecting
- DLSS at 1080p makes the game either looked oversharpened or too smooth. Might just be my hardware though (DLSS at 1080p is a no-go)

For $50 this game is a scam, straight up. This feels more in line with $20 DLC than a nearly full priced release. The only new things in this game are the story(which didn't grab me at all and just felt random even for this series), the secret agent fighting style, and a singular new area that turns out to be a tiny location thats only home to some gambling minigames and the arena. 99% of the game actually takes place in Sotenbori and it's exactly the same as it was in Kiwami 2. Some old minigames we haven't seen in a while, like Pocket Circuit, are back and while it is nice to have them back they are just exactly the same as before. The arcade game selection is pretty choice as well, Daytona 2 rules and Fighting Vipers 2 is cool as well. Paired with Sonic the Fighters, Motor Raid and VF2(wish it was swapped for VF3)all returning its a solid line up. 

Unfortunately the biggest dropped ball here is substories. There are hardly any. Instead they decided to put about a hundred random fetch quests of zero substance all over the map. Give a guy a random food item, pick up kids lost ball thats mere inches away, etc. Many of these do not even reward you in any way either other than filling up a sidequest experience bar that you can get a poultry amount of money from once you fill it and level up. There is a very small number of "real" substories but even those do not satisfy. You have to activate them all manually at your base first, where you're then given a run down of whats going on without actually interacting with any of the characters they pertain to, then you just go to where they are on the map, get a little more dialogue and context (if you're lucky), fight and its done. None of them are particularly memorable or funny, but are inoffensive and would all be considered "low-tier" in a real Yakuza game that usually has 70+ substories where its more acceptable that not every single one was a knock out. These few substories are quite literally all this game has outside of the insanely short main story so the poor execution and quality of them are immensely disappointing. Had they just ditched all of the nonsense and just made 50 or so classic substories, it could have saved this game and helped make it feel more worth the asking price.

Just about the only positives I have are the new secret agent fighting style and the combat in general. The whip is a lot of fun to use and the explosive cigarettes are absolutely chaotic in small spaces. The drones suck and are worthless though. I know not everyones not a fan of the Dragon Engine combat but I have a lot of fun with it and its no different here. The final boss was great too, awesome choreography and a comical amount of healthbars.

Somewhat unrelated to the game but I'd figure I would mention, the performance on PC is yet again worse than previous games. I really don't understand why but these games have very steadily been running worse and worse with each release despite running on the exact same engine and taking place in the exact same cities and reusing all of the same assets. I have a 3090ti and an i912900Ks. Kiwami 2(which is just about the exact same game as this) and 6 both ran at 4K native and a mostly steady 120FPS maximum settings on my machine. Judgment ran a smidge worse hitting about 80-90FPS and Lost Judgment ran considerably worse barely able to even hit 60FPS most of the time. Unfortunately this game runs like Lost Judgment does just scraping by at 60FPS. DLSS does help tremendously but Ive never been able to fully ignore the smudging and occasional artifacts it introduces, and I shouldn't need it anyway, these games are all literally identical in engines and assets, there is genuinely no reason they should be running worse than they did before.

Overall I wouldn't spend more than $20 on this game, and even then it still wouldn't be all that great anyway. The fact that you can buy just about the entire back catalog of this franchise 0-6 for about the same price(often even less when theyre on sale) as this nothingburger of a game is pretty embarrassing. Each of those is easily 100+ hours if you go for completion and are simply better quality games. Sega really needs to do better because I haven't enjoyed an entry in this franchise since the first Judgment game in 2019.

I would like to begin by summarizing my history of the Yakuza franchise. Being a Yakuza fan, I enjoyed Yakuza 0 and thought Yakuza: Like A Dragon was a masterpiece. But I wasn't particularly fond of Yakuza 1-6. Among my reasons are dull gameplay, repetitive game and level design in every game, similar stories with ridiculous plot twists, boring main characters (excluding Akiyama), same map in each game etc. As you might have guessed, I've had issues with the repetitive nature of this series. I considered the Yakuza series the Call of Duty of the East, even though Yakuza is much better in almost every aspect. But Yakuza: Like a Dragon changed it all for me. Thankfully, the combat system had changed completely. It was extremely well made and we got a main character with actual feelings and one who displayed them. Ichiban is such a likable character and I enjoyed seeing him as the protagonist dearly. I completed Yakuza LaD 100% for the first time in a Yakuza game. That's how much I love the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3080309736

After all this positive work from Ryu Ga Gotoku Studios, I had high hopes about this game, so I pre-ordered it. I feel sorry to report that this is a game with the same formula as Yakuza 1-6 and I didn't enjoy most of it. A generic plot with characters that I am never going to remember after beating the game, predictable plot twists, and an undercooked villain. I mostly have no issues with the feel of the combat (except Yakuza 3) but this one feels kinda off. I cannot put my finger on it. One of the selling points of the game, the new "agent combat style" looks fun, but sadly is very weak compared to the "yakuza style", so I barely played the new style. They couldn't adjust the balance between them.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3079834442

Let me move on to the positives of Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name. The most important topic of the game: Yes, the cabaret club is very fun just like the previous ones. This one's slightly better because they made it live-action this time. Secondly, I can see that most of RGG's effort has gone into creating the castle. Yeah, the castle looks amazing and has cool stuff in it to spend time with. The graphics are getting better with every game. The interiors look extremely good, but the outdoor graphics need a little bit more work. I won't go into spoilers, but I just cannot skip that finale scene when Kiryu was holding a tablet. Phenomenal scene. It made me tear up! I hope it results in something beautiful for Kiryu in the next game. That sums up the positives of this game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3084505410

Unfortunately, the best point of the game is the playable Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth Trial after you beat the main game. During that hour, I had an absolute blast and it's barely visible that LaD 8 is their focus and this is only a cash grab. Dear SEGA, I know the main reason you made this game was to please Kiryu and the Brawler fans out there, other than making an extra 50 bucks per purchase, of course. But please just let Kiryu and this dated combat system alone. Because it surely doesn't work anymore for me. People will get used to turn-based combat. Look at Baldur's Gate 3 for an example. Just keep doing amazing RPGs after Like a Dragon 8 as well. I am immensely excited about that game!

Game is much shorter than other entries (finished in 27 hours having done most but not all of substories) in terms of both play time and game scope, but it has what is probably the most emotional ending out of all the entries I've played. The payoff is certainly better than what Yakuza 6 attempted to do, and it also ties into Like a Dragon (Yakuza 7) very nicely.

Combat-wise, spoiler alert, bicycle meta is back. You improve skills by spending money so you want to get through street encounters as soon as possible, and the fastest way to do so is to swing around bicycles. I mentioned the same thing in my Yakuza 6 review; you want to buy the best skills? Time to swing those bikes! It helps to say "eat this" whenever you hit someone with it. Also one of the few games where you can get Tiger Drop relatively early (just ¥3,000,000; do Pocket Circuit a lot and exchange their PP points for Platinum Plates and you'll be good; or you can also get a lot of money from the Coliseum too). The timing on Tiger Drop is very precise; you must hit the button right before their attack lands so it's high risk high reward, but if you pull it off, it's very satisfying and can trivialise any bosses.

In terms of polish, this game is a strange mix bag. The combat is very polished and smooth, but there are very odd design decisions:
1. Many of your side quests must be started by talking to Akame instead of being discovered naturally or by visiting a question mark on the mini-map. As a result, I'd recommend just picking up all the available side quests at once and then work on them.
2. Game actually runs much smoother on my aging PC and graphics card than Yakuza 7: Like a Dragon. I think it's just optimised much better.
3. The cabaret club is a nice change but I'm not sure I like it. They call it "immersive" cabaret club because they actually use FMV but I honestly would have preferred if they had spent the resources on actually bringing back the cabaret hostess club minigame from Yakuza 0 and Yakuza Kiwami 2.
4. Pocket Circuit is back!
5. You can customise your usual as well as your fighting outfit, leading to the trademark (and hilarious) juxtaposition of a serious scene with you dressing up with literal clown makeup. There are a few side quests that require you to wear specific outfit, but you can only change outfit by going to the Coliseum so that's quite a bore.

For all its flaws, I think it's a must-play for fans of the series who are itching for a non-turn-based-combat entry (please announce Judgement 3!).

The best way to describe Gaiden is that it's a greatest-hits compilation celebrating Kiryu Kazuma, the Dragon of Dojima.

While it's a rather short game, only comprising 5 chapters – it's a fun little jaunt that put you back into his shoes and reminds you just how great of a character Kiryu is. I personally think that this game respects Kiryu more than Y6, and truly has a sense of finality – which is funny given how Kiryu is present in the upcoming LAD: Infinite Wealth. Great callbacks, with Takaya Kuroda's incredible voice acting really showcasing just how much Kiryu has changed over the past 7 games.

Combat-wise, it's not as great as Lost Judgment. I'd put it slightly above the first Judgment, but it's still fun to beat up random dudes. This game shines in it's side-content, where I've spent majority of my playtime doing. That's not something I usually do in a Yakuza title, as I greatly enjoy the story content more, but Gaiden incentivizes you greatly for checking off that list, and I couldn't help but continuously support the Akame Network.

I'd rate it a solid 8/10. My only downside would be the humungous file size. I hope RGG puts out a patch to reduce the storage taken up by the Cabaret Club FMVs, and also consider making the LAD8 demo a separate download / DLC install. 98GB is too much space for a 15-30 hour bite-sized Like a Dragon game. I'm certain that Infinite Wealth will be much smaller than this when it comes out in January.

Graphics wise, DLAA and other reconstruction technologies are present and well, it beats not having them for sure. Otherwise, the graphics look like a small step up from Yakuza: Like a Dragon--Kasuga's game. Nothing particularly exciting nor modern. Some very weak areas still remain such as reflections barely looking recognizable in the slightest--I'd turn them off entirely if I could. 

The audio--at least in the Japanese track, I have no idea about the English--is great, overall quality is there for me. 

Performance wise, it's doing better on my hardware than say Kiwami 1 & 2 are, so I suppose they figured out some inefficiencies. I can easily lock 60 fps and hit my 120 hz max with everything cranked. I'm not experiencing any sort of stutters which, is special in 2023 for some reason.

If this is your first Yakuza Game (Like a Dragon is the name of the series in Japan), have fun! Though this game is primarily a brawler-style game, it throws our favorite karaoke singer Joryu into a wide variety of activities besides the street combat you'll find in the rest of the series. You could spend a lot of time on recreational activites Joryu himself may do, such as golf, board games, gambling, pit fighting (best way to grind cash in this game hint hint), and my personal favorite, singing Baka Mitai at the bar.

For those who have played Yakuza games before, this game uses the same engine as Yakuza 6 and Yakuza 2 Kiwami, making for seamless transitions between combat on the streets and roaming Sotenbori. The game devs allow you to progress the story at your pace, and they will give you ample warning when you are going to a long brawling segment (except for the Chapter 1 gauntlet, watch out), so you can either take time to do some other activities or prepare for the long battle. I would recommend doing the side activities, not only because they are fun and provide comedic relief to an otherwise dark story, but because you'll need them to strengthen Joryu's stats and abilities since the upgrade tree requires the currency the side content provides. 

I had a fun time with this game and made it through the story on Normal mode in 33 hours. Keep in mind that I did not go for 100% completion so this number could vary for you if you decide to pick the game up for yourself. 

PS: Start the game with Japanese VA's. The English VA for Joryu ... let's say that it leaves a lot to be desired.

An excellent RGG "side game" that I would say is good enough to, lower content aside, to stand with the series' best entries. Some bullet points to give you an idea of what's going on with this weird new Joryu guy:

[list]
[*]This game is much less focused on main campaign content, and more focused on side content. It's got less than half the campaign length of a regular RGG game, and even that's being a bit generous as a significant part of the main story is actually more like mandatory engagement with that side content. If you're like me, you can easily get 60h or more out of this if you like Yakuza minigames or the improved Colosseum, if you're just doing a one and done campaign this is more like ~20 hours. (maybe plus a few more if you want to play 8's included demo)

[*]This game is [b]not[/b] a good entry point for those new to the series, and isn't trying to be. This game was made for people who have played Yakuza 7, and are invested enough in the Kiryu Saga games that they want to know what he's been up to during the transition between Y6 and Y7. IMO Yakuza 0, or maybe Yakuza 7, are better starting points for anyone looking to try an RGG title.

[*]The updated combat is overall very fun and much better than some other Dragon Engine games like Kiwami 2 IMO. I don't think it's [i]as[/i] good as Lost Judgement but that's probably an unfairly high standard to clear. Joryu struggles to earn Heat, but makes up for it by being very good at opening enemies up to air juggling and having perhaps the strongest crowd control in the series' history.

[*]While the Yakuza combat style plays how you'd expect, Agent is a new moveset that gives Joryu a lot of crazy new tools. Some of its ideas, like the ranged grabbing wire are extremely useful tools you'll use often, but some other features like the Hornet drones don't feel anywhere near as useful. It's great for defense and crowd control and so always has a use, but I think most players will use Yakuza style as their default with Agent being a specialist style.

[*]The improved Colosseum is probably the best take on the feature we've ever seen. Besides the usual ability to quickly enjoy fights, you can also assemble a custom team of fighters for giant chaotic teamfights and, finally, play as said fighters to use their unique movesets and abilities normally reserved for NPCs. Because this is still a side game, it's not perfect. For example, Kaito only recycles Yakuza 0's Brawler moveset instead of his full Kaito Files moveset, and Higashi does not inherit his unique Muay Thai moveset from Judgement. But we do get some classics like the joke drunkard moveset, and overall a really fantastic way to make our own fun trying to become world champs with jobber characters. My only real criticism of the Colosseum is that some of its later Hell Team Rumble fights are a bit much, bloating HP to comical levels (seriously some of these enemies have like 50 health bars to work through) because their captains are balanced around requiring an entire levelled team of 10 people dogpiling attacks onto them like an MMO raid boss. Aside from that balancing complaint that only affects a small portion of the Colosseum's content (and will become less of an issue further and further into endgame stats) I think this is a huge highlight feature especially for longtime fans.

[*]Despite how relatively short this story is, it is [b]definitely[/b] worth the ride, for the ending alone, but even the stuff aside from that is extremely fun, especially the final boss.
[/list]

If you have any investment in Kiryu's story and can spare the price, (which is admittedly steep) you [b]really, really[/b] should play this.

This game is proof that RGG fans will eat any slop put in front of them. I want to forewarn everyone looking at negative reviews that this game is not HORRIBLE but isn't on par with the other titles in the franchise. This game should be DLC to Infinite Wealth, and is definitely NOT worth the 50$ price tag. Go buy Judgment or Lost Judgment instead if you don't already have them and want to scratch that kuza' itch. 

I think that the foundation of the Like a Dragon (Yakuza) franchise is that they basically get to reuse assets every two years, so long as they innovate and add to the world they've created. And this is fine. I love coming back to Kamurocho and in this case, Sotenbori, to see what is new. Players returning to new titles in the franchise expect new side content, new fighting styles (or characters), revamped areas of old maps, a beautiful story, and interesting characters to tell that story. While Gaiden does a good job of telling an easy to digest and pretty decent story, it falls flat virtually everywhere else. 

For starters, there isn't a single entirely NEW side activity added. Most of them are just remixed or slightly inferior versions of what we had in earlier entries to the series. I don't think Pocket Circuit needs to see more light-of-day than it has already gotten. (Unless it's made like, substantially different or somehow more entertaining.) I have to say, I enjoyed it a lot in Yakuza 0 because it was my first time experiencing the Circuit racer. But the reason I skipped it in Gaiden is the same reason I skipped it in 6. I just don't feel like it anymore. I already dumped six hours into collecting and racing parts in 0. It no longer entices me, and the last time I played it was over two years ago now. That isn't to say it's BAD, but it has definitely run its course. (pun intended)

My next minigame complaint pretty much falls on me; for some reason the advertising of this game led me to believe there would be a cabaret minigame where you would actually manage your own club and staff, similar to 0 and 2. Unfortunately for all of us, I was wrong. And what there is instead is an almost DOWNGRADED version of the cabaret dating minigame we had in past titles. While it's sort of interesting to see live actors portray the parts of the hostesses, the dialogue and engagement compared to the series' former cabarets is still lacking. 

The coliseum battles are definitely my favorite by far, and I'd imagine the same goes for a lot of people. It isn't without its flaws, however. The Hell Team Rumble mode is basically just a cluster of NPCs beating the crap out of each other. Don't get me wrong, that's very cool! But it's not as engaging as you'd think. It's very hard to tell what's going on until there are a few people left, and even then, it will usually be this giant tank enemy that you and your squad will just roll over. 

Going into this game I was under the impression given to me by trailers and discussions that majority of content in this entry would be on the side. I was again, correct, unfortunately. Substories have been dragged through the mud. Over world side content is now quite literally reduced to giving homeless people bentos, wearing a silly outfit for someone, or helping someone getting ganged up on. While there still are real substories with organized objectives and stories, there's only about twenty of them and they aren't added in the traditional way. Instead of finding people around Sotenbori that need your help, you get a grocery list of missions from Akame. Some of these are pretty decent. I'm particularly fond of the one where ChatGPT tells some guy to jump off a bridge. Every mission ends with you calling Akame and explaining the situation and then getting paid in Akame Points. That's all. The only thing you get from completing substories is Akame points. 

And finally the thing I personally look forward to the most when a new LAD comes out, the combat. Agent style is extremely underwhelming. It gives access to four gadgets. Two are absolutely useless, and the other two are useless but can be used if you really feel like it. I'm ranking the rocket shoes number one out of the four simply because it's just sort of fun to jet through enemies or pull yourself out of a sticky situation. The spider wire comes second because it has two things you may actually want to use it for. The first is swinging objects/enemies into other enemies to deal damage which is sort of helpful for crowd fights. The second and most useful is this attack where by pulling the enemy to you with the spider, you can punch them into a juggle where you keep attacking and they are in the air. That's all for the spider though. You're supposed to be able to constrain enemies but it only works on the weakest enemies. So don't expect to get any utility out of using the Spider during boss fights, or against any "fat enemy" type. Also it's nearly impossible to pick up weapons off the ground using the LT button with Spider. It's so finicky at times it's not even worth trying. Finally the last two little gizmos you get are the Hornet and Firefly. BOTH are useless pieces of crap that are activated by disengaging entirely with the enemy and then holding down the corresponding button for at least a whole second. This does not flow well combat-wise, and is definitely not worth the minuscule damage both do. The final redeeming thing I'll say about Agent is that the general combos are fine. In heat mode, it does a very good job of dealing with crowds.

The Yakuza fighting style however is decent. No complaints. Same old stuff different game. And it feels much better than it did in 2 and 6. 

That's pretty much all I have to say about the game. No new minigames, watered down substories, mediocre combat, and an ALRIGHT story. I don't really see a lot of criticism for these games, (apart from people crapping on 3) but there are some decisions that should be questioned more often that aren't.  

5.9 / 10

POST-GAME NOTES: I just finished the game with about 18 hours on my save file. (It's like 30 some hours on Steam, but I was afk a lot) I bumped up my final score from a 5.9 to a 6 after experiencing a fantastic final sequence of fights and cutscenes. So with an amazing final boss, and heart torturing finale, I can safely say that the story carried Gaiden.

POST-GAME COMBAT NOTES: A fully upgraded Agent left a much better, but still underwhelming taste in my mouth. I eventually grew to like Spider more than the other three gadgets as the game progressed. I think what opened my eyes was the crowds of enemies near the end that the gadget just does wonders on.

Like A Dragon Gaiden is such a huge disappointment. I can't stand playing as this Joryu guy, he's by far the worst protagonist RGG has ever made. He's just some bland generic agent with no personality, always has the same scowling look on his face. He doesn't come anywhere close to being as charismatic and endearing as other protagonists, like Ichiban and Kiryu.

Speaking of Kiryu, it's wild that so many people in the story keep thinking Joryu is Kiryu. They look nothing alike, aside from the same hairstyl. They're very obviously different people. The way characters in the game keep saying that Joryu is Kiryu, it's like the writers are trying to convince us players that they're the same guy. They are trying to make this loser Joryu ride on the success of Kiryu, and expecting us to be a naive audience who falls for it.

I'm not going to take the bait. Kiryu is my favorite video game hero, probably my favorite character in all of media. There's no way I'd ever buy that Joryu is even half as interesting as Kiryu. If they plan on making this Joryu guy the new face of the series, I might have to abstain from RGG games until they come to their senses and give us a better protagonist.

Bringing back a character whose story had been concluded close to 8 years ago is no easy task.
To say that I was skeptical about this game's story and the impact it would have on the legacy of one of my favorite characters would sure be an understatement. RGG somehow managed to beautifully tie everything together and also deliver an even better send off to the legend of Kazuma Kiryu than his initial "final Game" Yakuza 6.
Everything that was missing from Yakuza 6, due to its rocky development is here.
- better combat
- better minigames/side activities
- better bosses
- more light on the old cast of characters
Some of us were definitely expecting this game to be a cashgrab, a cheap asset flip, just to cash in on people's love for the character. They definitely cut some corners in the very short 6 months of development, but the end product is one I'm more than satisfied with.
I only have a few small gripes with this game:
- The Coliseum (while cool on paper) is very underwhelming,
movesets of pre-existing characters were butchered and really don't offer any kind of depth.
The huge team battles are also just a cluster fuck.
- The Dragon/Yakuza Style is extremely broken and just kills bosses with like 2 combos.
- Small pacing issues in an already short story: you could erase Akame from the plot and it probably wouldn't change a thing. I found her inclusion to be quite useless. She is just a tool for you to start grinding.
- The flow of combat feels a bit off in big groups at times.

But other than that, Gaiden offers basically anything a Yakuza fan could ask for.
Lastly I would like to say:
Nishitani III has become one of my favorite bosses in the series, this guy is fucking awesome.
