This game originally was going to be DLC, but it ended up becoming its own stand alone title. You can honestly finish this whole game in 12 hours if you just rush the story. So the game is obviously in the short side but I really think this is one of the best games in the franchise gameplay wise. Story itself without going into spoiler territory is a bit slow at first however it then kicks into high gear in the later chapters. Normally I would have a problem with that style of story telling (Kingdom Hearts 3 left a sour taste in my mouth) but considering the length of the game, it's not horrible to deal with. 

Side content there's a shocking amount of stuff to do. Substories wise they're a treat as usual with some great fan service. The Colosseum is easily the best it's ever been with the ability to also play as every single ally you recruit into your team is also really awesome, despite the lack of heat actions for them. 

Gameplay as I mentioned is really REALLY good, It's Lost Judgement combat with even more juggling, and the style switching for juggle combos are really smooth. I'm not claiming to be the sauciest or best gamer in the universe, however I hit some saucy ass combos on some bosses and it felt really satisfying. Agent is a really sick new style and the gadgets are pretty funny to mess around with, and the traditional Dragon Style feels at its absolute best in this game, really shows RGG is improving the combat with every new game they make. 

TLDR tho, I would honestly still wait for a sale, despite all the praise I've given this game. cuz you're paying for a 12 hour game featuring a demo of Infinite Wealth.

From an overall perspective, the game ties up things after the ending of Yakuza 6 but before the end of 7. No spoilers, but Yakuza 6 kind of ended in a strange way, and Kiryu's unexplained appearance in Like a Dragon/Y7 was pretty weird. However, this game goes out of it's way to explain it in detail, and it's a great time. As it's $50 price tag shows, it's not as long as one of the main series games, but I actually think it's a huge advantage for it. Despite the title, you should NOT buy this game if you haven't played Yakuza 6 and 7, there are major spoilers for both games in it. The new fighting style is questionable at first, but after upgrading some of the gadgets, it really comes into it's own as one of the best crowd control fighting styles in the franchise (also, super broken).

From a story perspective, I actually loved this game. Kiryu is either seen as a standard goon by people which is pretty funny, or has to be adamant that he's not Kiryu, since he's working undercover, and is officially dead, to protect his loved ones. While it's definitely not as tense as Yakuza 0 or as gripping as the first Judgment's story, the first few chapters offer a great and entertaining setup, with the side content being much more streamlined. Instead of running around and finding substories, they're given to you in bulk. There's definitely more of a focus on the main story, with side stuff actually coming secondary for the first time in ages. 

I do believe that's intentional, because the story, especially the ending, are very important to anyone interested to see how Kiryu's story ends. Not since Yakuza 0 has there been such a rough scene as the ending one to this game -- really went for the feels.

Overall, it's a buy. RGG rounded out the year with yet another stellar, cheaper entry to the franchise. If this is the end of Kiryu's story as a main protagonist, I think it's a good one. I wouldn't have minded a meatier game as a sendoff for him, but... he'll be in 8, so not a huge deal.

I'm glad to see Sega's gamble with porting these games is still paying off, 5 years strong. I think it's fostered an entirely different group of fans of the franchise and it was a great decision. Looking forward to LAD Infinite Wealth.

Gaiden is Gaiden. A short spinoff you can call Yakuza 6.5. 

Its a very short game, only 5 chapters, but those 5 chapters are pretty solid. The mini games are pretty good, many returning from 0.

Gameplay feels like Judgment with two fight styles. Dragon, and Agent.

I dont need to explain Dragon to you, so lets talk about agent.

Agent is very fun, a very fast swan like style. It comes with much fun abilities like holding square to throw bomb cigerattes, holding X to dash around and run over people with rocket shoes, holding triangle to send in drones that attack people over time and circle you while blocking, and of course the string which you can use to pull enemies, items hidden around the map, and weapons to you. It was a very fun style to pair with THE DRAGON STYLE. The unlock system is money based like 0.

The core side missions are little missions you take on for an intel woman. This woman provides many pretty good mini games from what I have played. you will unlock points for her, which allows you to get awards, upgrade your abilities. Not a huge fan they tied this into the upgrades, but fair enough. The upgrade screen is very similar to Judgments also.

THE CASTLE. What a grand and amazingly crafted location that is beautiful to see. Its a major plot point of the game and holds many gambling mini games and the wonderful coliseum you fight in. The coliseum mode is pretty awesome. You can fight as many different characters you recruit into your team, among some being very prominent characters from past games if you got the dlc preorder, as well as a suprise Judgment reference if you accomplish a certain side quest. I thought it was fighting arena done best its ever been done in the series, so if you like that you will like this. There is team battles, your team vs others, 1v1s, 1vgroups, and SPECIAL battles that usually involve weapons and special fights like certain types of bosses.

So, the only downside to this game is its incredibly short, as I said the campaign is 5 hours long. The only thing holding this game back. Idk if its fully worth 50 dollars. I would say more 30 or 40. It definitely shouldve got cut in half Id say. The story was pretty solid and well done despite how very short it was, with an incredible tie back to the moment (you know the one) in Yakuza 7 where kiryu shows up. The story ties it all up in a bow for 8 coming out the beginning of next year, and it was a pretty good experience despite how small the game is. It had a very beautiful end and truly made it feel like this is the last game Kiryu is the main protagonist in.

TL;DR: 
- 9.5/10
- Worth full price
- Should NOT be your first yakuza game.

Combat is the most refined Kiryu's ever been. A lot of changes that make wanting to learn the combat more fun. Never felt like there were any unfair fights, and you can't rely on heat actions as much encouraging you to master your moveset and new juggle mechanics.

Side content is surprisingly expansive. Best coliseum mode in any LAD game, funny side missions, and tighter systems that all interact with each other. I didn't feel like the Akame network was tacked on and I love that. It's also really well tied-in to the story, which is the best part of the game. 

I loved the story. It's basically a "mini" sequel to Yakuza 6, so existing fans will get a lot out of it. Big disclaimer- there's obvious padding in the first half of the game. But its Yakuza padding- used to onboard you to the game's side content. Which is great anyways so I didn't mind! Just when I felt like it was going to ruin the game's pacing, it stopped and the story REALLY picked up during the latter chapters. 

I don't want to spoil, but you can only fully appreciate the final hours of this game if you've played all the previous ones. It has the most bittersweet but cathartic ending I've experienced in media. It actually ruined me, and pushed my score for the game wayyy higher.

So yeah, Gaiden exceeded my expectations. Play it please. If you're a longtime fan you owe it to yourself to.

It's a considerably shorter title than other titles in this franchise, but considerably longer than the Kaito Files expansion for Lost Judgement.

Both fighting styles available to the player are fantastic and gradually become more fun to use the deeper into the game you get. Agent is the style that the game is definitely pushing harder than the Yakuza style, as it has all the new goofy mechanics and gizmos that were advertised as a selling point for this game. Oh, and Tiger Drop is an ability you can use in combat as well.

The soundtrack is, as expected of a title of this series, great. My favorite track has to be Cold Fire.

The story... I have feelings about it. It takes place after Yakuza 6, and leads up to the halfway point of Yakuza 7/Like A Dragon. Playing both titles before this is absolutely required, I think; there are flashbacks and references to events of both games that spoil their respective titles. For the sake of not spoiling anyone who has yet to play it, I will not say anything further. 

There's a lot of side content available in this title, and a little somethin' somethin' for the Judge Eyes/Lost Judgement fans as well! The game also includes a special trial version of Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth available right away from the main menu upon launch.

For 50 dollars, and with how much extra time you get out of the side content in these titles, that's well worth your money. I powered through the story mode and it took me ~22 hours, with a bit of grinding on the side for abilities. Give it a go.

I just finished the game and got my last achievement so I'm going into this review pretty fresh. Like a Dragon: Gaiden is an absolutely phenomenal entry in a series that I've grown to adore. The gameplay continues to be refined with each entry, and I'd say this is about on par with Lost Judgement in regards to combat. Though there are only two stances, the insane gadgets you unlock for Agent stance more than make up for it. The extreme variety of side content is here as always, with most everything being an iteration on existing minigames to make them a bit more engaging, most notably the clan battles from Yakuza Kiwami 2 and Yakuza 6 are actual battles you participate in instead of that weird tower defense thing. On that note, this is one of the best iterations of The Coliseum in the entire franchise, though there is one specific substory fight that you'll need to level up your clan for. The map size isn't particularly large, roughly the size of the Majima Saga from Yakuza Kiwami 2, but there is considerably more content and variety packed into here than you'd think. If you're a fan of these games you can buy this with no worries, you'll be satisfied for sure.

Story is shockingly engaging for something that's filling the gap between Yakuza 6 and Like a Dragon, I genuinely wasn't expecting to be as interested in anything outside of Kiryu himself but that wasn't the case at all. Akame is an excellent addition to the cast and is a joy on screen, pretty much every character punches well above their weight in terms of what you'd expect from a spinoff entry. I cannot recommend this game enough if you're a fan of Yakuza and Kiryu in particular, longtime fans will have an absolutely ton of references that they can pick up on. On top of all of this, there's a demo for Infinite Wealth included so you can get your feet wet for that entry. RGG Studios has turned into one of my favorite developers to watch right now and this game is a testament to their skill. It's absolutely unbelievable that this was made in six months.
Yakuza 6.5 didn't disappoint at all. I will forever be a fan of Like A Dragon till the day it ends (or till it sucks)

I am a big fan of the Like A Dragon series and although initially excited, was also skeptical of this game since LAD Gaiden follows a more different structure than other mainline games and follows similarly, according to some developer interviews, to The Kaito Files, a special DLC for Lost Judgment. I actually like these shorter Like A Dragon experiences since the mainline LAD games, even the old ones, are very lengthy and have so much stuff to do. So this is a nice break and spin of the usual formula and opens more potential for more stories that can be told in the LAD universe if the devs wishes to do some.

Like A Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name is a LAD game that focuses on an undercover Kiryu Kazuma being an agent of the Daidoji faction, assuming the name Joryu. This game being a Gaiden (side-story) tells a fun and simple and somewhat interesting tale about this new side of Kiryu Kazuma. Being an agent means he will always fight and do combat (as he always do) and enables him to have a very new and unique style which is Agent Style that gives him alot of spy tools and gadgets.

The story is okay and simple but I will say my criticisms for the story is that there are really no stakes. This is mainly because the game takes place at the same time as Yakuza 7 and the whole goal of Gaiden's story is to reach a crucial moment that will impact the overall story in Yakuza 7. So any moments where Kiryu and his friends are in danger, never really feel like actual danger since they all are in Yakuza 7. Another criticism I'll give is on a certain antagonist that I was kinda hyped due to how much backstory he has but ultimately, he's just another generic villain that is evil.

I will say that this is the most chill Yakuza or Like A Dragon game. Kiryu in this game is somehow the best he has ever been. Kiryu Kazuma has always been a very interesting and very well-written character starting from Yakuza 1 to Yakuza 6 with the sixth game being tying a neat bow to Kiryu's saga. That's why I was skeptical towards this game's release since for me Kiryu's tale is already done, but fortunately Kiryu has a great comeback and he comes hard. While there's daddy Kiryu in Yakuza 3, depressed Kiryu in Yakuza 5, and angery Kiryu in Yakuza 6, LAD Gaiden has peak, Dragon of the Dojima Kiryu Kazuma.

In some way it is brilliant to have Kiryu being an agent to showcase his pure intelligence, raw skill, talent and charisma, that really presents why Kiryu is the Dragon of Dojima since in the past games, there was never really a moment of that part of Kiryu's life other than being mentioned and told by characters countless times. Even Yakuza 0, the prequel that shows his origins, only presents the period before his tenure as the Dragon of Dojima. 

All the characters in LAD Gaiden are likable as there always banter between Kiryu and them. I really love the more quiet moments where they are just chilling out eating, or just complimenting each other, or just..... talking. Although Kiryu and his peers are mostly out of the norm, being a Yakuza and all, the writing and the dialogue makes them all very grounded and very relatable.

Combatwise, it is okay. I am still getting used to Agent Style and found myself using it when fighting larger crowds, but ultimately all the tools you use as an agent like whips are very fun and crazy as they always been. Kiryu has two fighting styles with the other being Yakuza Style which is the classic traditional Kiryu combat from past games. There's also the juggling system from Lost Judgment so Kiryu can finally juggle enemies too. I'm not an expert when it comes to Like A Dragon combat but I've lot of fun with it here.

Being a shorter Like A Dragon game like Kaito Files, this game is obviously short. I finished the main story in 20 hours and there are two big side-content which are the classic substories (but in a unique spin) and the fighting arena (which also has unique spin). My only criticism is only on the substories with the gang related substories being very repetitive and tedious as hell. But that's just my only main complaint since the other substories are bangers as all things should be.

Music for me is also kinda okay. There some bangers that kinda mixed in with not so banger ones. Some of the not so bangers are kinda generic, trailer musicish, but the banger ones are great like Deadly Struggle, Un Altro Appasionato, and the Yakuza Style theme.

When comparing between Kaito Files and LAD Gaiden, I ultimately prefer Kaito Files first mainly because of how high the stakes are there. Not to the discredit how high the stakes can be in LAD Gaiden, but LAD Gaiden is also a fun time with Kiryu and I'm kinda glad he's somehow back. Comparing to the mainline games isn't really fair since this is a much smaller game and different direction, but LAD Gaiden does takes elements from mainly the Kiryu Saga games and offers abit of homage to them.

I recommend those who have played the Yakuza games to play this. For newcomers are also welcome since this game is great at recapping some aspects but mostly in Kiryu's backstory.

Overall, a solid and short Like A Dragon experience.

Best Yakuza/Like a Dragon game.

I didn't expect this game to be as wonderful as it is. I was expecting to like it but it's just a side game for the series. But instead it's now one of my favorite games in the series. It's the best Kiryu game in terms of gameplay and Kiryu's journey in the main story absolutely destroyed me at points and it makes me so so so excited for Infinite Wealth. RGG has just been making banger after banger ever since Yakuza 5 and they just keep getting better.

LAD: Gaiden is proof that RGG can still make a Kiryu-centric entry in the series, and have it all feel novel and entertaining. The story is simple, but the melodrama and action are cranked up to 11, and the boss fights throughout are all really fun. The combat has a good rhythm between the crowd-clearing Agent Style, and the slow, powerful Yakuza style. The only downside is the lack of combo speed upgrades. Akame's network provides a good balance between fetch quests, side content incentives, and some fun stories in Sotenbori. The new coliseum is really fun, the ability to play as new fighters is novel, and you really need to max out your resources hear in order to beat every possible fight. The castle itself is a great way to grind money, fool around with customization via the boutique, and overall just have a good time. 

All in all, the only bad part of this game is the cost, but beyond needing to wait for a sale to justify this game's purchase, it is a great entry for series veterans, and proof that RGG can do anything and do it damn well.

I'll start the review by saying that this game is not worth sixty dollars. 

However, with that being stated! I still would recommend you play this game because it's a fantastic installment to the Like A Dragon franchise and gives some real emotional payoff that has been in the making for seven installments with our remarkable stoic protagonist Kazuma Kiryu. 

This game is best consumed after playing Yakuza 7: Like A Dragon. 

With all that being said my biggest complaint with this game is how incredibly short it is compared to other games in the franchise. I completed the story in about eleven hours and got the final achievement right at the eighteenth hour mark. 

The basic plot summary for this game without getting into many details is that after faking his death at the end of Yakuza 6: Song of Life, Kiryu is roped up into a plot to protect the people he cares about most, while some shady individuals try to reign control of the Dragon of Dojima to benefit themselves.

Outside of the main story you can partake in many side activities that are not forced. There is a collection of accomplishments you can do if that sort of thing strikes your fancy. You can also partake in little side missions to help people's issues that just give a cute little slice-of-life feel to break up the pace of the story if you like. However, within this game, the big chunk of your time outside of the side missions that you get through this woman named Akane is that of the coliseum. The introduction to this game's gimmick that being the Hell Team Rumble was very enjoyable for what it was and I wish there was more to it. 

The game is beyond beautiful, runs perfectly on my computer, and sound quality is great! The change of just two fighting styles instead of just the Dragon of Dojima style we got used to over the course of the games is a nice change of pace. Agent style is stupidly not balanced, but! Balance isn't really an issue in this single-player experience because the combat is utter perfection. 

With that! I would recommend you buy this game, maybe at a discount if you can... However, if you're willing to spend 60 on a 12 hour game go ahead, you'll have a fantastic time. 

PS: Make Amon great again...

This stems from playing Yakuza 0, Yakuza Kiwami 1, Yakuza Kiwami 2 and Yakuza: Like a Dragon.
As far as story telling goes, it not very exciting. It really doesnt get exciting until Chapter 4 (out of 5). Of the games in the series I have played, this really felt like a DLC - A Colosseum game with quests and a lot larger gambling space really is what this game sums up to be. 

Youre mainly stuck in Sotenbori. Have little to nothing to do in Ijinjo and you dont even get to touch Kamurocho. They do tie in their Yakuza Like a Dragon game and the upcoming games in the series and it does cover the tiny interaction Kiryu had with Kasuga and thats it. 

They bring back some of the  references and players from their previous titles which kind of gets me engaged just a little more, but the face value it brings falls below my expectation. In perspective, I spent more time finishing the Cyberpunk DLC alone at 100% achievement than this game also at 100% achievements. Ill get more into the game details towards the end. 

Fighting feels a little sloppy. Im glad they brought back the button mashing brawl way of fighting. He doesnt really reach to hit the next enemy so there is a lot of air combat. You get 2 fighting modes: Agent mode where you can use your weapon arsenal which is great to use for anyone who is not a boss. 
Then you have Yakuza mode that is good for bosses which is pretty much it. 

As far as using or finding weapons, you cannot keep or equip any weapon. The weapon you use in that fight only last until the end of the battle scene, until you use a heat action or until you are knocked down. \
Unlike other Yakuza games, you can stack similar items and have compounding stacks. Here, you cannot. 

They got rid of the food combos for more effective healing and they also removed item sets for boosted stats. When youre swapping out gear, the equipment screen does not tells you what stats the current item gives, but it will indicate what stats will change when you swap it out. They dont show duplicates which makes equipping gear much simpler and easier, but its also very limited and shrunken down. 

Im so glad that the golf mini game has gotten so much better to play. The golf mini game is actually fun to play and enjoyable. The Karaoke game feels like an actual rhythm game now because the buttons match the beats but you can only sing with Akame- no one else.

The achievements are realistic to accomplish. Unlike the Kiwami versions of the game, the achievements are impossible feats of perfection. This one at least, you dont have to play the game up to a certain level to be able to get the achievement to pop. 

Its cool that there are quests you can do depending on the outfit youre wearing. I would like to see more of this in future titles, but make it where you can change your outfit in your home base or even use your Colosseum outfit out in the open like a regular costume. It also shows the change of outfit during the cutscenes. This game only allows you to change outfit in one place, and its troublesome to access sometimes.

POCKET RACING - even with guides, you really have to work for your wins and you do really have to utilize your boosts and stabilize abilities at the right times. Its so much more fun. 

They did try to do something unique with their cabaret club interaction where they make it more like an interactive movie instead of the usual game graphics. Its unique; like the photography studio sidequest on Yakuza Kiwami 1. 

As for the overall game, the writers did a great job with the ending. It portrayed very strong emotions and does tie in Kiryu (in this case, Joryu) with the whole reason he had his name erased in the first place. Its just THAT ending scene alone is what makes playing thru feel a little rewarding. Still, all things considered, I still felt more disappointed than satisfied (or even just ok) with this game as a whole. 

its really difficult to justify paying for this game at full price. Its fun, but it just felt lacking - unfinished even. Im really hoping that they get to add perks in the next game for people who bought this one because it really doesnt feel worth it.

Allow me to give you a different perspective that you won't often encounter. I love Yakuza 7. I love the character of Ichiban. I also love the Judgement series with Yagami. For the games with Kiryu as the MC? I've not been as enthusiastic. I've tried multiple games with him it, including Ishin....but I wasn't able to get "in" to previous games with Kiryu as the MC, because of how stoic he is as a character. I bought this game as something to hold me over until Y8. THIS game? I'm starting to like Kiryu. Is he stil stoic? Yes, but this time it feels better.

First things first, the "movie" cut-scenes?  *chef's kiss* It's amazing, and considerably the best that RGG has ever made. It doesn't take very long in order to get to the action and getting you invested on wondering what's going to happen next and why people are trying to get Kiryu back into the fold. Kiryu's fighting is smoother than ever and "secret agent" style is definitely my go-to choice when in combat. At first glance, you might think the blue rope attack is stupid.....but on the contrary....it's very useful at times and somehow never loses it's appeal as you progress through the game. 

Speaking of progressing, you may notice that in chapter 1 that your exploration in the city is limited to the direction of the next cutscene. Don't worry, this is done away with by chapter 2. 

The story introduces a new character to the Yakuza franchise. This character is the one that offered Kiryu money to "die" at the end of Y6. He is back and he is Kiryu's handler. On top of that, he seems to be a pretty honorable guy. I've not yet finished the game, but I hope he stays true to the end. 

If there is one thing that I DON'T like about the game? It's that to get new moves or to increase your health/stats......it's not done by experience of battle, but by money. What this means is that when you are spending money on clothes/armor, food, etc....you're also having to use it to upgrade Kiryu. This will mean that you will need to grind more than ever to improve Kiryu. 

What would I rate the game as of now? Without even getting into everything the game has to offer? I would give it a 9 out of 10.

Completed the story in roughly 20 hours, absolute must play for any Yakuza fan, the gameplay is the best it's ever been for Kiryu, Agent style is pretty neat and innovative, but Yakuza style was a huge standout for me due to the new rework of extreme heat, it's an absolute blast, and the regular moveset feels like the best of both worlds from the early dragon engine games Y6/YK2, and the earlier games which I found great. 

Loved the story, it really broke my expectations of what I thought it would be, a very classic and satisfying yakuza story with great characters and hype moments, the ending in particular gave me Yakuza 5 vibes, except even better.

The minigames are a good collection of everything from the series, but I actually found the new substories to be extremely engaging, even moreso than the old games, they felt very focused and well curated, albeit at a numerical cost, but that's fine though, since I think it could be easy to get burnt out on them due to how it ties into progression (also a good thing)

So for 50 dollars in 2023 you're already getting a really decent bang for buck in regards to the actual quality of the game even if it's not that crazy long, I felt it was similar length to Anno Mutationem (25 bucks), it's awfully nice having a fun, polished, gorgeous, optimized game on launch in this day and age, so I still recommend it regardless, this game is about quality over quantity.

The Man Who Erased His Name is a filler entry that closes the gap between Yakuza 6 and 7 whilst also providing Kiryu some additional closure that wasn't entirely given in Yakuza 6's ending. The ending also gives justification for why Kiryu ends up in Hawaii at the beginning of Infinite Wealth. I wouldn't consider this game a must play but it is a great send off for (what I assume) will be Kiryu's final game in which he is the sole protagonist.

If the price wasn't a giveaway, Gaiden is a short game by modern Yakuza/LaD standards. That's no bad thing as the developers made it clear that the scope of this game is that of DLC, rather than a full fledged Yakuza title. I managed to finish the story in about 22 hours, if you include a copious amount of side content. The main story is about 14 hours or so, which would put it closer to Yakuza 1 or 2's main story if you want some idea of how long this game is. You only ever have access to Sotenbori which is one of the tiniest districts in the series history, as well as the "Castle" a large sea container turned into a makeshift playground for societies richest and most depraved individuals. 

A shorter experience is no bad thing if the game is made with this in mind and Gaiden mostly sticks to the same successful formula every other Yakuza entry has followed since the original in 2005. Kiryu plays similarly to how he felt in 6, but this time he has a brand new style (Agent) alongside his traditional Yakuza style. Agent is a technique style, combining fast punches with gadgets that can take out multiple enemies at a time. It has a lot of versatility for both single and multiple enemies once you've upgrade it. His traditional style isn't weaker because of how strong Agent is, but it is very powerful and there isn't a huge reason to use his Yakuza style outside of one-on-one encounters. The combat is almost as fun as Lost Judgement's. You can combo and juggle people while switching styles on the fly. If you enjoyed Judgement or any of the Dragon Engine combat in previous games, you will love the combat here.

Side content in Gaiden is generally strong but can also be very repetitive. Not unusual for any game in the series, but it might feel like padding if you consider how short the overall plot is. There are several returning minigames, but nothing particularly noteworthy outside of Daytona 2 being available in the arcade for the first time ever. The cabaret club minigame from the first few games makes a return (not managing a club, just the experience of visiting one). The main draw here is that it uses full motion video using real actors, instead of in game models simply using their likeness. 

I'll be real here: it makes for a pretty uncomfortable and awkward viewing experience. I'm not the target demographic for this content so I'll avoid saying that it's outright bad, but I think it would be in everyone's interest if this went the way of the pachinko minigame for future games. I have no problem with this minigame returning if people want it, but I think it should just be an optional download if the FMVs are going to eat up several gigs of data. 

The Hero requests from Like a Dragon also make a return, which are about as interesting as they were in that game, by which I mean they are pretty underwhelming. You do whatever a random NPC asks of you and you are rewarded with currency to upgrade Kiryu. The side content here is fine for a game of this size, but outside of the Coliseum which is the best in the series history, it isn't much to write home about.

The story deals with Kiryu having to live a double life after the events of Yakuza 6. He is isolated and is effectively stuck doing jobs for a faction he doesn't truly care for. It's entertaining but like most Yakuza games, last few twists feel a bit forced and if you think about it too much, you will question the logic and motivation of any given character. It's not unusual for a soap opera and if you've played virtually any game in this series, you're used to a few contrivances here and there. That being said, the new characters introduced in this game are excellent and the final boss is one of the best in the series. I really loved the Omi crew and Akame quickly became one of my favourite side ladies in the series. She's peppy and a bit boisterous but not annoying or "quirky", just a high spirited woman whose personality clashes with Kiryu's stoic and reserved nature. Despite the colossal difference in personalities, they work well together. I hope she returns if the series ever heads back to Sotenbori. 

And without spoiling anything specific, I will say that the ending to this game may be one of the best in the series. It was incredibly cathartic in a way that 6's was not. Especially if you've played Yakuza 1/Kiwami and Yakuza 3. While I did enjoy 6's ending, Gaiden's last few minutes give Kiryu closure on events that were only ever hinted at and it successfully shows the passing of time in a really painful and tragic way. 

Gaiden also has a bonus demo after completion for Infinite Wealth. I didn't play too much of it because I don't want any major story spoilers, but you can roam around a sizeable portion of Hawaii (whilst riding a segway!) and do a few substories, minigames and battle. The English dub has also been provided in that demo and you can listen to Judgement being sung in English if you want to punish yourself.

Overall not bad. The story is quite entertaining for Kiryu fans, but feels quite fan servicey at times, such as bringing back previous bosses like [spoiler]Ryuji & Kiryu cosplayers as bosses[/spoiler], and naming a character after one from 0. One of the Special Coliseum battles is even a gauntlet of robot versions of the previous endgame bosses w/ their respective themes playing.

The nice thing about this entry is that 100% compendium completion isn't required for all achievements, so you can get them all without being good at Mahjong or Shogi. I did it in about 29 hours.

The combat feels less polished than other entries, and has design choices that sometimes make me wonder what RGG was thinking. 
- When not locked on you can't dodge in a direction, meaning if you want to create space from a crowd you have to first lock on which easily throws off muscle memory for longtime fans. 
- Bosses are given grab attacks that are inescapable once they connect, other games had this but never to this extent, as someone else put it, it often feels like you're fighting Zangeif in SF. 
- The rush combo speed you're given is also incredibly slow, and since there's no combo speed upgrades you have to use Agent as your fast hitting style or play like you're always on the lowest heat level in Y0. It's mostly a problem for the Yakuza style, because if you're used to the Y6/K2 moveset, the contrast in speed can throw you off since it takes so much longer for the combos to come out. As such I recommend mods to increase the speed so that you're not literally always slower than who you're fighting. 
- Bosses are given insane hyper armor and no sell your attacks unless from behind turning some fights into Resolute Counter/Charge light --> Spam heal fests. 
- Tutorial pop-up telling me to guard vs. Nishitani who has a knife.
- The lock on is also inconsistent, so much so that this's the only Yakuza game I've had a problem with it. It can make the Spider gadget harder to use than it needs to be since you'll lock on to whatever boss or strongman is in the crowd and be unable to tether them, or in general when it targets random enemies nowhere near you and you whiff every hit until you release and actually get who you want.

Despite all the issues I have with the combat I enjoyed most of the story and especially the final chapter and have to say the final boss and section before it was incredibly hype. The ending makes me hopeful for Kiryu's character even though RGG should really make Ichiban the new head of the series and put an end to Kiryu's story.

Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name is a decent addition to the series and offers an enjoyable even if a little short roller coaster ride of a story along with yet another iteration of the brawler style combat. As a long time fan of the series I had my fun with the game but at same time I couldn't help but to feel like I was playing through a glorified expansion sold at a premium and one where it might be a little difficult to justify the price tag unless you plan to do most of the side content as the main story is really short.

Combat system is a fun iteration of the older brawler combat which is a welcome improvement after the somewhat lackluster combat of Kiwami 2 and Yakuza 6, although it isn't without its flaws and the more you level up the more those blemishes start to show especially in terms of balancing. In addition to the familiar fighting style of Kiryu game introduces a new agent style which focuses bit more on finesse, stylish counters and utilizes some rather hilarious spy gadgets that you unlock as you progress through the story.

As expected of a Yakuza title there is a plethora of minigames and a chunk of side content, minigames could be described as a sort of "best of" collection of various things you've seen along the years with some new things sprinkled in here and there, side content on the other hand felt like bit of a letdown. Substories for the most part are rather generic and a far cry from some of the more whacky and memorable ones the series is known for, combine that with some bland "fetch quests" that the game introduces - I think the best way to describe them would be disappointing.

That being said I had my fun with the game and enjoyed the roughly 26 hours it took me to beat it on professional difficulty while doing all of the substories, almost all of the fetch quests and a good chunk of the minigames. If you're a huge fan of the series I think this is an easy recommendation even if it might be worth playing the game on game pass or waiting for discounts instead of purchasing it at full price.

[h1]🐉Spies and Yakuza🕵️[/h1]

This is a game about Kiryu ending a lot of conclusions of the mainline history of the games, if you are the kind of people who didn't like the JRPG, this is the other side of the history of Yakuza 7: Like a Dragon and summarises all. Nevertheless, both games are great and made with a lot of care.

[h2]🎮Gameplay[/h2]

Remember Yakuza 0? and the EXP system that is fixed with money? This system is similar because you upgrade using the money made in combat, exploring or doing side-quests but in addition to a point system of doing little side-quests and secondary quest to Akame.

The combat has 2 stances, there's a Spy one that is focused on using gadgets and AOE to the enemies, with tools like the "spider whip" to toss the enemies, unarm them, etc... Rocket boots, Drones and my favourite one, the exploding cigar. The other stance is Dragon, it's all the normal combat you should expect if you played this saga.

Finally, there are some mini-games and Pocket-Circuit returned once again. If you played the saga like I am, you should be able to exploit all the systems and have fun. The only thing is that the game is a bit shorter than the mainline ones, make sure to know it if you want to wait for a sale.

[h2]📕History[/h2]

We are a few years after Yakuza 6: Song of Life, Kiryu is working with the "Daidoji Faction" and it's like the "Deep State" of this fictional Japan. Also, this game happens at the same time as Yakuza 7: Like a Dragon with another perspective and more insights about the resolution of the "3K Plan" of the dissolution of the Yakuza/Gokudo.

[h2]🎨Art [/h2]

This game is made in UE5 but still feels like all the Yakuza games, even if the same assets look a bit recycled or refurbished, Sotenbori looks awesome with all those billboards, neon lights, etc... beautiful scenery with tons of details and little things. As always, the character models and expressions are top-notch, great and expressive, even the NPCs look great.

Like a Dragon Gaiden: The Man Who Erased His Name is by far the shortest game in the Like a Dragon series so far, and it only took me just under 14 hours to beat it while going for quite a bit of the side content along the way. However, make no mistake, this is probably one of the best games in the series to date, with solid combat, story, and setting.

The combat is by far the most fluid and fun in the series to date, beating out Lost Judgment as it takes all the strengths from that game and combines it with new and interesting mechanics to make it more interesting. Kiryu has 2 styles, Agent and Yakuza. Yakuza is very similar to Kiryu's Dragon of Dojima style from 1-6, with a few extra moves added in, but the Agent style is completely different, with 4 different gadgets to use during combat, and a moveset that is more suited to dealing with large groups of enemies.

The story, without spoiling too much, perfectly bridges the gap between the end of Yakuza 6 and the end of Yakuza: Like a Dragon, showcasing Kiryu's perspective during that time. It also gives you extra info about what some characters (I won't say who) from a previous game are up to in the present. 

The game itself is set in Sotenbori (with a brief section in Isezaki Ijincho towards the beginning of the game) now expanded to include the park which was noticeably absent in previous iterations of Sotenbori in the Dragon Engine. It may seem like a small change but it really makes Sotenbori feel a lot bigger and more lively with a wider variety of places to visit.

Finally, there's the part I was most excited for before this game released, which is the trial of Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth included after beating the main story. I haven't played much of it so far but it's an amazing reward which offers a sneak peek into what the next game will be like.

Overall, if you enjoyed Yakuza 6 or Yakuza: Like a Dragon, I'd definitely recommend purchasing this game, as there is so much that's offered in addition to a preview of the next game in the series before it's released.

A bit pricey overall, but a must-play for anyone who played through Kiryu's saga and 7 and is looking forward to 8 (Infinite Wealth). Spices up the combat with unique gimmicks, adds the best Coliseum the franchise has seen so far, really nice outfit customization (mods are gonna make it wild 100%) and a nice variant of Part-Time Hero for things to do in Sotenbori. 

Having finished the story, it is definitely more entertaining than a lot of story beats of other games in the franchise, that's for sure, and there's nice references to previous games scattered across the main story and substories. It ties into the events of 7 really nicely and the finale is amazing.

[b]Do note:[/b] for best experience you'd have ideally played all of the previous games, but in general here are the recommendations:
- 6 and 7 are absolute must-plays: Gaiden goes into the story beats of 7 a lot and connects the timeline between 6 and 7 and doesn't hold back on going into all details of what happens in 7. It doesn't go into much detail of events of 6, however, other than the one reason why Kiryu is The Man Who Erased His Name
- 3 and 5 are next on the list of must-plays: to fully grasp the emotional side of Kiryu's experience throughout his journey in Gaiden and to basically feel the feels for the man. I felt many feels, ok, and I didn't enjoy 3 at all but ngl what they did here kinda made my suffering of playing 3 on Hard worth it
- Kiwami 1 and 2 aren't a must-play, but it's good to have played them both to understand a few references and callbacks here and there
- 0 and 4 are kind of not really relevant at all, surprisingly, other than for Pocket Circuit I guess

Probably the most well-tuned brawler produced by RGG using the Dragon engine I have personally seen. Runs exceptionally well on AMD hardware. The story is a little faster paced compared to other Like a Dragon fare, though this isn't a bad thing since the story itself is said to be shorter, and it doesn't bog the player with exposition that they either should already know or be able to ascertain themselves. The emotional beats are on point as always. It is very much a Like a Dragon game for Like a Dragon fans.
Special mention to go the music. Whether it is the 007 style jazz for "Agent Style", the amazing karaoke tracks (both old and new) or the creeping 80s synth when Kiryu wanders the neon streets of Sotenbori, the soundtrack lives up to the bar raised by its predecessors. 
While if you are new I would recommend playing the other titles first in order to appreciate the full story of this game, if you are familiar or especially a fan, both young or old, Like a Dragon Gaiden is a masterful chapter in the saga of Kazuma Kiryu.

Daytona USA 2: Battle on the Edge (known simply as Daytona USA 2 (デイトナＵＳＡ２, Deitona USA 2) in Japan) is an arcade racing game released by Sega in 1998 as a follow-up to the extremely successful Daytona USA. The game featured vastly superior graphics, utilizing the Sega Model 3 hardware. The majority of Daytona USA 2 cabinets were released as deluxe models (with far fewer Twin Cabinets), which could be linked together for up to sixteen players. A notable change from the original is the ability to select a car and corresponding driver, each with varying capabilities for varying levels of player experience. Just like before, the game has three courses – a Beginner course with 8 laps with a distance of 1 mile (1.6 km), an Advanced course with 4 laps with a distance of 2.5 miles (4.0 km), and a long Expert course with 2 laps with a distance of 5 miles (8.0 km). The 'time lap' mode also returns, and is accessed in the same manner – by holding down start at the transmission select screen. Like the original game, mirrored versions of the tracks can also be played by holding down the Start button when selecting the course. It is recommended, however, that the player has had mastery of the course beforehand. By request, an arcade operator could put the game on Grand Prix or Endurance mode to increase the number of laps in a game. Finishing a race in the top 3 in any course allows the player to view an "ending" and see the game credits. An addition to the game was the "slingshot", corresponding to advanced NASCAR drafting techniques.
